Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:When would you be able to see your reflection in a piece of wood? Choices:  A: burned B: polished C: carved D: composted E: nailed<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>To see your reflection in a mirror, you must be able to see yourself. But the problem doesn’t state anything about a mirror.<n>When I hear wood, that means we should be focusing on a piece of wood that has been made into a board or used to build something. (Burned, Polished, Carved, and Nailed)<n><n>(Burned) In order to see your reflection in burned wood we must be able to recognize a reflection in it. Is my reflection visible in this charred, black piece of wood I just burned? Yes. A hot charcoal fire will still burn when turned upside down so the reflection will still be there. <n><n>When we burn wood we can get the following types of burns like black charcoal, carbon dust, wood, and other impurities that we get from the fire. A piece of wood can reflect these items. I can see a reflective image of my face in a charred piece of wood that has black charcoal on it. However, the black charred wood isn't all used for a reflection. Darkened wood may be used to make wood furniture.<n><n>(Polished) I will not be able to see my reflection in a board that is polished because it needs an unpolished surface to make a reflection. To see a reflection, you must be able see something. Polishing something will take the rough texture away. Since the wood is smooth, you cannot see your reflection.<n><n>(Carved) Carving wood into something different requires the wood to have a rough texture. Because it is rough, you might be able to see more details when you look at a piece of wood with a small opening/hole. I wouldn't see a reflection on a carved piece of wood. It is carved. To get the best reflection you must have a smooth uncarved surface because you cannot see details of your face. <n><n>(Nail) A reflection requires a smooth surface. Nailing in order to assemble a board into a home. To nail a board, you will use a hammer or a screwdriver. To assemble it, you will need to screw two boards together, it will get the job done faster, and it won't be loose. You cannot place a board together by using nails. The use of nails wouldn’t be able to produce a reflection because it

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where is basketball court likely to be outdoors? Basketball was played by two teams, and the team score was 17-10. What was the point difference? Choices:  a: 10 b: seven c: 7 d: negative seven<n><n>### a:10<n><n>### Rationales:  Point difference equals team score minus the opponents score. The teams scored a 17-17. Therefore, the point difference is 10.<n><n>### A: What is the rule of thumb for making sure my clothes don't fall for the floor? Choices:  One: I place my pants on a chair. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where is microphone boom likely to be used to record an album? A microphone boom is a telescoping pole which allows a mikecorder to be moved close to a performer's mouth. This way, people can speak into the mike with greater ease.<n>

Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The old man was retired and liked the simple things, he would do crossword puzzle every morning simply just to do what? Choices:  A: you're bored B: pass time C: relax D: mentally challenged E: win<n><n>### Response:		Choice A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question. <n><n>### Demostration: How much was it?<n><n>### Demosrt: You go to a book store where you are given $10 to spend on any book of your choice. You pick the book “Adventures of Alice in Wonderland” and the price tag reads $9.49. How much change is given to you?<n><n>### Step 1: You go to a store where you are given 10 dollars to spend. You pick Alice in Wonderland for 9.49 and the book clerk will give you 55 cents for change.<n><n>Answer: 55
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The man was cleaning clothes for his date, what was he looking to achieve? Choices:  A: ruined B: clean clothes C: sadness D: attractive appearance E: look better<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions: Answer using the following three choices.<n><n>### Response Question:  If there were $13 in a bank when an additional amount of $7 is deposited, how much would be in the bank if an additional amount of $8 was deposited? Choices: 1) 20, 2) 21, 3) 22, 4) 23<n><n>### Response Answer: 23<n><n>13 + (7) + (8) = 23<n><n>Input: Which of the following describes a function of 20,40,80,100, and 120? <n><n>a) an expression that is greater than 20 b) two expressions c) an inequality d) an equation<n><n>Rationales: <n><n>* For a function to be an expression, at least two elements should be involved. Therefore, an inequality is the only expression that does not describe any combinations of values.<n>* Two inequalities are given here, one of which is $x < 20$. The latter statement describes four choices and  one of the combinations should involve $4x$. Therefore, the other statement should involve an equal sign.<n>* The other inequality should contain three expressions and therefore should not contain any expressions that are greater than $20$.<n><n>Answer: e<n><n>### Input<n><n>I am going for a walk in the park. I decide to bring 18 apples, and then it occurs to me that I will feel better if I eat an apple a day. That way, I will eat 2 apples for every 9 apples I put in my bag. If I were to pack away 10 apples, how many apples would I have to eat every day?<n><n>Choice A. Twelve<n><n>Choice B. Six<n><n>Choice C. 17<n><n>Choice D. Nine<n><n>Choice E. Eighteen<n><n><n>### Choice E<n><n><n># Exercises<n><n>### Exercise<n><n>### Instruct: Given the table below, determine if the function is increasing/decreasing on set A or B<n><n>### Exercises on A<n><n>### Demos: <n><n>* x = 5 7 = 13<n><n>Answer: Dec
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Choices:  A: idaho B: shopping mall C: big city D: in town E: new york<n><n>### Response:		The answer lies with C.<n><n>### If they need a lot of customers<n>C, because the mall gets a lot of foot traffic<n><n>### If the store is not very popular<n>B, to compete with the other stores<n><n>### Input (involving fractions): In addition to being a member of the baseball team, George is also a member of the track team. Of all the track team members, 40% of them are runners and 60% of them are members of other sports teams. George is a member of the track and field team. In terms of membership in the team, George is what percent a runner?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: Let the track and filed team be the "track team" and the number of track and field members be s. <n><n>Then, lets say that the whole track team has 100 runner, which accounts for 40% of their total members. <n>Then, the remaining members would be s-100, which accounts for 60% of the  team's total 	members.<n>Therefore, 60% of s represents runner percentage on the track team. <n>If George is a member of this team, he/she would also be a member of the track. <n>Therefore, 100% of s gives number of track team members to George.<n>This means he/she is 40% of s.<n>That's George's runner percentage on the track.<n>Answer: 20<n><n>### If 32% of adults in a certain region read at a level of 9-12; what percentage of children in preschool through 12th grade are at this level of proficiency?<n>### Demostrafion:<n>Input:<n>In any population, it is a good idea to average out the proficiency level.<n><n>So, instead of adding up all the people (children) in the region, and get the percent change by finding percentages out of the whole population, it's better to divide the population into 2 parts: the adult portion, and the child portion to get the final result. <n><n>We do this by taking 32% of the population and dividing 32% by 100% (100% is what the final

Choices:  A: suitcase B: filing cabinet C: computer D: desk drawer E: cloud<n><n>### Response:		E (the answer is not A, B, C, or D. It is only the answer E because it is the cloud that someone keeps a digital file.)<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input:Where can someone keep their important documents? Choices: <n><n>- A: suitcase<n>- B: filing cabinet<n>- C: computer<n>- D: desk drawe<n>- E: cloud<n><n>Now, let's have a look at what is said.<n><n>The sentence "Where can someone keep a document?" is a request for someone to provide the place or a location to store the document.<n><n>From the answer choices given, there are two which match or do not match this.<n><n>There is "A: suitcase" which was the place where a document is stored.<n><n>There is also "E: cloud" which is the place where the document is also stored.<n><n>The sentence said "important documents" and that shows that the information on the document is vital or important, thus an easy way of protecting it is to put it in the cloud.<n><n>Therefore, E which is "cloud" is also the only answer that matches a location that can store important documents.<n>I also need to state that a desk drawer is not an important place because most people don't usually keep important documents in drawer but only in boxes that are safe.<n><n>The person who was asked to answer the given question is probably a person who is very careful with important documents and so would put all the important documents in a very safe place just like in a cloud.<n><n>There are also other places where people put important documents but those are not the place used by a person who cares for the documents.<n><n>### Input<n>There has been a fire in your office and all files are burnt. You were keeping all the documents in a filing cabinet. In order to keep your business moving, you need all the documents restored as soon as possible. Therefore, you decide to try an online service for restoring your documents. How much will it cost?<n><n>### Response<n>A: $80-160, B : $30-50, C: $50-70, D: $0-30, E: $160-240<n><n>## Demonstration<n>Input: There has been a fire in an office. 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:i like to examine different things,why do books the chapters on the back Choices:  A: examine thing B: go somewhere C: knit D: read book E: see particular program<n><n>### Response:		<n>(C) knit<n><n>### Input :i like to examine different issues but i dont like to read a book. why do chapter come on the  back? Choices:A: examine them B: go somewhere C : make them D : examine them E : read them <n><n>### Response<n><n>(A) examine them<n><n>### Input  :i dislike to examine issues  but i enjoy to knit. why are they on the back ? Choices:  A  : examine them B  : go somewhere C  : make them. D  : examine them  E  : read them <n>(B) go somewhere.<n><n>### Input<n>what do these questions look look like? and is there a way to look a a question? <n><n>### Question<n>Yes there is! You can click on [questions](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLZHQObOWTqDNUo0U7M7Jl8xM9l4ZGI5K) in your homepage to access all the questions from your collection.<n><n>### Answer <n>Yes! You can click on the [questions](https://edu.google.com/quizzes/#/) in your homepage to view all questions that you have encountered before.<n><n>### Reference
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What building has a ot of glue bottles? Choices:  A: art room B: police station C: classroom D: desk drawer E: school<n><n>### Response:		D: school <n><n>Reason 1: the police use sticker so that must not have glue bottles<n><n>Reason 2: the art does have glue so<n><n>### Input 2: What is bigger than a penny and smaller than a dollar? Choices:  a: quarters b: dimes c: nickels d: cents e: dollars<n><n>### Response 2: d: cents<n><n>### Input3: How much money is equivalent to 6 nickels and 2 quarters? <n><n>###Response 3: $1.10<n><n>### Reason 3: <n><n>6 nickels = $0.30<n>2 quarters = $0.50<n>$0.30 + $0.50=$ 1.10<n>

Choices:  A: farm B: business district C: car D: amusement park E: urban area<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Rationales:A farmer would most likely get upset if he saw someone parking in one of his fields. A car going to a business or shopping districts are not likely to find a convenient parking space in the vicinity of a roller coaster. Amusement parks are most likely the appropriate location since they are built up to house a wide range of rides and activities for all ages, which include a parking area. Parking lots provide people parking convenience while other urban zones like business districts often suffer from parking problems during the day.<n><n>### Input :  You have 3 choices. Choose which option can be an example of an equation: A: 7 less 4 B: 7 + 3 + 2 C: 7 + 4 = 15<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Rationale: Equations involve basic operations like addition, subtraction, division and multiplication applied on the same base numbers with the same algebraic variable. An equation does not include mixed operations on numbers such as 3 + (+5 * 4), where adding and multiplication are mixed operations.  We have to choose the choices that show operations applied on the same base number with the same algebraic variable like 7 + 4 or 7 less 4.<n><n>### Output : <n>

Out of the 5 options "B" stands for museum.<n><n>### Response<n>"B" stands for museum<n><n>### Input <n>Gustavo bought a bag of apples, and used one apple to make juice, one apple to make apple cider, and the rest of the apple to make pie. If he had a total of $200 after selling the food and earning 30 cents per apple to eat, what amount of money did Gustavo earn after expenses?<n><n>### Response  <n><n>After the sale of Gustavo's food, he must have earned some kind of cost of the material to make it. If he earned 30 cents for each apple, Gustavo must have spent 1600 cents on materials to make the juice, apple cider, and pie. The sale of food costs, add 1600 - 30, therefore, the amount of money he earned must now be 1570.<n><n>### Input  <n><n>What would be the cost of shipping 26 boxes to two different locations?<n><n>### Your response  <n><n>To find the shipping cost to two different locations one would take the number of boxes and multiply it by the cost, in this<n>case, if shipping costs 18 dollars how much would it cost? 26 boxes x 18 dollars = 456.<n><n>### Your Response <n><n>For what value of n, is n(sin (n-1)) > 1.5?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>n= (sin(n-1))/((1/n(t^2/(t^2+1)+t)) <n><n>### Solution 2<n><n>n= (1/-2/2) /(1+5/2) <n><n>n= (5/2)/((
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A night owl is what you'd head at sunset and you'd hear a what at sunrise? Choices:  A: morning person B: early bird C: lark D: early riser E: rooster<n><n>### Response:		A B C D A night owl is what I head at sunset and I'd hear a rooster at sunrise.<n><n>### Input A: Which shape would show five-sixths of the shaded area?<n><n>### Choices: A: rectangle B: square C: triangle D: oval<n><n>### Response A: rectangle<n><n>### Justification: The answer is a rectangle since a rectangle is one of the two shapes that covers half of the shaded area.<n><n>### ##Input: A: For every time I have had trouble sleeping I have been able to have a restful nights sleep the next time. B: I've had troubles sleeping and have had trouble falling asleep. C: I only have trouble sleeping if I drink caffeine. D: I have been able to fall asleep at the same time every night for the past six months. <n><n>### ##Response A: B<n><n>### Justify: This is because of "I've had troubles sleepin and have had trouble falling sleep"<n><n>### ## Input: A: I do the math in my head B: I use a calculator C: I use a paper and pencil<n><n>### ## Choices: A: B C: C<n><n>### ##Justify: Because paper and pencil is the last choice on the first option. So, I'll choose the closest to paper and pencil which is C<n><n>### # Input: A: I can do it B: I have done it C: I will do it soon D: I have been practicing<n><n>### ##Choice D: I have been practioning<n><n>### ## Justify: I chose "I have been practicing" because it sounds like that he's been practicing for months.<n><n>### #Input: It seems like every time we come back from a summer vacation, there is a new and improved version of our favorite gaming system.<n><n>### Rationales: This is a sentence transformation task which will be solved using FANBOYS principle.<n><n>Input: It seems like the weather today will be as stormy as yesterday.<n><n>It is a sentence combining task, and the sentence has a negative connotation, so using a comma and not a semicolon is acceptable in this case.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where is small knight likely to be found? Choices:  A: fairy tale B: castle C: middle ages D: chess board E: doll house<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input:"Hello, John. I hope this letter finds you well. I would like you to meet someone tomorrow and she is a very kind, nice person. Her name is Amelia. She is a young woman in her mid-twenties. She is very sweet and is looking for someone just like you. We are going to meet tomorrow at the park at 6 PM Eastern Time. Make sure you arrive and stay for the entire time. I know you are so shy, but Amelia is so kind and she will make you feel at ease. Remember, this is very, very important and has a lot at stake. I can't wait to see this turn out well. I'll talk to you later."<n><n>### Rationales: John knows that he is very shy and Amelia is a very nice person. John will feel at ease when he meets Amelia. He is a good boy and Amelia is a sweet girl. John's best friend, Paul, told him to be on his best behavior and arrive at the park at 4 PM because John might meet someone special who could become his new girlfriend. Paul told him to arrive early so that he will be ready. <n><n>### Input:[6 marks for each question, 40 marks for the entire task]<n>1. The word that most closely relates to the context is "at stake" in the following sentence: "We are going to meet tomorow at 6 PM Eastern time. Make sure you arrive on time. I know you're shy, but Amilia is very kind and she'll make you feel at ease." A) At stake means that this is very, very importan and has a lot at risk. B) At risk means that this is so important and has a lot of risks. C) Make sure you arrive and stake has a lot at risk 11. The word that relates to the idea is "to turn out well" in the following sentence:"I can't wait to this to turn out well." A) To turn out means to turn out well. B) To turn out well means very, very importan 13. The phrase "he'll make you feel..." is used in English to __________. A) explain an action B) show a state of being C) show a feeling D) show a feeling for an action or state

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What might two people competing get into? Choices:  A: stress B: debate C: argument D: winning or losing E: tension<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Question: What will they use to tell you which answer they selected?<n><n>### Input Choice Answers:<n>(1) _stress_ (2) _debate_ (3) _argument_ (4) _winning_ or _losing_ (5) _tension_<n><n>### Input Explanation: <n><n>### Response Explanation:<n>The words in (1) give a feeling of strain, anguish or agony.<n>In (2), they give a feeling of a discussion with other people, either formally or informally. <n><n>They refer to 2 people to participate, not 1 person to participate as in (3) and (4). <n><n>They are also talking about people who are arguing, not just two people.<n>And they seem to be talking about people who are on opposite sides of an argument.<n><n>The words in (5) suggest intensity or high levels of anxiety. <n><n>In (4), they are both talking at the same time, but not in opposition.<n><n>Since (2) has both people talking and refers to intensity, that matches the description best.<n>Answer: (2)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write the name of the number that comes after 24 in the space provided.<n><n>### Examples:<n><n>#25<n>#26<n><n>### Additional Input<n><n>#25#<n><n>### Additonal Instructional Text:<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>Answer: #26<n><n>## The Solution<n><n>```python<n># import math<n><n>from numpy import *<n>import numpy as np<n>import time<n><n>def print_inputx(data,x,n):<n>    while data[x] < 1 or data[x] > n:<n>        print x<n>        x += 1<n>    print x<n><n># get input<n>data = open('../input.txt').read().split('\n') # splits<n>x0=0<n>xn=len(data)-1<n>x = int(x0 + data[1])  # read input<n><n>x0=x<n>n = int(xn - x + 1)<n><n>while True:<n>    print_inputx(x, x0, n)<n>    s =

It was missing its lid, so Mr. Chow was able to put it in his suitcase as it lay flat and took up a lot of space. As soon as he returned to the mainland, he went straight to sell it to a local museum. The price he got was $9,000.<n><n>The actual weight of the urn is in kilograms, and is exactly equal to the weight of Mr. Chow's son, 27 kg.<n><n>The urn is worth $16,303 in dollars.<n><n>The price of the urn in dollars was 3 times its weight in grams.<n><n>Mr. Chow paid $5,910 for his trip.<n><n>It cost Mr. Chow $116 to check in his suitcase.<n><n>Mrs. Chow cost much more last month to get her hair done at a salon than her son is worth.<n><n>The distance from New York to the Philippines, where Mr. Chow had to visit before returning to the mainland, was a greater portion of the distance from New York to Beijing than Mr. Chow was from home to the Philippines.<n><n>It took Mr. Chow 4 days to get around the entire world to visit the Philippiines.<n><n>### Rationales<n>Input: A. The reason why a paper notice would be left on the house refrigerator, is that people usually use the refrigerator to leave messages that are intended for family members/others who do not live in the said house/property.<n><n>### Option A<n>Front door. - <n>Because it is the entrance of the home (the front door). As people open this door, they would notice the paper notice. - <n><n>### Option B<n>Conference. - <n>B/c in conference is place where important things are held and if there's anything needed, like for examinations, paper notice are usually posted on the said room/place.<n><n>### B<n>Classroom. - <n>Based on the text

Mom says that we should be sharing and sharing is caring. I do not understand how this statement can apply to the problem we are trying to solve.<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input <n>You and your brother both want to play games or use programs. Instead of playing or using programs together you want to play alone. Mom thinks that you should share, but you don't understand how this helps you.<n><n>### Completion<n>I find it difficult to find other solutions, but I can share time. There are a few options. For instance, I can take turns and start on the task I want. I can try to find an alternative to my brother's program, computer, or game. I also can ask my brother nicely or politely if he can let me play the program, computer, or games for twenty minutes.<n><n>### Explanation<n>This was the best I could think of to solve this problem, but it is not very efficient and I prefer to play my games alone, instead of taking turns with my brother.<n><n>### Input You went fishing in the lake, what was the deepest point of the lake you went to? Which answer could be incorrect: The lake did not have a deep point at all The deepest was four meters The deepest was six meters There were 25 fish in the lake.<n><n>### Complexity: Difficult<n><n>### Completed<n>The lake you went to did not have a deepest point. The deepest part of the lake was four meters. There were 25 in the lake.<n>If the answer choices were,<n>- There were 25 or 26 in the lake<n>- The lake did not have any fish<n>- The deep part of the lake was zero<n>then the answer choices would be incorrect.<n><n>### Justification<n>I cannot answer this question because it is not in my ability to do so.<n><n>### Answer:<n>The lake you went fishing to didn't have a deepest point at all. But the deepest part you were in the lake had 4 metres. There were 24 fish in the lake<n>- There were not 25 or 36 fish in the lake<n>You were
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a light? Choices:  A: ocean B: desk C: universe D: attic E: chair<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following fill in the blank.<n>Put a: __ on the ____ (light).<n>Answer: Chair.<n><n>### Input:"I need a drink. What's in it?" Answer:<n>What can I put in the: __ (blender)?<n><n>### Response:"You might put: ____ (apple) in it"<n><n>### Input "Why do you wear a belt?" Answer:<n><n>### Response"Because: It ____ (holds your pants) or it helps your pants stay up."<n><n>### Input"I put on my socks. There's no shoes on."<n><n>### Response "You might put on the: _______ (shoes) so your feet don't get cold."<n><n>### Instructions: Write a complete sentence that agrees with everything in the brackets.<n>

Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The priest pushed for more orthodox behavior, what kind of behavior was he trying to stop? Choices:  A: liberal B: heretical C: recalcitrant D: conservadox E: heretical<n><n>### Response:		Recalcatious<n><n>### Instructions: Read the following passage and answer the question that follows.<n><n>For over a thousand years, the church's relationship with art has been a complex one. As a building, the church is a repository of the world's greatest works of art. In the form of sculpture or painting, many of the best works of art ever done have been built as, or placed in, churches.<n><n>### A) The art was placed in the churches for beauty.<n>### B) The relationship between the church and art goes back at least a thousand years.<n>### C) Great works of art that are considered to be "high art" are built as, or placed into, churches.<n><n>As a repository of art objects and buildings, the church represents a very large part of the world's cultural heritage. These objects represent religious beliefs and, even more important, a link to the past, connecting people with their ancestors. This was not the original intent of the builders, but the presence of such objects in the church created a tradition for religious people and their art.<n><n>The church also houses the church's property, which can become the subject of worship on its own. This aspect of the church's art is one that art dealers, curators, and museum people call "high art." It is important to understand that the church itself has only recently begun to treat such art as a part of its artistic program.<n><n>The relationship between the church and the arts has not been one of goodwill and trust all the time. Many of the most famous works of art, from Michelangelo's ceiling of the Sistine Chapel to Giotto's paintings in the chapel of Assisi, have been commissioned by the church with special instructions. These instructions may have been to show the nature of the church, to present a new view of Christ, or to simply show the church's wealth. These commissions can lead to serious confrontations between church and client. Even when there is no conflict, many of the greatest religious works of art were created by artists who belonged to another sect or religion altogether. In the case of the work of Michelangelo Buonarroti (1475-1564), he was a devout Catholic who wanted to use his talents to help his faith. He was one of the few painters
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would a Martian find the Indian Ocean? Choices:  A: asia B: southern hemisphere C: planet D: east E: earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>- Choice A- asia- WRONG it would be the asia continent<n>- Choice B- southern hemisphere - WRONG the Indian Ocean is just in Asia<n>- Choice C- planet - CORRECT the Indian Ocean would be in the entire planet including mars.<n> - Choice D- east - CORRECT the planet earth is 360º in the entire planet however the Indian Ocean is located to the East of the continent Asia.<n><n>### Input<n>There are 10 cents in every dollar, and there is 4 in every 100 cents. In a dollar, there were 100 pennies. <n><n>Mary counted and saw $3, 6.975 cents, $2.495, and $5.43 dollars. <n><n>Maria counted and saw $2.16, 2.95, 2.68, $2.87., 4.5 cents, 3.87, 1.99, $4, $.947, $2.59, $.73,$8.06, $.415, $0.18, $1.95, $1.86, $.12, $5.77, $2.99, and $4.38 dollars. <n><n>How much money was Mary able to earn?<n><n>### Rationales<n>- The dollar contains 100 cints per dollar. <n> - Then the 10 cent equals to 1/10 of a dollar = ten cents in a dollar. <n><n>- Then 4 1/100 of a dollar equals to  4 cents in a dollor = 4 cents in a total cost of a dollar.<n><n>- Maria has more money and the value of money than what was Mary's earned.<n><n>### Output: <n> Mary's earned of money <n>$.947, $.73,  $0.18 dollars<n><n>### Detailed:<n>- Mary has $.947, $.38, $0.12 <n>then the dollars are 3,6,12, 43 then the total amount $4.3

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If you are fiddling through a music book when you should be playing, you probably dont have? Choices:  A: practice B: dexterity C: idle time D: knowledge of music E: conductor<n><n>### Response:		The right answer is B as if you are fiddling, you are still playing but at the same time you are not playing at the standard and you would not call it practice.<n><n>### Input : The most expensive piece of music made for a movie is 15 million dollars. What is the smallest budgeted movie? Choices :  Choice 1: $1,100 Choice 2: $2 million Choice 3: $26 millionChoice 4: $100 millionOption is C it is the smallest budgeted.<n><n>### Response : The correct answer is Choice 4 answer is $100 million.<n><n>###Input:If you are fumbling through a music book while should be playing, you dont have:<n><n>###Choices:<n><n>A: practice<n>B: dexterity<n>C: idle time<n>D: knowledge of music<n>E: conductor<n><n>The correct answer is: A<n><n><n>###Answer:<n><n>Explanation:The right answer is A, when you are using your hands to play the piano (and you probably are, since you were fiddling with the music) it is a waste of time since you can use the music as a guide, so you are wasting time when you are fumbling with your hands and not actually using them to play the music (since they obviously are not a good guide to playing the piano).<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>Explanations:The right answer is C if you are fiddly, then you arent playing correctly thus you have dexterity. Idle time is if your not playing the piano then you would have idle time. Knowledge is probably for the most advanced since you dont have the knowledge to go to the next level unless you have it. The conductor is the teacher, which is the person who is telling you what to do during the performance, thus they dont have that knowledge that you have, but they have the ability to help you with your dexterity, so when they are there they will help you with your playing. <n><n>### Answer :<n><n>Explanation : The answer is C . You can determine the dexterity of a person in playing a piano. <n><n>Input : If you are fiddling as you should be playing, then you are wasting your time because a)  you are not practising

Choices:  A: slender B: free flowing C: sparse D: unacquainted E: diet<n><n>### Response:		A: slender<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The word "thick" implies large or full bodily mass; not small, fine, or light.<n><n>The closest match in meaning to "thick" is "slender"
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is made out of only one piece? Choices:  A: jigsaw puzzle B: chess game C: puzzle box D: jigsaw puzzel puxxle E: puxxle<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. Answer: The jigsaw puzzle<n><n>### Input<n>Write a sentence that includes a verb in the past tense.<n><n>### Response<n>Example Sentence: On Friday, I ate a cookie.<n><n>### Input <n>The cost of a bus ticket is $2.40. Rounding to the nearest penny, how much was a ticket?<n><n>### Response <n>Round to the nearest penny to $2.40 is $2.39 <n><n>### Input. You are the teacher who had a class of students who are in second grade. You have a class set of 12 pencils and each of your students has a pencil. How long do you have to give each of the students their own pencils? <n>### Response. Answer: A 06-Mar-2021<n>Give 12 pencil class set to each student. <n><n>### Instructions<n>For each problem, describe a plan or a strategy for completing it. Write the answers.<n><n>### Problem 1: How to save for vacation by the end of the year<n><n>First step to save for vacation is to save for 10 months of the year. Second is to save $200 per month. Third is to save $400 on every vacation.<n>Then, $200/month x 10 months =$2,000/year<n><n>Step 2: 2,000 x 4 =8,000<n><n>### Problem-2: How much of a carpet should you buy to cover a section of the floor?<n><n>First calculate the area of the floor. You calculate the area of the room by multiplying the length of the room by its breadth. <n><n>$52ft x 12ft=$624ft$ sq.ft<n><n>Then take that number and divide it by 4. One square foot is 1ft x 1ft. <n><n>1200 ÷4 = 300 sqft<n><n>### Problem:3. How many apples were left?<n>The total number of apples was 124 and the number left was 72.<n>Therefore, a) there are 52 left<n>b)

Choices:  A: jail time B: fear C: going to prison D: nothing E: feeling of guilt<n><n>### Response:		<n>B: fear<n><n>### Input<n><n>The cost of renting a hotel room is determined by the number of nights it will take to use the space. For the first night, the cost is $150. Each additional night, the cost is cut in half. The cost of renting a beach villa is the same as a hotel room. <n><n>How much does it cost to rent one of the 3 available rooms for 3 nights?<n><n>Answer: A) $575 (hotel room), B) $675 (beach villa), C) $150 + $150 + ½ x $150 = $325 (beach villa)<n><n>### Demostrations<n>In response to an increasing cost: <n><n>A) Decrease spending <n><n>B) Decrease consumption <n><n>C) Cut in half <n><n>D) Double in cost <n><n>### Input <n><n>In this class we learned that the United States' federal minimum wage is $7.25 per hour. Write a response according to the request. <n><n>###### Example 1<n><n>Solution: One way is to convert the decimal to an integer by rounding to the nearest 2 digits: 5/7 = (2 x 2.25) / 5 = (4.5) / 5<n>45/5.<n><n>**What is the value of the fraction 7/8**Solution: Step 1: Convert to decimal<n>7/8 = 1<n><n>Step 2: Convert to percentage<n>1/8 = 1/8 x 100 = 12.50%.<n><n>What is the value of 2 – (3 – 4)?Solution: Step 2: Convert to a common form by performing addition or subtraction<n>1 -.25 = 1 - (.25 +.25) = 1 -.50 = 0.50<n><n>**Answer** 0.50Solution: (1 – (.50 x.25)) / (1 – (.25 x 0.50)<n><n>## Question<n>Ques : Write a response that appropriatley completes the request.

C: I will be quitting my job.<n><n>### Response; A<n><n>### Rationales:I just got a raise at Work is the key sentence if any of the other sentences are used then the question is incorrect.<n><n>### I went on a trip is not acceptable since trip is not about salary <n><n>### Smelling the roses is not acceptable because roses smell good and you have not bought roses <n><n>### It's time for me to move to the next place is not acceptable since this sentence is only used if you move out of work then it will be acceptable <n><n>### There's nothing at work for me, I must resign.
