How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you find people gathered near liquid in a workplace? Choices:  A: water cooler B: opera C: hospital D: hockey game E: beach<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Notes:<n>*The only possible answers are letters of the alphabet.<n>*Would it be possible to tell the difference between any of the choices?<n><n>### Questions:<n>*How many other possible choices did I need to answer this question?<n>*Does the choice list need to be limited?<n>*What would I need to include if I had to include a list of possible answer choices instead of choosing 4 choices from a list?<n><n>Input:When you divide $8 by 1/2.How many times?<n>Rationales:"When you divide $8...how many times?"<n>Input:Diego saved 18 cents for a pen. How many of these pins does he give his mom?<n>Rationales-:Diego saved 8 cents for a pin. How many of these pin does he give his mom<n>Diego-saved-18-cents-for-a-pin.-How-many-of-these-pins-does-he-give-his-mom <n>18 ÷ 0.18 = 100 pins<n><n>### Demistation:<n>Input:Mary’s house is across the street from Sarah’s house. Sarah’s house is across from Betty’s house. Where does Mary live?<n>Rationales:/!\/\/!\/\/!\/\/\/\! What is Sarah's house's neighbor? It is definitely not across the street from Sarah's house. It is across from Betty's house.<n>Mary and Betty are sisters<n>It is Sarah's house, so the answer is across the street from Mary<n>Answer: Mary's house<n><n><n>Answer: It is across from Betty’ house. 1. Mary’s house is across Mary’s house 2. across the street 3. Mary’s house across from Sarah’s house 4. Betty’s house 5 Sarah’s house.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a fox hunting when not in a forest? Choices:  A: open meadow B: arctic tundra C: beach D: great outdoors E: england<n><n>### Response:		Open meadow<n><n>### Justification: A fox typically hunts in any area that is near food sources, however the best place it can be found when not in a forest is open meadow. This is because open meadow can have the perfect set up. There are grass, herbs, etc that are there for the prey, but they don't run away when they see the fox (because the predator is usually a great fox.) In a forest, it's a lot harder to find a place where it doesn't get disrupted when hunts. It has grass areas, however it also has rocky, uneven places that will get out of balance and be hard to chase prey when running through forests.<n><n>### Inputs:For a field trip tomorrow, your teacher would like you to get a sample of a bony fish. You can find samples of a bony fish in:  A.A stream. B.A lake. C.A river. D.A bay. E.A mudflat. <n><n>### Response and Justification:A stream<n><n>### Input for Demonstration on Input:<n>A bony fish is common in lakes, rivers and mudflats. This fish is a little bit special compared to others since they have the biggest brains in relation to its body. Even though people prefer to eat salmon, some people may want a bony fish. This fish is also common in aquariums. They like to eat a variety of seafood and they are easy to maintain. The reason why some people do not like them is their teeth, which have to be removed to make the food taste better. Another issue this kind of fish is facing is its decline in population. Most people have forgotten how this kind of fish tastes good. Also, there is more demand for salmon and other species that is eaten with their own teeth removed than this fish.<n><n>### Response to Input for Demonstrations On Input:<n>A boney fish is also known as flat back. It is a marine ecosystem. Boney fish’s predators depend on where they live. In the ocean, they are mostly eaten by starfish and sharks. In the streams, they are eaten by other fish. In rivers boney fish is most vulnerable because they don’t have any shields for their body.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What cuisine is joked about eating small dogs? Choices:  A: backpack B: dog show C: chinese food D: french E: good hands<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions: What is the cost of $18.23 with 8% tax?<n>### Response: $15.57<n>### Input: Write an expression for the price of a pizza if the menu item price is discounted by 15% with a $1 delivery charge.<n>### Response: p + 1 and 15%<n>   <n>### Input: What is the best bargain: a 4-dollar ticket that you can see 3 movies for, or a 7 dollar ticket that you can only see 1 movie for?<n>### Resonse: 7 dollar ticket<n><n>### Response to above: I would probably go to the more expensive one because I like movies more. But if I am on a budget, then I would go to the one with the best deal.<n><n>### Response for both:<n>The first one would be better for me because it's a 7 dollar and you can only go to one.<n><n>I would rather see and pay for those because they might be a good quality or better quality movie.<n><n>The one that I would not want to see or waste my money on would be the 4 dollar movies because it's only for three movies so you have to see at least 2/3rds of the movies but I think I can only go to one because its only for $4 and you have to pay for that price three times.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The rowdy frat boys shouted they would have fun and do what tonight? Choices:  A: do enjoy B: get laid C: enjoyable D: work less E: enjoy living<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A - D - E<n><n>### RATIONAL: Choices: A:do enjoy;B: get laid;C: enjoyable;D: work less;E: enjoy living; A - enjoy.<n><n>### Rationale: We want to know which word is a verb and not the noun form. That leaves us with B, C, D and E. B is a noun. C is also a noun and work is a verb, but we don't want a noun/verb pair either. Then there's only three options left. D and E are pronouns in the noun form, so they won't work. That leaves us with C: enjoyable. <n><n>### Answer: Enjoyable<n><n>### The student should:<n>- Recognize that this statement is informational.<n>- Provide the requested information in an appropriate response.<n>- Provide all information necessary for the task.<n>- Ensure that the response appropriately provides answers to the question.<n>- Ensure responses are concise and meaningful.<n><n>### Rubric:<n>**Rationale:** This is an answer with no rationale provided.<n><n>**Rationale: This is an answer with a very incomplete rationale.** There should be at least one sentence explaining your reasoning.<n><n>**Rubric:**<n><n>-This answer is rated as "Sophomore".<n>-This answer is below expectations.<n>-This answer may partially meet the requirements of the task.<n>-This answer shows limited, incomplete, or inaccurate information.<n>-This answer requires additional work or a little help to meet expectations.<n><n>### Input : What is antonym of bizarre? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If you have trouble beginning work you're suffering from what? Choices:  A: sitting down B: excitement C: tiredness D: progress E: procrastination<n><n>### Response:		If you have trouble beginning work, you could be suffering from the problem of procrastination.<n><n>### Input<n>Lisa can finish a job faster than Mike but Mike can do more than Lisa. How is this true?<n><n>### Response<n>Lisa can finish the job faster because Mike can do more than her. <n><n>### Input If you want to keep your hair long you need to get a haircut in the beginning, as it grows quickly. <n><n>## Response If you want to keep the length of your hair, get a haircut early because the more you let your hair grow, the longer it will become.<n><n>## Instructions<n>Write 1-2 sentences to explain your choice.<n><n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is a lover likely to want to do with their partner? Choices:  A: build family together B: fall in love C: make love D: complete E: distance themselves<n><n>### Response:		A: build family together<n><n>### Input :In 1956, 44% of US farms were family owned. In 1997, that number had dropped to just 7%. What was the percentage of US farms that were family owned in 1997?<n><n>  Rationales:The percent of farms that are owned by families will be the 1956 - 1997. The - 1996 should go on either the numerator or the denominator.<n>- If the answer isn't 100, do nothing.<n><n>Input:In the 1990s, 38% of all homes were purchased with the equity line of credit method. In the 2000s, 35% of all homes were bought this way. What percentage of homes were purchased with the  equity line of credit in each 10-year period?<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Input the number of homes bought with equity line of credit.<n>   <n>   If the answer isn'treally equal to 100%. Then the answer is zero.  <n><n>Input:When 3% of the 1876 population was on average in prison, how many inmates were there?<n>Solution:It does not matter if the denominator or numerator is the larger portion:<n>If it is 1876 then the denominator = 1876<n><n>If it is the numerator then the denominator = numerator / 100<n><n>If it is 3 then the denominator = (1876 * 3)<n><n>Answer:   <n>3% of 1876 = 0.03 = 3 / 100 = 0.016<n><n>Which comes out to 1876 * (1 * 0.01 / 100) = 187.6<n><n>187 * 3 = 561<n><n>Answer: 561<n>	<n>### Input:The 1999 population of a city was 665,336 and it's 2006 population was 666,966. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What does a person looking for new things in life do? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What would you put furniture on top of? How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:You can read a magazine where while waiting for your transportation on rails to arrive? How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The policemen wanted to clear the scene of the accident, so what did they do to traffic? Choices:  A: hurry along B: direct traffic C: help D: force open door E: corner thief<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions:Fill in the blank with an appropriate choice.<n><n>#### The policemen wanted to clear _____ of _____ so what <n>did they _____ to traffic? Choices A: _____ along B: _____ <n>traffic C: _____ D: _____ E: _____ thief <n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input :What does the following expression equal? <n><n>### Demostration :<n><n>\`\`$1 +\$110+10000 +\ 2000 +\$215 -11 +\$60000 + $60 +5+\$111<n>### Response: Answer: 289625<n><n>#Exercise 1:<n><n>### Input<n><n>$$\begin{array}{l}3\times\left(\begin{bmatrix}<n>1&2&3&4&5\\<n>1&5&3&2&4<n>\end{bmatrix}\right)\times \left\{\begin{bmatrix}<n>2\\<n>3\\<n>3\\<n>4\\<n>1\\<n>4\\<n>2\end{bmatrix}\end{array}$$<n><n>### Demestrate:<n><n>$$\begin{(3\times \left[1, 2, 3, 4, 5\right])\times \left[2,3,3,4,1,4,2\right]}\end{array}$$$$\begin{array}[t]{l}\mbox{Add and rearrange rows of both matrix to simplify:}\\<n>\mbox{3\( \begin{bmatrix}<n>6&25&2&\underline{15}\end{bmatrix} \) +}\\\<n>\left(5 \left\{\begin{matrix}<n>2&5&3\\<n>2&3&4\\<n>4&1&4\end{matrix}\right\} \right)\times\\<n>\mbox{\(\left\{\begin{matrix}\underline{15}\\<n>10\\<n>4\end{matrix} \right\}\) =\}\\<n>\left(\left\{\begin{bmatrix}\underline{15}&\underline{10}&\underline{4}<n>\end{bmatrix} \right\}+\left\{\begin{bmatrix}{0}\\<n>{0}\\<n>0
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you find performers on a platform in public? Choices:  A: arena B: building C: dock D: concert hall E: museum<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions:Choose the verb that best completes the sentence. For each sentence, there will be one correct answer.<n><n>### Verification:<n><link><n>https://www.verbalplanet.com/maths-questions-verification-process</link><n>input:How do you verify answers to math problems?<n><n>Output:(A) Verification process depends on the subject<n><n>### Input:(Choices:  T: True B: Bluff C: Correct)<n><n>Answer:  <n>If the question had the wrong solution, you could have said the correct one.<n><n>The answer must be “C” because all of your answers are wrong.<n><n>### Input(Answer: 28).<n><n>Rationales: <n><n>### Output: 1/222/1,000,000<n><n>### Instuction:Input:How many more days are there to Christmas? Choices: 1 Day B: 55 Days T: 50 days<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Instution:Input:If you are planning to spend $7,500, what is the least amount of money you can save and then take out the $7,503? Choices:  $75 A: $100 B: $7600 D: $852 T: $753<n><n>### Demastation:<n><n>## Output:<n><n>This is not a multiple choice question<n><n>Answers:<n><n>### Inputs:How many people live in New York City? Answer 2005: 8,175,178<n><n>Answer 2015:10,455,796<n><n>Input:How many people live New York City? (Choices: 2010 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016)<n><n>Input A: 2016 <n><n>Output:2016<n><n>### Instuiton: Input:Choose a correct subject.<n><n>Rationales<n><n>Choose a "subject". There are many, many subjects, but we can identify one which is a single-letter string

How much will be cost if it is sold for $0.91 per 100 grams?<n><n>### Solution<n>The answer will be sold for $96.5<n><n>## Input<n>Input: For every piece of art work you sell, you receive $2.50. If you sell 6 art works, how much will you receive?<n>Rationale: Your family sold 6 artworks and received $2.50 for each work. <n><n>Answer: $2.5 (for each artwork) x 6 = $15<n><n>Answer: $15<n><n>### Q3<n>Input: For every hour you babysit, you will receive$30. 16 children are staying at your house and spend one hour at your house. How much money will you receive?<n><n>### Rationale<n>A family babysit for 16 children and got paid $30 for each babysit. <n><n>If they babysit 16 children once, every babysit is equal to 1 hour of babysitting. <n>Babysit for every hour is $30. <n><n>The answer for how much money they receive is $30 x 16, which is 1 hour x 16 kids = $480<n><n>Answer: $480<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where do people find bills with bread? Choices:  A: restaurant B: congress C: envelope D: mail box E: cheese store<n><n>### Response:		 Answer: C (mail box)<n><n>### Input:(The next two examples are based upon a picture of two people. The only context to work with is a drawing of two people. Each group will receive a picture of two people which will be used for the first two questions. Answers will not be shown.)<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the question.<n><n>## Input: In this picture, there are two people. Whose jacket is lighter?<n><n>### Answer: the woman's jacket is lighter<n><n>## Instructions:Answer who's sitting and explain the reasoning.<n><n>### Input Who is sitting?<n><n>### Response Answers: A: The woman since that is a woman's desk.<n><n>### Output Answers: B: The woman since that's the man's chair.<n><n>### Rationale A: The woman is sitting so that is her jacket is lighter and she is wearing it.<n><n>### B: The woman is sitting because the desk belongs to a man.<n><n>## Instruments<n><n>In a previous version, the only instrument that was used was a ruler.<n><n>Now, this lesson uses the ruler and the compass, which is part of the ruler.<n><n>### Annotated solution<n><n>### Ruler: The ruler<n>Let's say that we want to use the ruler to mark something.<n>It's marked in red, it's 10 cm long.<n>So let's say we start using the ruler and we want to mark the 4 cm mark, and we know I can do this with a ruler, 2,4, but let's do it with a compass.<n>But if we want to do it with a compous, let's say we want to mark with the compous.<n><n>Okeay, I'm just going to turn it over and let's start mark using the compous.<n>Let's start on the right side.<n>I'm going to rotate it, and look, I can now mark this, it's already marked, but that's okay.<n>I can, let me just zoom in a little bit more on my screen, just so you can see more clearly where the intersection is.<n>I think I just have to rotate
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where can you eat fruit on a red bridge? Choices:  A: refrigerator B: engineering school C: san francisco D: tree E: market<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer:<n><n>E<n><n>### Input<n>How old were your parents in 2007? How old are they now?<n><n>### Response<n>This problem is asking about the ages of the user parents. We want to know how old they were in 2009 and now. It asks for our parents ages. I am not sure about the age of father.<n>Following this information, there is an image with two people standing under trees. The woman looks younger than the man. She is probably our mom. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What makes people happy when it is surprising and unexpected? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The movie had many a song and dance, it was a what? Choices:  A: bollywood B: record C: musical D: jukebox E: napster<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A, B, C, or E but not all possible answers include 30 credits<n><n>### Rationale: You will be given a sentence with at least two parts, and four possible answer choices. Choose an answer choice that describes the sentence by selecting the image that best matches the situation. <n>The movie had many a. song and dance, it b. had many songs and dances, but was a. musical, not c. jukebox. <n>The film was originally a. a movie but later re-released as a. a musical, not e. a record, so a. it was not f. bollywood or g. a record<n><n>Answer: C<n>

Choices:  A: question B: dispute C: deny D: contradict E: refuse<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>An attempt to confirm an referee would fail if they:<n><n>	A. Question<n>		: The confirmation of an application will fail if they question the validity of the reference that you have supplied.<n>	<n>	B. Dispute<n>		: The reference will dispute your claims if you do not supply your correct personal details when applying for employment.<n>	<n>	C. Deny<n>		: A confirmation of an application made will fail if the reference provided is not available to provide an answer to the employer due to the employment.<n>		<n>	D. Contradict<n>		: The application will fail if the reference that you have provided is contradicting about your qualifications and experiences.<n><n>	E. Refuse<n>		: The applicant will refuse your application if they do not get a satisfactory response from you about your reference. <n>		<n>	Note: You should be able to answer all of these questions. <n>```<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where is a microphone boom likely to be covering a stock market event? Choices:  A: new york B: concert C: tv studio D: gig E: recording studio<n><n>### Response:		The best answer is:A<n><n>Answer: The microphone boom is used to pick up sound, so it would make sense if it were located in a place full of lots of noise such as a stock market event, or concert. In contrast, a microphone boom would not be used in a television studio because only one person, the host, would be speaking; the microphone itself would be adequate for picking up the host's speech. A concert would be another place to put a microphone boom because when 100 or more people are singing together, the boom would have a job to pick up all the sounds, just as it would in the sound booth. Finally, in a recording studio, one person at a time is allowed to speak and is miked, so there is usually no need for a microphone boom. <n><n>Answer: The best answer is:A <n>#recursion<n>### Instruction Use recursion to solve the following.<n><n>### Input For n = 3, there are 2 ways to arrange the numbers in a pyramid scheme. For n = 4, there are 3 ways to arrange the number in a pyramid. For n = 5, there are 4 ways to arrange the three digits in a pyramid, and so on. How many ways are there to arrange n different digits in a pyramidal arrangement? Rationales: The function to arrange n different numbers in a pyramidal shape uses recursion. This can be explained by going back to its mathematical definition. For example, let’s start with n=3. There are two ways to place three numbers, 1, 2, and 3, in a pyramidal scheme. The first method places 1 on top then 3 with 2 in the middle and bottom. It can be explained with the code (1, 2, 3) (3,2, 1) The second method places 2 on top then 3 and 1 with 2 in the center. It can be explained as (2, 1 )(1,2,3)(3, 1, 2) Next, for n=4, there are three ways to arrange the four numbers. One is 1 on top and 2-3-4 below it in a triangle. It can be explained using the code (

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where are seats most likely bleachers? Choices:  A: movies B: opera C: theater D: lecture hall E: hockey game<n><n>### Response:		<n>D (lecture hall)<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>How might the author be feeling? <n><n>Rationales: <n>Author might feel:<n>- happy<n>- sad<n>- angry<n>- afraid<n>- depressed<n>- lonely<n>- stressed<n>- surprised<n>- scared<n><n>Answer: Author might feel:<n><n>- _____<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>How does the author’s tone compare to the tone of the original quote by Aeschylus, “In war, truth is the first casualty”? <n><n>Rationale: <n>A quote's tone is about how it makes the audience feel when they read/ hear it. Truth is supposed to get us thinking instead of telling us what we need to know. <n>For example, if you read something in textbooks, it tells you what you know already. But when you watch a movie or TV show, they tell us through storytelling and characters, not telling us what we need. So, the quote's tone is not comparing.<n><n>Answer: _____<n><n>## Inputs:<n>In what ways are the two authors trying to persuade us by using pathos? Give an example of each. <n><n>Rationale <n><n>To persuade the reader about a certain idea, it is used to gain support from the reader by appealing to their emotion. <n>The emotions that the authors are trying to appeal to us are:<n>- Sadness<n>- Pity<n>- Anger<n>- Pain<n>- Joy/Happiness <n>- Fear<n><n>Example: Ex 1: <n><n>The first author might persuade the reader by using:<n><n>- Pathos: Pity: "We can do all this because of the bravery and sacrifices of brave men and women who, with unwavering resolve, fought to keep our nation free from communist powers and terrors."<n>- Emotion: Sadness/Anger/Pain: "How can the American people be so heartless"?<n><n><n>The second author might persuade the readers by using <n><n>- Pathos.<n>- Emotion: Fear: "We're all human in some way, but they are not human, and in a sense the more I know them the less you can call them human at all."<n><n>Ex 2: <n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where are you if your reading magazines while waiting for a vehicle on rails? Choices:  A: vegetables B: market C: doctor D: train station E: bookstore<n><n>### Response:		A (vegetables)<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Input: Where are you if your reading magazine while waiting for a vehicle?<n><n>Since vegetables are commonly sold at markets, if the person is reading magazines and waiting for a vehicle is in a market or a bookstore and wait for a train respectively.<n><n>Answer: A (vegetables) or B (bookstore)<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If an actor is said to be on the “silver screen" where would you see them perform? Choices:  A: play B: movies C: theater D: screen E: television<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The correct response is A, play. The reason behind this choice is that the actor is performing, not being a part of the production. You don’t see actors in theater or movies on the screen, nor do they perform on the television, as that is reserved for the medium the actor is performing on.<n><n>### Input. : How Many can I Save? Choose A and enter the number of gallons that you can save; or choose B and enter the number of miles that you can drive.<n><n>### Response<n><n>The correct response would be A, the number of gallons you can save. This is because if you are able to save a number of gallons of gas you have essentially saved yourself money.<n><n>### Question:<n>What is a negative number?<n><n>### Instuction:Complete the sentence.<n><n>Gerard’s brother is three years older than Gerard. How much_______older is his brother?<n><n>### Response 1<n><n>The correct response given is “years old.<n><n>The reason to which this is the correct response is because “than Gerard” means greater than Gerard, while “_____ old” means, years old. Gerard’s brother is years older than Gerard does not make sense, therefore; the correct answer is years old.<n><n>### Solution 1<n><n>If you are looking for the number of years, there is no age, so the correct response would be “years.” If you are looking for the age in years, the correct response would be 3 years old.<n><n>Explanation: There's also the answer of 3. That makes more sense. For example: How many years are there in 3 and a half years? The answer is 3 and half years. However if you're looking for the age, the answer is 4 years, not 3 years old. Years, however, makes sense for the first part, asking for the number of years while 4 does not.<n><n>### Analysis<n><n>### Source 1<n><n>### Source2<n><n>![Rubric4](assets/img/Rubric4.png)

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What's the nickname of the monster the beauty loved? Choices:  A: beast B: ugly C: ugliness D: satellite E: top of mountain<n><n>### Response:		<n>> The choice B is correct.<n><n>### Input<n>Sara gave each of the ten volunteers $5, she spent $24.40 for groceries and she used a total of $100 at the pet shop. How much money did she pay for gas?<n><n>### Choice:<n>> A; $3.25. <n><n>### Reason<n>First subtract all the money she spent from the total amount she has.<n><n>$(5*10)+$(24*40/100+100)=$(110-192.5) ≈ $(82.5)<n><n>Answer: (82.5) (divide the amount with 4): 0.21<n><n>Answer = $0.21<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Sally was a senior in the House.  What might she be a member of? Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n><n>### Response:		The term High School or College is used interchangeably in this context. <n><n>### Response Justification: <n><n>#### A. Assisted Living Facility - There are other terms that might be used in this context.  These could be facilities like a nursing home but it doesn't fit.  There are numerous websites listing assisting living facilities in the area, such as [this](http://www.assistedlivingtoday.com/assisted-living/pa/philadelphia/916-woodrow-avenue#.U11xBnV9K9I).  Assisted living facilities are facilities that provide various care services to people who require assistance with their care. They are for disabled people of various ages and abilities but primarily seniors.  In a few states they are required to be called assisted living rather than senior living, as they don't provide care related to aging. <n><n>#### B. Old People's Home - In the United States this is a pejorative term, that is the term itself has no real merit, nor does this appear to be anything that would be used in that context. There are various old peoples homes in the area but they go by other names, such as [this facility](http://www.montgomerycountypa.gov/AgingAndAdultService/assistedliving.aspx) which lists this as an assisted living facility. <n><n>#### C. High School or College - <n><n>#### D. Republican Party - There are numerous party facilities in the area as well as the State and County Democratic Party offices.  There are no other party organizations that are known to exist for any of the other organizations listed, such as the Democratic Party, that are also political parties, or non-partisan organizations like the Republican Party, the Libertarian Party, the Democratic People's Party, etc. <n><n>#### E. Organization - There are many organizations in the area, such [as this](http://www.meetup.com/southeastern-pa-forestry-association/), these are organizations but not affiliated with a political party or a political ideology. Sally is in her senior year as a college attendee at the time, she would most likely be an organization that represented college or high school students. <n><n>## Input:You are
