And if he drives South on the highway then his next destination will be Arizona<n>Answer: Arizona<n>### Instruction : <n><n>### Task: The numbers in the following table are the answers to 10 mathematics questions which were given to 50 students. Write a text that represents the data in the table.<n><n>### Input Table: Students | Maths Questions | Attempted | Correct | Percentage<n>| Student | Attempted | Answer Correct | Percentage | <n>| ——————— | —————– | ————- | ———— | <n>| 1A | 10 | 9 | 90% | <n>| 2A | 20 | 12 | 60% | <n><n>### Demostrations :<n>The students who were given the 10 mathematics questions attempted the following number of math problems. <n>First, add the sum of the Attempted Column to the sum of the Correct Column. <n> <n>```<n>1. Add 10 and 20<n> <n>```<n>  <n>The sum of the Attempt Column is 30. <n>The sum of the Correct Column is 22. <n>Therefore, the total of the attempted correct percentages is 22%/50 x 100 = 44%.<n><n>  ```<n>| 1 |  -  -<n>| 2 |  -  -  -<n>```<n>The students in this table represent students in an entire classroom. <n>The students in this classroom attempted 50 mathematics questions. <n>Their answer to each question was recorded individually for each student<n><n>### Rationale: <n>The table shows the amount of correct answers to different groups of 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What happens when you take a shower after going for a run? Choices:  A: feeling refreshed B: becoming tired C: restlessness D: leg cramps E: sweating<n><n>### Response:		Answer D: leg cramps: Leg cramps is a condition where a muscle or the muscle group gets suddenly contracted which results in pain.<n><n>### Input 1: If the numbers 3, 9 and 29 were written out as a mathematical equation, which would have the greater value?<n>A: 329	 <n>B: 93	<n>C: 92<n><n>### Response 1: Answer B: 92 is greater<n><n>### Input S: Write down the sequence shown below.<n>S: (1,6,21,55…)<n><n>### Response S: 2,9,45,105<n><n>### Input/Output: A. B. C. D. E. F. G. H. I. J. K. L. M. N. O. P. Q<n>A: 5 B: 3 C: 9 D: 7 E: 10 F: 5 G:12 H: 7 I: 5 J: 2 K: 7 L: 2 M:9 N: 2<n>P: <n>O: <n>Q: <n><n>### Response/Instruction 1: The pattern is the following sequence; 5, 3, 6, 9, 5, 10, 7 and 9.<n><n>### Response Question 1: What did Matthew do after he ate his lunch? Answer 1: He drank half of his milk.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:No matter the background of the person, they should all be given what in applying for the job? Choices:  A: critical thinking B: congratulated C: equal opportunity D: compliments E: raffle tickets<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:No matter the background or the person applying for the job, they should all be treated on the same grounds and given what? Choices:  Critical thinking  Congratulation Equal opportunity Constructive criticism  Compliments Raffle tickets<n><n>Output:<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>It is because of everyone’s backgrounds and abilities that should be given equal opportunities.<n>But since in this time and age racial discrimination exists, it is important that all applicants should be treated equally when applying for the job.<n><n>### Input(Cont): What do you need before you can get a driving license?<n><n>Output:<n>   A: 18 y/o B: Car C: Vehicle knowledge D: A legal document of proof E: Both C and D<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>The minimum age required is 18y/o. You need to be physically and mentally fit to apply for a driving license. You also need the physical manifestation in order to be legally allowed to drive.<n><n>A driving license also requires a legal proof that an applicant has the ability to drive. An applicant must not be restricted to only apply for a license due to the legal restrictions that are applicable to them when they apply for one.<n><n>### Question:What other factors need to be given if you want to become a driving license applicant?<n><n>### Ratians:Answers:You can apply for the permit as well to prepare better for your driving course and examination. You need to be skilful and knowledgeable as well to be able to drive well and be able to handle any incidents. The driver course is to make you learn the basic safety measures and precautions to be able to drive. You also need to know how to read and understand signs to know whether stopping and stopping means you are allowed not to. A driving license requires a license to drive and an individual has to first be familiar with the vehicle and be able to handle it. A car must be properly insured.<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you stand in a line and need a coat if it is cold? Choices:  A: graph B: bank at noon C: good book D: post office E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>from math import *<n>x = int(input())<n>n = 0<n>while n <= x:<n>    print("")<n>    i = 1<n>    if x % i == 0:<n>        print("{}".format(i))<n>    n += i<n>```<n>   <n>## Solution Code<n>```python<n>from time import sleep, strftime<n>from math import *, sin, cos, asin<n><n>def main():<n>    s = strftime("%I:%M%p", localtime())<n>    print("Good evening!")<n>    if 5 == random.randint(0, 100):<n>        print("Doodle time")<n>    if cos(random.randint(1, 359)) > 0:<n>        # print("The weather looks good:", asin(sin(random.randint(-20, 2)  / random.randint(100, 119))))<n>        color = "BrightRed"<n>    else:<n>        print("No weather doodle today!")<n>        color = "White"<n>    print("#333333" + color + " ")<n>    print(s + ": ")<n>    print("Wanna draw? Use the <code>mouse</code>!","Use the <code>keyboard</code>!")<n>    print()<n>if 1 == random.randint('0', 100):    # if 10% of the time we want a weather doodle<n>    while True:<n>        i = random.randint(5, 99)<n>        v = i // 5<n>        print("Let's try draw {0} {1} times!".format(i, round(v)))<n>        # print('Draw {0,d} times.'.format(i))<n>        sleep(0.05)<n>        n = int(input())  # number of draws requested<n>        draw_counter = 0<n>        while n > 0 and draw_counter <= n:<n>            p = 3 - int(random.sample(range(1, 4), 3))<n>            try:<n>                x_pos = int(random.uniform(0, 315))<n>                y_pos = random
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:where do you typically find a trash can in the city? Choices:  A: park B: motel C: corner D: bus stop E: store front<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>

So I think the pet store would have to be the answer because "business".  So that is one of the places John doesn't want to go.<n><n>### Detailed response:<n><n>* John could avoid: <n><n>* C: <n><n>* D: John really hates animal abuse because everyone likes to work with animals but not when people treat them so rudely. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where is a good place to sore a wind instrument in you home? Choices:  A: under bed B: symphony C: music room D: band practice E: music store<n><n>### Response:		The answer is [A] or [D].<n>### Reason: This problem asks where we should store a wind instrument in your home and we have 6 options available, namely [A], [B], [C], [D], [E], and [F]. <n><n>Since A and D are on opposite sides of the question and we are only going to choose one of these, we will eliminate [A] and [D]. <n><n>We have narrowed our choices to [B], [C] and [E]. <n><n>We use our knowledge on sores to know that sores are often placed in places that are safe, such as under beds, next to symphonies, and in music rooms where there are music to practice. <n><n>Therefore, we can eliminate [C] and [B], which means we only have 2 options left, [A or E]. <n><n>The instrument in question is a wind instrument, so we remove the "store" option and are left with the choices of [A] and [E].<n><n>Since both choices are in storage, we remove them, and we are left with the answer: [A] or [E].<n><n>Input:If Tom has 14 less than twice of John's age, how old is Tom?<n>RationalesThe problem involves determining how old is Tom if his age is 14 less than two-times of John's age<n>The age of John is given as two-times the age of Tom, and the given number of 14.<n>To find the age of Tom, we use algebra. <n><n>First divide the given 14 by the two-times 14 to get the age of John. <n><n>14 ÷ 2 × 14= 7<n>Taking the remainder from 7, we get the number 7.<n>We know that Tom has the age 14 less than 2-times the age of John. We already found John's age using the remainder given above.<n>So, Tom’s age is the number given divided by 2-times the number obtained. <n><n>12⁄7 gives you the number less than seven in 12. Take the quotient, to get 12⁄7 = 13⁄7 so Tom's age is 13–7 = 6. Therefore, Tom is
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:She curled up under a blanket to get warm, this made her what on the couch as they started movie? Choices:  A: sleep B: feel more comfortable C: sweating D: blush E: cuddle<n><n>### Response:		<n>B.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>As used in the question, the word blanket is used to describe the cushion that kept the person warm.<n><n>Sleep is the word given as the solution for the question. <n><n>### Instructions:Complete each expression with the mathematical symbol indicated after the expressions.<n><n>### Example:<n>Input: $ 3. 123 =<n><n>### Output:<n>$ 3. 100 = $3   $ 3. 012 = $3   $3. 001 = $0 <n><n><n>### Instuction:Complete the expression below by selecting the most appropriate multiple of the given number listed to the right of the expression. <n><n>## <n><n>### Output Instruction: Answer the question by writing the correct multiple to use, but do not use the answer. <n><n>## Input:How many sets of 6 cans does it take to purchase over $11?<n><n>### Output<n><n>Output: For every 6 cans you recycle you receive $0.40, and for every six kilograms of newspuers you receive $0.60. If your family recycled 122 cans and 13 kilograms of paper, how much money did your family receive?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Rationals: First we need to know how many cans and how many kilograms of newspaper there were, to determine how much money your family earned. <n><n>There were 122 can for the family to recycle. <n><n>Next, the statement says that the family recycled 6 cans. <n>This means that there are 6 can for each set.<n>Finally, there are 13 kilogram of newspaper for the family to recycle.<n><n>As we now know, there is 10 sets of 6 can for a total of 60 cans and 10 sets of the newspaper for a total of 130 kilogram.<n><n>Next, we need to calculate how much money the familly is making from recycling these. <n><n>Each 6 can is worth $0,40. <n><n>Next each 10 kilogram of newspaper is worth $0,60. <n>

This question is a good example about describing a task in more detail to understand it more deeply.<n><n>### Inputs: I have six friends, and three of them will be in my car on a trip to the movies. On our trip, my friends and I can be in the car no more than two hours. How many combinations of four people are there who could be in the car with me?Choices:  A: 0 B:1 C: 2 D: 4<n><n>### Response for Options: B<n><n>### Rationales for the Question:<n><n>### The instruction requires a response that appropriately complete the request. This is the task description that helps to clarify the question (e.g., What kind of situation(s) require a response?) and the request (e.g., to do/complete something). For a response, the user can choose from the options given.<n><n>A question like this may be asking about a problem. The first step in describing a problem is to clearly understand the task (what the problem is asking you to do). The next step is to describe the question (What details explain the problem? What is the situation?). Finally, you answer by choosing an option.<n><n>In the task above, the user's response should match one of the given answers. This is called choosing the correct option. An "expert" (i.e., a successful response) chooses the best answer out of the given choices:<n><n>![](https://static8.businessinsider.com/image/58086e15de08950644e43266/baby-shark.jpg)<n><n>Answer: Option B<n><n>### Choice B: We first need to find the number of ways to choose 3, and then multiply that by the number of combination of 4 people who can go to the movies with us.<n><n>First, let's find the number of ways of having 3. Given _N_ equals Number of Choices, the number of ways of choosing 3 is _N_ / 3. Next, we know that 3 choose 3 is the same as 3-choose-3 (since you're choosing the people you can ride with, it doesn't matter how you get there).<n><n>From here,

That meant that the only time to leave was when? Choices:  A: early morning B: day time C: night D: afternoon E: daytime<n><n>### Response:		A <n><n>### Instructions:Complete the table below where M indicates multiplication and E indicates division. <n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer:<n><n>$$<n>E\left( \frac{ 9 }{ 9 }{ \left( \frac{ -7 }{ -3 } \right) }{ \left( \dfrac{ -3 }{ 4 } \right) }{ } \right) =  E\left( \frac{{ 1 }}{\frac{{ -1+9+3 }}{{ 3 }}-{{ -\frac{8+7+7 }}{{ 3 }} }}\right) = E\left(\frac{4}{-\frac{6}{3}}\right) = E\frac{4}{-2} = E\left(\dfrac{-2}{2}\right)=E(-1) = 12<n>$$<n><n>Answer: $$<n>E\left( 6 \right) = E\dfrac{ 6 }{ 1 }{ \left( 2 \right) }{ } = E\left( \dfrac{ 5 }{ 6 } \right) = E(0.8)(1) = \dfrac{ 1 }{ 6 } = \dfrac{ 5  }{  6  } = \frac1{5/3}<n>$$<n><n>Answer<n><n>$$<n>E(9+3) =E\left(\frac{ 11 }{ 9 }{  \left( \dfrac{-7 }{ -3 }  \right) }{ }  \right)=E\left( \dfrac{{ 1 }}{\left( \dfrac{-10+7}{9} \right) } \right) =E\left( \overbrace{\dfrac{ 1 } {\dfrac{ 7+1 }{ -9 }} }  \right) =E(\dfrac{ 1 }{ \dfrac{ 8 }{ -9 } }) = E(\dfrac{ 8 }{ 4 } ) = 2<n>$$<n><n><n>$$<n>E{\left(\frac{ 5 }{ 4 }{ \left( \sqrt{9+5}\right)}\right)}=E\frac{ 5 }{ \sqrt{9+9}\left( \sqrt{5+2}\right) }{ } =E\left(\dfrac{ 5 }{ \dfrac{ 5+2 }{ 9+10 } } \right) =0

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What would a person expect if they are competent in their school work? Choices:  A: compliments B: passing grade C: intellectual challenge D: sticker E: avoid pain<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n><n>### Input What are the different choices for the people when recycling in their school? Choices: A: Paper, bottles, and cans B: Paper, bottle, and aluminum C: Plastic, paper, and aluminum D: Cardboard, paper, and bottles E: Paper, glass, and aluminum<n><n>### Response<n><n>C<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>### Input Describe the relationship between the variables: X = (26, -5) Y= (11, 2) Choices: A: X > Y<n>B: X < Y<n>C: X ≥ Y<n>D: X = Y<n><n>### Response Choice: <n><n><n>### Rationals:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that appropriately addresses the request.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:There weren't enough chairs for everyone.  What might have to be delayed? Choices:  A: bookstore B: building C: meeting D: office E: coffeehouse<n><n>### Response:		<n>Because there weren't enough, the coffeehouse can be delayed. What might have to be deferred is not mentioned.<n><n><n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Choices:  A: article B: adjective C: interjection D: conjunction E: pronoun<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale:To combine words, we use a 'conjunction'. 'The and' is an example of such word.<n>Input: How much is twice seven plus twice six?<n><n>### Response:"<n>Answer: 15<n>input: what percent of 17 is six?<n><n>## Rationale: <n>To find what percent of a number, it is divided by the number and multiplied by 100. <n>For example, to find 12 out of 100%, you would divide 12/100 = 12/1<n>then multiply by 100 which you get 12 as the answer. <n><n>The same goes for 12 out of six hundred, it would be 12/600, that is 12/6 and then you multiply it by 100, this way you get 0.2.<n><n>So in the question, we take the number that we want to find out the percent of and it is 17. <n>Take 6 (the 12 in the 12/1) / 17 so you get 0.35. This is our final answer for 6 out of 17.

Choices: A; residential neighborhood B: suburbs C: market D: suburbs E: community<n><n>A gas station should be located in a residential neighborhood as it's a building used to dispense fuel for transport. For a gas station to be constructed in a residential neighborhood, the area should have a huge space. It means that a residential neighborhood is a place filled with houses and big space around them. It gives more sense for a gas station to be found in a residential neighborhood. Therefore, it is a place where ill people can be taken care of since hospitals are very big and have space.<n><n>Therefore, a gas station should be located where people live. Choices: A: it would be too difficult to carry around that many cans and newspapers B: she would have to get special containers to hold that much trash C: she has other things to do besides recycle D: she doesn’t need money E: recycled trash doesn’t weigh as much<n><n>Rationale: <n>In this question, the text says, “Betty will reuse 12 cans for each trip but 5 kilograms for newspapers,” so she doesn’t use 12 cans and 5 kilograms because for every trip. When she only reuses 5 kilograms that means she doesn’t need all the trash that will weigh her and make her to carry a special bag to carry her trash.<n><n>Answer: E <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where can you find a place to eat and places to buy items of many different kinds? Choices:  A: city B: downtown C: own house D: bar E: shopping center<n><n>### Response:		D downtown<n><n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you see a performer at a gathering of you friends? What would you do? Choices:  A: get money B: pay money C: go shopping D: lose money E: save money<n><n>### Response:		The products are tricking women to buy them.<n><n>### Input (2) Choices:  A + B<n><n>### Response (2) A or B<n><n>### Input Choices:  A<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Demos(2) A<n><n>### Answer<n><div>If your mother tells you “Johnny went to the store and got a new toy for his birthday”, you could ask “What toy did he get?”<n><n>If she replies “He got a ball for his dog and a football for himself”, then the sentence you could reply with would be “Did he get something for you?” <n><p><n><p>If you ask a friend “How did the party go?”, they might answer: “It was great for my little sister. She even got a nice big dress.” In that case, you could reply with “Does she fit in it?”<n><n>Finally, if a cousin of yours asks you “How is your school year going?”, you can reply with “Is it going well for yourself?” or “So, what do you think about your courses so far?”</p><n><n></div><n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. B: to earn money. C: to buy a home. D: to get more goods. E: to buy food.<n><n>### Response:"B"<n><n>### Why:"B"<n><n>Because money is a tool that we buy things with<n><n>### What do you think that is better between A and B<n><n>### Why<n><n>A is better<n><n>### Why is better "A"?<n><n><n><n>### Choices:<n><n>A: Money has no value. B: Money has value.<n><n>### Choice<n>Because money can buy many goods and is easy to get money in many places<n><n>### Choose a response:Choices: A: Work and sell  B: Buy and Sale <n>C: Make and Sale  D: Buy and Sell  E: Gets Money from work <n><n>### Response 1<n>A: B: C: D: E:<n>![Answer](./images/24793516_2690287817915068_8619287296682179176_n.jpg)<n><n>### Why are you better than the other?<n><n>The first step we can start to make money is working to sell products or sell a house, we can also start making money by buying and selling.<n><n>### Which job do you think is harder?<n><n>I don`t know<n><n>### Why?<n><n>Because work and buy-sell are hard<n><n>### What money is better than others?<n><n>### Why "A" or "B"?<n><n>### A: A man named Bask was working and made 50 pesos.<n>```<n>Bask bought a sandal. Bask gave 20 pesos to the person who made the sandal.<n>After that, the person who made the 20 pesos sold it to another person.<n>The person who sold the selling 15 pesos.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is the result of instituting civil action? Choices:  A: bad feelings B: confusion C: going to court D: hurt feelings E: sandwiches<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>D = hurt feelings (because it is a painful experience and it is usually not fun)<n><n>### Input:"Who" and "it" are used to refer to a specific person, place or object. "Which" and "That" are used to refer the speaker or reader to a specific part of a list. Choose the correct word. Choices: A: Whose B: Which C: That D: Whichever<n><n>### Response:"Whose" is for a specific person, place, etc., and "That" is something in which or which of a list.<n><n>### Input "To understand mathematics requires studying and doing mathematics. It requires an enormous amount of memory and effort. Choose the correct statement. (a) To solve a math problem, knowing the steps to follow is very helpful. (b) It is not necessary to know all the steps to solve a problem. (c) One cannot know all the steps to follow, it is helpful to be able to solve some problems without knowing the steps. (d) It is important to know and understand each of the steps involved in solving a problem." Choose the correct statement: (a) (b) (c) (d)<n><n>### Response("b"): It is not necessary to understand all of the steps.<n><n>### Question:How can you find the surface area of a composite shape? Choices: A: Subtract each face's perimeter. B: Add the perimeter of each face. C: Total the area of each face. D: Find the perimeter of the whole figure.<n><n>### Response (B): (C) (C)<n><n>### Question:"Making a kite is a lot like learning how to make paper fold toys. If you're having trouble understanding how to make your kite or toy, you might want to read a book on paper folding to see what the directions are." Choose the sentence that best connects to the theme of an argument." Choices: A: Learning how to make a kite is no different than learning how to make paperfold toys. B: You might as well read that book on paper folding because it will help you fold your kite. C: You should always read the directions before making a kite. D: Not all of the book's directions will help you fold toys.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The man didn't like getting out of bed and stepping on the cold tile, so where did he put carpeting? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:People celebrate by going places and riding rides. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Stopping being married to one another was a costly task, the lawyers and their what were astronomical? Choices:  A: scars B: being born C: sorrow D: misery E: kill yourself<n><n>### Response:		You should be honest with yourself. Life is not easy. It is full of problems and misfortunes. The best thing you can do in times like this is get help. Be honest with yourself, take the next step, and never let anybody tell you how your life should have been. It will always look harder in retrospect.<n><n>### Input 1 :<n> <n>What will happen if I take the next step?<n><n>### Response 1 :<n>The next step in your life will not be easy, but there are many people who are willing to help you. These people will give you the support you need to find the right person who can help you with problems. Taking the next step can make you feel overwhelmed at times because it requires time and effort, but know that there are people around who care about what happens in your life as much as you do, and they will give up anything for you to succeed.<n><n>###<n>Input: If I take the next step, I am very scared I will fall.<n>Response: The next step is going to be difficult, but you have to take the next step. The best thing you are doing for your future is that you can take the second leap of faith. After that, do not look back and continue pushing yourself.<n><n><n>### Question<n><n>Which choice best describes what you would say if you met someone who had committed suicide recently and told you about the experience?<n>Choices: A: I care about you B: I wish I could have helped you C: I wish I could do things differently D: Yes it was worth it<n><n>### I believe that the correct answer is "I care about you"<n><n>### The response should be, "If there is ever a time where you need help, I am just a phone call away. I would love to help you get the help you need from a professional."<n><n>### Question 4<n><n> <n>Which choice is the best way to respond to someone who tells you he or she has decided to commit suicide?<n>Choices: C: I know it must be hard A: Yes I'm listening B: I'll give the number of a counselor I know D: It's never too late to change your mind<n><n>### Input question: <n>What will happen in the future if I try to commit suicide but I don't
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A school is most likely to be located in what sort of zone? Choices:  A: residential neighborhood B: community C: building D: prague E: every city<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### rationale:<n><n>### Input<n>There are many variables to determine that best fit an area as a school zone. One that is taken into consideration is the average cost of housing in the area. Usually the area is mostly residential.<n><n>### Response<n>A school is most likely placed in a residential area because people like to live in a quiet area and preferably in a place where their child would be in a safe area.<n><n>### r<n><n>## Answer the following question, then explain your response.<n><n>### Given:Jim, John, and Sam were each given 8 pancakes and 5 cans of juice. If Jim ate 7 pancakes and used up 6 cans of juice, John ate 5 pancakes and used all of the juice, and Sam ate four pancakes and used 2½ cans of juice for a total of 5 cans, how many more pancakes did John eat than Sam?<n><n>### Rationale:The problem requires finding out how many more panckes did John eat than Sam. <n><n>First, find out how many pancakes and juice did each person get at the beginning. <n><n>8 pancake + 5 juice = 13 pancakes and juices <n><n>Then, find out how many each person were left with after they used up their initial supply of pancake and juice. <n><n>Jim had 1 (7 pancake) - 6 can juice<n><n>John had 2 (5 pancake) - all juice<n><n>Sam had 3 half (4 can juice) - 2 can juice<n><n>Therefore, John finished with 5 canjuice - he used up all his pancake and juice <n>Sam finished with 4 canjuice - 2.5 can of juice <n><n>Then, take how many pancakes Sam finished with and subtract this from how many Jim finished with and you get the answer <n><n>5 can juice - 1 = 4 pancake/can juice.<n><n>## Rationales<n><n>### Answer: 4 can juice<n>For each person, find the initial supply, find the remaining supply and subtract the initial supply from the remaining supply, to get the number of p

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What happens to people when they do not have enough food? Choices:  A: eat fish B: they steal C: talk to each other D: write stories E: die of starvation<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Rationales:** <n><n>If they do not have food, they will die of starvation. <n>If they do not steal or do not talk to each other, then they will not have enough food.<n>When they get there, they can steal, go get some food, or talk to each other.<n>They can talk to each other because they cannot do anything else except they can steal or go get food.<n>When they steal or ask someone for food it does not work out, because they are hungry or it will cost a lot of money.<n>So, when they are dying of starvation, they die.<n>This is how the world would be very bad.<n>Then, the world will be even worse.<n>**Answer:** A: eat fish<n><n>

D: gym E: theatre<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rationales:<n>It does not say in the statement if bob is a kid or that he is an adult. How many adults have to attend the game in order to fill the middle tier at a cost of $20 per seat, and how much money will be contributed to the booster club?<n><n>### Rationale :<n>The college basketball game's cost is $25 to lower half-court seats. <n><n>As I see it, there's a number of people (n) at this event, <n><n>$25(n - 6)$ per individual with no more than 6 people at a time. <n><n>The cost of the game is $20 for the middle tier and $15 for the upper tier. <n><n>$20 (n - 6) + $10 (n - 4) = $200 <n><n>Each individual has to contribute $5 money as a requirement for this event and there are a group of four people in total. <n><n>$5(n - 4) + 5(n - 8) = $20 <n><n>Therefore, when the group of people are 20, the middle tier is sold out, and the booster club receives $220. <n><n>Answer: 20<n><n>### Instructions: <n><n>## Input: The number on which the total cost of the entire set or group is divided is referred to as what?. Choices:  A: fairgrounds B: friend's house C: space shuttle D: oven E: microwave<n><n>### Response:		E: microwave<n>### Response:D: oven<n><n>### Response : C: space shuttel <n><n>### Demntion:<n>The problem involves a task that allows the user to calculate, convert a decimal into a fraction, and determine the answer to a question correctly on the provided answer key.<n>### Instruction :<n><n>### Input : <n>* Food is safe to eat if it is freeze-dried before you eat it.<n>* You can't take food that is not freeze-dried on what vehicle? -Choose the correct answer?  - - - - - - 1. An oven A. a bus B. A space shuttle C. A helicopter D. A microwave<n><n>- - - - - -<n>* A B C D E <n>* answer : D<n><n><n>### Rationale:<n>* Food must be freeze-dried so that it can be eaten when it is taken on a space shuttle.<n>* An oven is used to heat or cook food. <n>* A bus is a closed four-wheeled vehicle that people can sit in.<n>* A bus is not used for transportation while in space.<n>* A bus must be heated to be able to travel.<n><n>* Answers: <n><n>B: You can't take [food that is not freeze dried] on what vehicle? Choose the correct answer? -Choose the...<n><n>### Input Choices:<n>- Choices: A: fairgrounds<n>B: friend's house<n>C: space shuttle<n>D: oven<n>E: microwave <n><n>**Solution:**<n><n>### Input Instruction:<n>### Input 1:<n>Because food must be freeze-fired, not the other answer provided<n> <n><n>### Input Demonstration 1:<n>* B bus <n>* B friend's house <n>* B friend of friend's house  -   -  -  - - -  -   -   -   -  -   -  D -<n><n>### Input Rationale 1:<n>* Food must freeze fire<n>* Food must be eatable before it can be eaten<n>* A B C bus bus. <n><n>##
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What does someone chatting with friends do when they hear a joke? Choices:  A: giggle B: lie C: laughing D: chuckle E: smoke<n><n>### Response:		Laughing<n><img style="color:red" src="sources/test.jpg" height="100px" width="100px"><n><n>### Instructions: What is the first letter of the 5th digit of the number 1374368?<n>```<n>The first letter of the 4th digit is the second letter of the 3rd digit is the 3rd letter of the second digit. <n>If the second digit of a number is greater than 5, the letter that we get is b.<n>If the second digit is 5 or lesser, we get an a.<n>The letter in the sequence for the number 754319816 is bbbba (the order of the number).<n>Here, the 5th digit is the 4th digit.<n>The letter that we get is the 4th letter of the word.<n>The 4th letter of all words begins with b.<n>Therefore, the letter of the 5 digit of 13740368 is b.<n>```<n><n>## Submissions<n><n>Submit a response as a `.md` file in this directory.<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The artist knew that this was the peak of his fandom, so he decided it was time for cashing in by doing what? What percentage of the total US electrical homes was there in 1940?<n><n>### Response : The correct answer is B, according to the information provided in the question's input. <n><n>In this type of problem, you want to determine the actual total number of homes in a given year and subtract that number from the total number of electrical homes across the whole span of the problem.<n><n>In this problem, we learn that "68% of its [1940's] homes" were electrical. <n><n>"% of total electrical" means 68% of the total electrical (in 1940) compared with 10 years later (1950). <n>In 1940 there were only 68% of 100% which means 68% were electrical and 32% were not electrical. <n>Therefore in 1959, 32% of 10% were not electrical so 32 *.01 =.032.<n><n>Rationales<n><n>Input: One night, Alice, Carol, David, and Eric were arguing about the length of time it takes for the sky to turn blue. There are 60 people who attend, so there are 60 people per seat. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where can you buy a hairbrush along with bandages? Choices:  A: drugstore B: hospital C: bedroom D: car E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>## Input 45 + 16 = 61<n><n>## Rationale: Input:Where can you find a shining gold ring and an eye dropper? Choices: <n><n>##: a. house <n><n>## b. drugstore <n><n>## c. grocery store <n><n>##: d. hospital <n><n>## e. car <n><n>## Rationale <n><n>##: Rings are most frequently sold in jewelry stores, so Answer: A: house <n><n>##: If someone goes to the grocery store to purchase a box of cereal they will most likely also buy milk to go with the cereal.<n><n>Answer: B: drugstore<n><n>### Input 23 x 2 = 46<n><n>### Rationale  For a given pair of numbers, we find the product (23 x 2) and then we add the results of division.<n>The product is 46.<n>The division is 23 ÷ 2, which is 11. Adding these gives 61 as a result.<n><n>### Input24 – – 35 = --<n><n>### Rationales: For 24 24 – 35, the first thing we need to do is subtract 24 – 24 from 24 and we get 0.<n><n>Then, we subtract 35 from 24 and get 9.<n><n>Finally, we add the divisor (35) to the remainder (9), which gives 11.<n><n>## Input A - B = -18<n>## Rationales:To subtract two numbers we subtract the ones that are first and the one that is second.<n><n>###Input: The length of the road from one gas station to the other is 88 miles long. It is also 27.5 degrees south. How far is it from the equator?<n><n>###Rationale:The length of the road is 88 miles and it is 27.50 degrees south. <n><n>In order to find difference between this and zero we must subtract the values that are first. <n><n>Therefore, 88 - 0 - 16 = 72<n><n>###Input A - B = C<n><n>###Rational
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would a restaurant put a candle? Choices:  A: dimly lit room B: kitchen C: wall D: table E: birthday cake<n><n>### Response:		Answer B.
