Choices:  A: laugh B: sit C: happiness D: being entertained E: walk slowly<n><n>### Response:		The most appropriate response is the letter C. This will ensure that the child will happily enjoy their time at play. It is also important to teach children how to behave as they are having fun. If the child is walking slowly, it could be because they are unsure of their environment. If the child is sitting while going to play, it does not guarantee they will have a pleasant experience. Being entertained and laughing could be the case in a stressful situation, not a happy and easy one. Therefore, they are unlikely to do this while going to play.<n><n>**Question : ** <n><n>### Demographics: A student's income from working during the summer is $346. They saved the money and spent $54 of it on a pizza delivery. They kept $33 of the remaining money for their birthday. How much money did the student have left after they worked all summer?<n><n>### Demand: A student's total income from working during the summmer is $346 and they kept $33 of it for their birthday. The student's income was $346 - $54 spent on pizza delivery = $392 then they kept $33 so their remaining money is $359<n>### Calculate: $359 - the $392 they spent at the beginning = -$32. <n><n>The student kept $33 and didn't keep $54 spent on delivery, therefore they had a smaller amount of money to keep for their birthday.<n><n>### Conclusion: The student spent $54 on pizza delivery, and after accounting for that and keeping $33 for their birthday, the student had a remaining amount of $359 - $54 = $305.<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:where do you store wine? What is the probability that the number of the year is odd?<n><n>### Demostrait: <n><n>* 1) What number sequence is given?<n><n>* 2) How many ordered pairs in the listed number sequence?<n><n>* 3) How many different ordered pairs in the listed pattern?<n><n>* 4) How many ordered pairs are odd?<n><n>## Procedures<n>Here I created a script to make the student's understand the process that how to code a block of python language. and how to run a script.<n><n>## Instructions<n><n>### Python Programming in the 21st Century<n><n>### Instructions for Programming Logic<n><n>### Instructor Note (The following text will be used to describe program logic.)<n>Python is a high-level programming language, meaning it’s less machine-dependent than most other programming languages. For example, Python can be run on a simple CPU system as well as a powerful multi-CPU system. The only requirement to run Python is an operational computer program. Here are the necessary steps to help you complete a block of Python code. <n>1) Type a block of Python code into your editor. Type each line of your code in the same order that it is presented in your book. Keep in mind that when you are finished writing your code, your block of code should have exactly the same coding as what is presented in the Example programs in the chapters.  2) Once you type in your code, save your file as ProgrammingLogicPython.py (Example #1 in the chapter).  3) Run the program by launching the Python interpreter and using the import statement from Chapter 2

Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A person with children might have a lot of plastic things in what place? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Choices:  A: efficiency B: getting work done C: marriage D: finishing up E: results<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Demostartion:<n>Efficiency - The goal of the ceremony is to get done quickly. We are using E, getting work done, to compare the two options.<n><n>### Alternative:<n>The bride and groom have two options when taking care of prop's, option A, efficiency, and B, getting work done.<n><n>First, we start with the cost of both options, option A and B.<n><n>Option A - 1 efficiency bottle + 2 efficiency coins = 3 efficiency coins<n>Option B - 1 getting work done bottle  + 1 getting work done coin = 2 getting work done coins<n><n>Next, we will add the efficiency and compare it to the getting work done option.<n><n>A + 3 efficiency coins = 4 efficiency coins<n>B + 2 getting work done = 4 getting work done<n><n>Lastly, we subtract the efficiency from the getting work done and compare it.<n>A - 1 efficiency coin = 4 efficiency coints<n>B - 2 getting work done coin = none<n><n>Answer: 4<n><n><n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would someone be likely to store a double edge razor? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Eating breakfast with a large family leads to a pile of what in the sink? Choices:  A: fullness B: underwear C: bad breath D: better day E: dirty dishes<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is B.<n><n>A [bad breath](https://www.wikihow.com/Choose-a-good-toothpaste), [underwear](https://www.verywellfamily.com/how-to-deal-with-an-infestation-of-cockroaches-8767), [fullness](https://www.healthline.com/health/eating-disorders/anorexia), [dirty dishes](https://www.fitsmallbusiness.com/6-ways-busy-restaurant-owners-manage-their-dirty-dishes/), and a better [day](https://www.teenshealth.org/teen/healthy_living/emotions/talking_about_anxiety.html) are all examples of an increased feeling of a great morning, also known as a "better day".<n><n>B<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Rationales:<n>You can read through the answers to see what each individual character of the word means.<n>The letter means "what".<n>Eating breakfast with a family is what causes your sink to be dirty.<n><n>A means "fullness", but since fullness isn't a word, it's missing the "ness" (as is all of the other answers)<n><n>B means "bad breath"<n><n>C means "underwear"<n><n>D means "a better day"<n><n>E means "dirty dishes"<n><n>### Input<n>My grandchildren say, "Please give us something to do we are bored." What should I do?<n><n>### Response<n>My grandchildren say this line, that is what they should be waiting for me to do.<n><n>### Rationale<n>The key point is that your grandchildren say you should do something which is asking for directions. You do what they say.<n><n>### Input 2<n>My grandchildren say: "I am 9 years old I want to go outside and play." What should I do<n><n>### Response 2<n>My grandchild requests you take them outside to play which is what they want.<n><n>### The Rationale<n>The key phrase is "grandchild requests". This gives an indication that your grandchild is being directed to
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:There aren't many anemone in what glove-shaped state? Choices:  A: michigan B: lake C: tide pool D: nursery E: atlantic ocean<n><n>### Response:		Correct.<n><n>### Rationale:For every $0.25 worth of milk, you get one cookie. If you have $3.00 worth of milk, in how many cookies do you get? <n><n>For every $1.02 worth of rice, you get one bag of tomatoes. If you have $15.22 worth of rice, in how many bags of tomatoes do you get?  Your answer:<n><n>$1.02/$0.25 = 4   Your answer:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>### Input:Directions: Use the information below to calculate your weekly grocery bill. <n>### Demos:Calculate your weekly grocary bill by determing what proportion of pancakes are in each batch is milk and what proportion of milk in each batch is eggs<n>Milk:10 boxes of milk : 10 dozen eggs<n>Eggs:3 boxes of eggs : 10 dozen milk<n>Rationales: <n><n>First, we see that in every batch of milk, there are 10 boxes of milk. <n><n>Second, we see that in every box of milk, there are  <n><n>10 dozen eggs. <n><n>Third, we see that there are total 3 boxes of eggs. <n><n>Fourth, we see that in the 3 boxes of eggs, <n><n>there are 10 dozen milk. <n><n>Finally, we put <n><n>boxes of milk:10 <n><n>boxes/boxes of eggs:3 <n><n>boxes( of milk) * boxes/boxes of eggs = eggs<n><n>eggs = 10 eggs<n><n>Therefore, there is a total of 10 eggs in every batch of milk<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>First, we see that in  every batch of milk, <n><n>there is 10 dozen eggs.<n><n>Second, we know that in every  batch of milk,  there are 10 dozen eggs, so in total there are  <n><n>30 dozen eggs in  every box of milk.<n><n>Third, for every box of eggs, we see that there are <n><n> 10 dozen eggs and <n><n> there are in every box of eggs <n><n>so,  <n><n>(1

Write a response that begins with "My solution is"<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Your friend asks you for a favor of you. Your friend says "When I was sick last week, all I could drink was water. I wish some of my friends had brought me water for the week. I think if they had they would have avoided the possibility of the illness".<n><n>Rationales:The problem involves finding a cause and effect. <n><n>The activity involves drinking water to recover from sickness. In turn, drinking too much water when sick can cause hyponatremia, a type of water toxicity. <n><n>A likely cause is drinking too much water and not stopping when thirsty. A possible effect is water intoxication. <n>***<n>### Instrucciones:Below is an activity that you may hear or do. Write a response that properly begins with, "One way to... is to...."<n><n>### Inspiration:<n>While you sleep each morning, your muscles and your organs become tight. Your feet and hands develop calluses, your back arches, and your spine becomes a question mark shape. If you want to make your muscles more elastic you should stretch<n><n>Your best friend asks you to take a walk together that day. You respond,<n><n>Rationales<n><n>The activity involves stretching muscles to get them more elastic. <n><n>There are several ways to stretch your muscles that do not require a partner.<n><n>Stretching is good for both adults and children to keep their bodies healthy because they get enough oxygen to their bodies and brain.<n><n>One way to keep your muscles elastic is to stretch them every day instead of just one-day before a competition.<n><n>During a walk, stretch your entire body in a variety of ways to get all your muscles moving.<n>***<n><n>## Instructions:Belows is an acitivity that you might hear or do. Write response that is correctly begins with "My mom makes...."<n><n>## Inspiration:<n>My homework is to find two examples and explain why they fit under two different categories<n><n>Example 1<n><n>My mom makes a big bowl of pasta
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The fact the two sides were able to even reach tentative agreement was a feat to what? Choices:  A: accomplish B: make progress C: stop arguing D: do business E: concert<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A. accomplish: The fact that two sides in a situation were able to even reach an agreement was a feat in that: Both sides agreed to take certain steps that were mutual. <n><n>B. make progress: The fact that and sides in a situation were was a feat in making progress because both sides agreed to take certain actions that were mutual.<n><n>C. stop arguing: The fact that the two sides were able: Both sides agreed to stop fighting in order to make an agreement.<n><n>D. do business: The fact that the both sides were able to: Both sides agreed to doing business with each other to make an agreement. <n><n>E. concert: The fact that the the sides were able: Both agreed to do mutual things which was an agreement.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What animal produces milk? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Society cannot exist without numbers. You must understand and memorize the instruction and apply the instructions correctly and correctly in different situations.<n><n>### Task 1: How Many Can A Human See?<n><n>### Instructions:A human can distinguish roughly about 5 million colors. Some believe that the number might be even a little higher. Write a response that describes at least 5 million different colors.<n>### Demontration:<n><n><n>The question states "describe at least 5 million colors." One way for a person to do this is to think about any object or item in their environment, and how many different colors are used in that object. For example, a person may find an object that is primarily red, and only has small segments of green and blue. This object would be a prime example of an object that can be described with "only five million different colors." For this answer, the word "describe" simply means "to give detailed information about something"<n><n>### Task2:What Would You Say?<n><n>### Questions:The word "say" in the question can be replaced by "tell". Rewrite the question by rephrasing it<n>using the word "tell."<n><n>### Question 2:Is there any difference between "what would you say?", and "what would you tell?"?<n><n>### Task3:How To Play<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>Write a response that includes the instructions below. The first instruction is a task. You must write a response to each task.<n><n>### First Instruction:<n>Play <n>### Second Instruction:<n>Tennis <n><n><n>### Third Instruction:<n>Golf <n>### Fourth Inst
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What would you use if you wanted to make some columns of numbers? Choices:  A: roman architecture B: whitehouse C: spreadsheet D: bridge E: pantheon<n><n>### Response:		The response is Roman architecture. <n><n>### Difficulty:Easy<n><n>### Demand:Knowledgable<n><n>### Knowledge Gained or Lessons Learned:How to determine the number of columns and rows using Roman architecture.<n><n>### Remarks:I would choose the option "Roman architecture" because in the question, it specifically says that you wanted to create columns. <n><n>## Instruction:Answer the multiple choice question<n><n>## Demonstration:Rationales:<n>The problem involves determining what type of architecture he meant.<n>1. Look for the first column.<n><n>The first column contains the number "I" twice.<n>Since these two "I's" do not seem to mean anything, we can cross it out.<n><n>2. Look for the second column.<n><n>In the second column, the number "V" occurs, and it's separated with a slash and "B" (indicating the space for the number).<n><n>Since there is no "X", we can cross out "B" as well.<n><n>3. Look for the third column.<n><n>In this column, we find "M", separated by a slash, indicating the space for the number.<n>Since there is no number, we can cross out "X".<n><n>4. Look for the fourth column.<n><n>We see the number "L" in the fourth column, where "X" should be.<n><n>Finally, we find the number "C".<n><n>Answer: The columns used would be the Roman columns, not the columns used in the Whitehouse or the pantheon.<n>Answer: Roman columns<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multipleChoice questions.<n><n>### What would you use if you needed to figure how a large building cost?<n><n>### Choices:A: brickB: paintC: woodD: mortarE: concrete<n><n>### Response::The response is (B) brick, (E) concrete, or (F) granite because the word ‘brick’ refers to a type of wall material. <n><n>## Demontration:Rationales<n><n>### Instructor/expert:<n>The problem involves identifying the material used in building a large building.<n><n>1. Look for "brick"<n><n>In the first column, we find the
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What would a person do to help someone that is not able to speak coherently? Choices:  A: sign language B: complete sentence C: drink tea D: feel angry E: cross street<n><n>### Response:		<n>> Answer: A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Read the instructions below and follow them.<n><n>### What's your favorite color?<n>### When's your birthday? <n><n>### What will you do after this course?<n><n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Why would someone be wet after being full of fear? Choices:  A: run B: swimming C: calculate things quickly D: fight enemy E: urinate<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A: run:<n><n>Let's say we have two people, one is wet after being full of Fear.<n><n>To determine whether or not one is wet after being FEAR-filled, run as fast as possible.<n><n>Even if one person runs, she will not be wet afterward because they are running fast as if they were frightened.<n><n>#### C: calculate things quickly: <n><n>One may be wet after being full with FEAR if he quickly calculates how to escape from the enemy.<n><n>This is because in the fear of enemy attack, you may not think properly.<n><n>Hence, you may be wet due to fear.<n><n>#### D: fight enemy:<n><n>One may be left wet after being full of anger if he decides to fight the enemy.<n><n>Since you are not properly calibrate your mind about everything when you are angry, you may get wet by fighting.<n><n>#### E: urinate:<n><n>When someone becomes frightened by the enemy's attack, he urinates because he has fear or is afraid. <n><n>When you are afraid, then you may have to do the following:<n>- Hold your breathing<n>- Pee<n><n>### Input-Response:<n><n>If it rains, people will be wet.<n><n>But if the rains wet, then the roads will be washed.<n><n>Watering the ground can cause a rainy effect.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Dan outfitted his house to run on the oldest heat source on Earth. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What would cause someone to use invitro for reproducing? Choices:  A: problems B: offspring C: overpopulation D: larger family E: baby<n><n>### Response:		The first choice is A<n>### Response:E<n>### Demonstion:A: not an option for reproducing<n>### Response:D<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The janitor got his pail out of where? Choices:  A: wishing well B: kitchen C: hardware store D: garage E: utility room<n><n>### Response:		The janitor's pail is usually kept in a hardware store, but if you wanted to be clever you might want to say that they got it from the garage.<n><n>### The Instuction:<n><n>### Demostration.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Input : Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Instuction.<n><n>### Demsotation : The next time you have to do a task, the best strategy is to come up with solutions to your problems and the best strategy is to brainstorm.<n><n>### Input.<n><n>### Respondation.<n><n>## Input:<n><n>## Instruction :<n><n>## Demostration :<n><n>## Answer :<n><n>## Instuction :<n><n>## Demotraction :<n><n>## Answer:<n><n>## Instuctions :<n><n>## Demeotrarion :<n><n>## Responsion:<n><n>## Instruc:<n><n>## Democatror:<n><n>## Answe:<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Sally took her medicine and experienced strong side effects.  What did doctors say about the side effects? Choices:  A: great B: distinguished C: remarkable D: excellent E: peculiar<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. <n><n>### Discussion:<n>The correct answer is A. <n>There are no commas in an answer to the question. Only statements.<n><n>Answer: Great!<n><n>Answer: Great<n><n>Answer: Great indeed!<n><n>Answer: I agree! Sally's side effects are great!<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>Question: What did Lulu do? <n><n>Answer: She dug the hole.<n><n>Answer: She washed her hands.<n><n>Answer: And picked her flower.<n><n>Answer: The flower is for me!<n><n><n>## Practice<n>* [Exercises](Exercises%20(Practice_I))<n>  * Example 1: Exercises (Practice I), Example 1<n>  * [Example 2](Exercises_20-16_Practice)%20(Pracice%20I),%  [Example 2](https://docs.google.com/document/d/16Ei59JrG8X6J9k4KCd5rX6mw7QK6Du-vVJUz0EhDYFk/download)tice I), [Example 2](http://s1.awsstatic.com/docsy/download/16Ei6GFZwmI3ZyHkQXC_bw5Zr-4WQ5.pdf)<n>  * [Example<n>  3](Exercises,_20-18_Practice),_Answer_20-19_(Practice_I), [Example 3](https://docs.d.awsstatic.com/_/downloads/74-5898-7479%5B1%5D.pdf)<n><n>* [Exercies](Exercises(PracticeII))<n>  * Example<n>  1: Exercis<n>ie_24-37_(Practice%20II),_Answer_Practice_II), [Example<n>  1](https://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSDocsCustomerContent/downloads/959-0818-7480-29.pdf
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:You can buy a pen here. Choices:  A: briefcase B: pocket C: friend's house D: office supply store E: classroom<n><n>### Response:		Please write your response here:<n><n>### Output:Output: What did you choose: a briefcase, pocket, classroom, briefcase, pocket, or classroom?<n>My choice is: classroom, classroom, classroom
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:James was delayed for a couple of hours because he had a connection.  Where might his connection be? Choices:  A: company B: airport C: wall D: computer network E: love<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice B: airport<n><n>### Instructions::<n><n>The problem involves finding out James' connection.<n><n>The question states that James was delayed for a couple hours because he had a problem with his connection.<n><n>The problem could literally be anywhere, it could be with his plane, his job, his computer, his home, his love for someone, etc.<n><n>It only says "there was a connection" and doesn't describe where the connection is.<n><n>However, it could be possible that James' connection was at the airport because he had boarded a flight.<n><n>Even though Choice E (love for someone) is an option, it is not the best answer choice because that can't be done by connecting to someone either, he just has love for them.<n><n>The connection could be with airplane, a job, his computer, etc.<n><n>Therefore, the correct answer is Choice B airport, because the other places that the connection could be are: at home, at school, at work, on a plane, etc.<n><n>The correct answer can be found in the choices: 3 letters out of the 5 letters of the correct answer, making the chance of getting the correct answer as 3/5, which is equal to 0.6.<n><n>The problem is ambiguous, in that Choice D (computer network) and Choice E (loving someone), are the options that are incorrect.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of foolhardy? Choices:  A: thoughtful B: discreet C: calculated D: cautious E: careful<n><n>### Response:		Foolhardy<n><n>Rationales:<n>Input:You need to figure out how many more oranges Mary bought compared to the number that Betty bought. You also have to figure out how much more oranges she bought.<n>Rationales:The problem involves determining how many more oranges that Mary bought compared to the total number that Betty bought and how much more oranges that Mary buys compared to Betty's. <n><n>We are not given the total number of oranges Betty bought or the total number of oranses Mary bought. <n><n>We can determine the total number of oranas bought by Mary by finding the total combined number of oranges bought by Mary and Betty from combining Betty's and Mary's total number of oranges.<n><n>Betty bought 10 oranges. <n><n>Mary bought 10 more oranges that Betty bought.<n><n>The total number of oranges bought is: 10 oranges bought by Betty and 10 more oranes that Mary bought = 20 oranges.<n><n>Now that we know how many more oranges Betty bought compared to the total oranges she bought, we can determine how many more oranges she bought by subtracting the number of oranges bought from Mary and Betty from the total number of oragnes bought. This is because we are not given any oranges from Mary and only from Betty.<n><n>This process is applied to determine a total number of oranges sold.<n><n>10 oranges bought and 10 more = 20 oragnes.<n><n>10 more oranges than the total number of oranages bought.<n><n>10 bought = 20 sold.<n><n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input : What day of the week did Thursday happen on?<n><n>### Response : It was a Thursday!<n><n>Rationales : <n><n>#### The problem involves checking the day to see if is was a Thursday.<n><n>### Input<n><n>You have to determine the amount of time it takes a horse to walk, run, jump, and trot for 11 seconds.<n><n>### Response<n><n>It takes 6.02 seconds<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people standing on a line near a road? Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:She was bad at dancing, so what basic skill did the instructor teach her? Choices:  A: euphoria B: rhythmic movement C: music D: moving body E: having fun<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: "B-rhythmic movement"<n><n>Input: You could buy two identical books for $4.99. You want to buy ten of them. How much money do you need to pay for your books? Choices: 22.80 0.72 4.96 49.90<n><n>Input: You bought ten bags of apples for $4.50. You want to buy twenty bags of apples. How much money should you pay for the apples? Choices: 40.00 65.00 59.00 93.00<n><n>Answer: "19.50" and "98.50"<n><n>Input: Two-thirds of a group of 21 people paid an entrance fee of $6.40 each to visit D'Wonders. The other third of the group paid 20% less, for a total of $4.94 each. How much was the entrance fee?<n><n>\(21 × 0.6 = 12.6\)<n><n>Answer: "$6.40"<n><n>Input : The total amount of money in Rushi’s piggybank is $8 and has not been taken out in some time. Therefore, the amount of coins in the piggybank is:<n><n>\($8\div\frac{1}{10}$\)=0.5<n><n>Answer: "0.80"<n><n>### Input :<n>She bought a shirt for $3 that she wanted to sell for $4.30 to make a profit of $1.30.<n>How much did she need to multiply her $3 profit by to get her profit?<n><n>Answer: "4"<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: A teacher sold 24 tickets to a concert for $6 each. What is the maximum amount of money the teacher made?<n>Input: You are playing a game where you can win $12, $10, or $8 dollars. You roll the dice and get a ten. What are your chances of winning $12?<n><n>### Response :<n>Input: 24 × $6 = $144<n><n>Input:1 / 12<n><n>### Input<n>She bought
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If a student was about to graduate, they would no longer be attending what? Choices:  A: library B: parties C: kindergarten class D: bar E: school<n><n>### Response:		In this context, a student who is about to graduate would no longer be attaining any of the choices. This is because when a student graduates, he or she would no longer be attain a bar unless they choose to take a bar exam. In the same way, they will not be attaining a library or a kindergarten class because they are too old and would no longer require these in their lives. Therefore, a student would no longer be attained a party either because parties are usually thrown in celebration for people not graduating. Therefore, a student cannot attend parties. Because a student is graduating, he or she would not enroll in kindergarten classes. Therefore, a person who is about to graduation would not be attaining a kindergarten class. To summarize, a graduating student will no longer be attaining school, a bar, a party, a library or a kindergartener class.<n><n>### Input :How many apples are there in the basket? Choices: 20 apples A: 6 apples B: 3 apples C: 4 apples D: 9 apples E: 2 apples<n><n>### Response :In this context, there are thirty apples in the basket. This is because there are five bunches of apples in the basket, as seen in the image below. Each bunch consists of six apples, as seen in the picture. Based on this context, there are five bunches and each bunch consists of six applest, therefore there are fifty apples in the basket total.<n><n>![example screenshot 1](example1.png)<n><n>Image from [Google Images](https://goo.gl/ZvRw6H)

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where may I view sharks in a clear tunnel? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries.
