If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is an way for people to meet with each other? Choices:  A: believe in god B: pay bills C: group together D: enjoy themselves E: face each other<n><n>### Response:		C.<n><n>### Input A: What did the group do when they found out that their teacher was leaving? Choices:   A: got mad B: got quiet C: were excited D: talked loud<n>### Response:D.<n><n>### Your Response: A: Believing in God was when people went to Church.<n>B: Pay bills were when they paid or had too take money from a money box.<n>C: Group together was when they were all in the same group or place.<n>D: Enjoy themselves was when they were happly.<n><n><n>### Your response:<n>### Input A<n>1.What did the group do when their teacher was leaving?<n>C. Group together was when they all were happy.<n>2. What did Betty give to her teacher for the farewell?<n>A. She gave her a handbook she made.<n>3.  What did Mrs. Smith and Mr. Green decide to do as a teacher before leaving?<n>A. They had a final class before leaving.<n>4. What does the author say about recycling?<n>C. If it was easy to make money.<n>5. What did Marilyn do when Mr. Green announced he’s leaving?<n>A. She was not happy about it.<n>6. What happened to the kids that didn’t pay their bills?<n>B. They were in jail.<n>7. How much money did Mr. Green collect?<n>C. He collected $207.50.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What does exercising immediately lead to? Choices:  A: relaxation B: exhaustion C: energetic D: become stronger E: use energy<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions:How long does a 3 mile race last? Choices: A. 10 seconds B. 20 minutes C. 30 minutes D. 3 hours E. 45 minutes<n><n>### Response A<n><n>### Instractions:Anna can wash 3 cars in 2.5 hours, and Max can wash 6 cars in 60 minutes, how long would it take Max and Anna working to together to wash 20 cars? Choices: <n> - A: 1 hour <n> - B: 4 hours <n> - C: 6 hours <n> - D: 7.5 hours <n> - E: 6 hours<n><n>### Response B&D<n><n>### Inputs:What is a combination of numbers that can be made? Choices: A: the result of 2 divided by 2 B: the result of 18 divided by 3 C: the remainders at the end of dividing by 3 D: an answer that can be multiplied by 1<n>-E: none of these - A is the result of dividing two by two which is four.<n><n>### Response D<n>-E: none<n><n>### Input A:If the perimeter and rectangle is 27cm, and its width is half of its perimeter. What is its length? Choices: – A: 5cm B: 2cm C: 2.5cm D: 6cm E:4 cm -C<n><n>### Rationales:If the perimeter of the rectangle is 27 cm and if the length is half of the perimeter then it’s width is half of the length to perimeter formula<n>The ratio between the length and the width is “1:2”<n>The ratio between the width and the length is 2(1/2) =1<n>The ratio of the perimeter to length is 1<n><n>To solve this we have to know the perimeter and the width of the rectangle<n><n>The perimeter is (2 × length)<n><n>The perimeter = 2(H/2)<n><n>The perimter = 2(length/2)<n><n>So length 2 (length/2)<n>Then 4(length/2) =27<n><n>Therefore length = 2

Is it possible?<n><n>2:Is coffee a lot colder than water?<n><n><n>3:A cupful of water can be rolled into a tube. Is it possible? One sentence states that water can be rolled into any shape, whereas another sentence states that paper can be rolled into any. shape. If an object is put into a shape that is different from its original shape, then it can not be rolled into that shape. When the sentences are said as statements, it is clear that both statements are true. However, if the sentences are written as questions, then the statements are not true because they can not prove that water can be rolled in into a tube or coffee can be rolled up into a cone.<n><n>### Response<n>1:B<n>2:B<n>3:A<n><n>## Task<n>1. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A student wants to hear what the professor is saying, what does he do? Choices:  A: gain experience B: taking notes C: listen carefully D: complete test E: focus<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>If there are 46 cards in a standard deck of 52 cards,how many cards are in 2 1/2 decks?<n><n>### Reasoning:<n>First, you need to figure out how many cards are in the first and second decks.(2½ deck)<n><n>Now, do the first 1 deck<n><n>Then, the second 1 deck or simply the difference to 2 decks<n><n>Finally, add the 2 decks.<n><n>### Solution:<n>In a standard deck of 46 cards, one 1/2 deck contains 23 cards because 52 cards ÷ 23 = 2.2, which is close to 2.5<n>52 ÷23 = 21/2 (1.5).<n><n>When 1 deck = 21/52 x 1 deck<n><n>then 2 1/5 decks = 41/52 x  21/52<n><n>41/52 + 21/5 43/52<n><n>or 46/52<n><n>(43/52 are left because we subtracted 2 in the second column)<n><n>### Instruct ions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you dispose of a broken icebox? How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a theater which only has unpaid actors? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:After bringing eggs home from the store in what are they held? Choices:  A: chicken coop B: supermarket C: box D: egg carton E: henhouse<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions: Use the table below to answer the following two multiple choice questions.<n>Input: Eighty is 10 less than three times a number. The number is 459 more than five times the number. If the number is 200, what is the sum of the two number?<n>Input: The table describes the weight of each bag for a certain type of dog food.<n><n><n>### Demostration:<n>In problem Eighty is 3 times the minimum of two numbers: 459 and 200.<n><n>To find the number, subtract the two minimum 459 – 200<n><n>459 – 10<n><n>The answer is 359<n><n>In problem the three columns are 5, 15, 25.<n><n>The total of all three numbers in the first column is 9<n><n>The total for all three in the second column is 39<n><n>The total of two numbers in the third column is 51<n><n>The product is 39 x 51.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The wood became fossilized, what did the paleontologists call it when they found ti? Choices:  A: sanded B: composted C: warp D: hardened E: petrify<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>The term used to describe a wood that was buried in sediments and sanded and changed into stone (or rock) over time.<n><n>Warp:<n><n>Warp: A distortion in a machine-made fabric or sheeting, such as a woven, knitted, or nonwoven.<n><n>### Input<n><n>You have been tasked with creating an algorithm programmed in Python 3 that will solve the following problem. You have to find the number that exists the most times in the inputed string.<n><n>### Rationate:Here is how to think about this: To create an algorithm you should start off by asking yourself what the goal is for the program, then create a flowchart that you can follow later. This way you can see how long it should take you, and how many loops you have to run. Your problem is this:<n><n>### Input Data:<n>Your input data is going to be the string. All you need is to look at every character in the string and determine which one occurs the most.<n><n>### Steps:<n>1) Start off with the initial string.<n>2) Go through every character of that string and find the frequency.<n><n>### Output:<n>Determine which character occurs the most out of all the characters and report it back to the user.<n><n>### Algorithm 1:<n>If string = “hello”:<n><n>- Loop through every character.<n><n>- Increment a counter by 1 when the character in the string matches the current character of the loop<n><n>- Print the value of the last increment.<n><n>Answer: 3, because the v has appeared 3 times<n><n>### Algorithm Two:<n>```<n>def most_common_string(string):<n>    count = set()<n>    for letter in string:<n>        if letter not in count:<n>            count[letter] = 1<n>        else:<n>            count[ letter ] += 1<n>    most_common = count.most_common(1)<n>    return most_common[0][1]<n>```<n>(you can use other ways of iterating through strings in Python 3. Some of these are: strings, for loop, while loop, counter, range, map, dict functions, etc..)<n><n>---<n><n># Input Data:You work for the famous shipping
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A small dog is lost in New England, where would it likely be found? Choices:  A: own home B: old england C: new hampshire D: coffin E: denmark<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>

They decided on C (arena) and started digging. Soon the found something that was different? from what they expected. What did they find? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What does someone need to do to begin creating art? Choices:  A: relax B: controversy C: pleasure D: frustration E: needs theater<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer to the question is: A: relax.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>First, you need to relax to begin creating art.<n><n>Second, the other choices do not work as answers because there is no controversy, frustration, or pleasure.<n><n>There is no need for theater.<n><n>There is also no need for controversy or frustration.<n><n>Therefore, the correct option is relax.<n>Answer: A: relax<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the statement.<n><n>### Statement: I am very interested in learning math and science.<n><n>Answer:<n><n>### Input<n><n>You want to know how to use a 3 in 1 oil. How many cups of cooking oil?<n><n>### Example<n><n>You want to cook for 5 people when the recipe calls for ¼ cups and you only have half of that amount or 2 ¼ cups. How can you make twice the amount you have?<n><n>### Solution for the example above<n><n>1.	Multiply 4 to the power of 0.25 and add the results together. <n>2. The answer for this example is 7.5 cups.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Let’s say u have 3 in 1. <n><n>To make 1 cup, u have to take ¼ cup oil plus ¼ cup water plus ¼ cup flour.<n>What we need to do is to multiply 4 to the power 0.25 plus 4 to the power.75.<n><n>Let’s substitute 0.25 for x and.75 for y and follow the steps.<n><n>1.	Subtract x from 1<n><n>2.	4 to the power 1 minus 4 to x power<n><n>3.	4 to the x power<n><n>Let’s go back and start all over again. We have to solve this equation.<n><n>4.	4 to the y power<n><n>5.	Multiply x and y<n><n>6.	4 to the z power<n><n>7.	Add 4 to the power z to the power 1<n><n>Answer:<n>```<n>1.	Substitute 0.25 to x<n>2.	Subtract 1 from x<n>```<n>3.	4 x to
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where is a bay always found? Choices:  A: lake B: manhattan C: shoreline D: coastal area E: los angeles<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input :<n>I have 5 boxes. <n>They weigh 50, 70, 90, 110 and 130 pounds each.<n><n>What is the total weight of all boxes?<n><n>### Response :<n>910 pounds<n><n>### Input  :<n>Find the amount of change: A) $17 B) $20 C) $30 d) $31 <n><n>### Response<n>d<n><n>### Input<n>How many pencils are in the bag if only 7 crayons and 16 pencils are missing?<n><n>### Answer<n>26<n><n>### Input A) There are 5 red balls and 20 purple ones. <n><n>### Answer B) The number of purple balls is 20. Rational: The number of purple ones is 20.<n><n>### Input How many coats are sold if a store sells 80 shirts.<n><n>### Answer 0<n><n>### Response B) The number of shirts sold is 80.<n><n>## Question<n>### Instruction Write a script/program that will print 10 squares, and then print the word "end" at the top of the 10th square. The number of the square should not be included at the top of the "end" line.<n><n>### Response A:<n>![output](./10Squares.png)<n><n>### Response C:<n>![output](10squares.png)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The man needed to buy flooring, where was he looking for it? Choices:  A: plain B: cold C: dull D: bad E: wet<n><n>### Response:		<n>If it rains today, I am going home wet(bad).<n><n>### Input <n><n>Write at least 7 complete sentences explaining the instructions.<n><n>### Response<n><n>First you must determine what is the size of the rectangle. Then you must determine how many squares are inside the rectangle. Finally, you must tell how many squares surround the rectangle.<n><n>### Input<n><n>A rectangular park is 34 feet long and 46 feet wide. How many square feet of grass does it have?<n><n>### Response <n><n>Step 1 : <n>For a rectangle to have a size X cm by Y cm, multiply the Length (X) by the Width(Y). <n>If the rectangle length is 50.6 cm and width is 80 cm, the rectangle size is 1.130 x 1.111 m. <n>In this case the rectangle is 5.487 m x 4.634 m, or 22.84 m squared. This is how you can compute how many squares are inside a rectangle.<n><n><n>Step 2:You have already figured out how to find out how many number of squares do you have. To find out how many number squares are around the rectangle, simply subtract the number of squares in the rectangle from the total number of squares the rectangular park has. In this example, the rectangle of the park is 22.88 m and total number of squares around it is 22 m, just subtract 22 m to 22.8 m and the answers will be 0.8.<n><n>Step 3:Therefore, the rectangle of the rectangular park is 22 m per side, and the rectangle of the park has 22.85 m squared per side.<n><n>### Answer:<n>The rectangle of the park is<n><n>22 m by 46 m square per side, <n>per each square is 22 m squared, and <n>there are 22.8 m m of all 46 m per side of rectangle.<n><n>Answer: 932 sq ft<n><n>### Instructions: Write a response that appropriatley completes the request. <n><p>Choose the answer that best completes the sentence or statements. Be sure to explain your answer

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The man set the cup on the table.  It didn't matter.   He didn't heave anything to put it on, and he lacked the what to balance it? Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		There are three statements of facts.<n>The man put the cup on the table and it didn't matter. <n>This means that it is not important, and <n>The fact that the man lacked the what (something) to support or balance it. <n>The fact that he could do this means he had what it takes. <n>Hard work!<n><n>### Input :  A cowboy was in the saloon when suddenly a man came in with a coyote tied to his right hand.  The coyote's left paw was injured and hanging down by his side. "Why this here coyote is in trouble," said the bartender. "What do you need?"  "I don't need a stump for the coyote's paw," responded the cowboy, "but I'll take a drink." <n>After he had finished, he walked out, left hand empty-handed.  "That cowboy was a thief!" The bartender quickly called out behind. The cowboy stopped and turned around.  "I'm leaving my stump with you so the coyote'll feel better," he explained. <n>"Thank you kindly for your honesty, " responded the bartender.  "You haven't asked for nothing in return. "No matter," said the cowboy. "All I can say is thanks. But this here coyote, he's in trouble—one paw is in a bad way an' the other is bad, too."<n>After drinking a second round, he continued, "This is a one-handed drink." <n><n>### Response :  The cowboy did not have anything to drink in his right hand.<n>That is why the bartender asked the cowboy, “I don't need stumps for the coyote’s paw.” In this case “nothing” is an object which the cowboy did not have in his hand.<n>After the conversation, cow boy was leaving and the bartender called that he is a thief. The bartender is shocked that cow boy is a thief and he wants to know the reason. Cow boy explains that the coyote is injured and he offers his one-handed drink as a gift. However the bartender misunderstands it as a gift for being a thief.

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:You might head to the locker room after getting a green drink here. Choices:  A: health club B: jocks C: fitness centre D: stadium E: gymnasium<n><n>### Response:		Answer the question.<n><n>## Rationale:<n>Let's see where locker room is on menu.<n><n>We need to go to the locker room, so we should go to choice E. <n><n>If you get a blue beverage instead, you end up in the parking lot.<n><n>There are only two choice at the stadium: jocks or fitness centre. <n><n>At the jocks, you can get a purple beverage. <n><n>If get a red beverage instead, you head to the parking lot. <n><n>At fitness centre instead of purple, you can get  a purple drink. <n><n>If we get the purple drink instead, we should go to the health club. <n><n>But if we get a red drink, we should just get the health club. 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The sanctions against the school were a punishing blow, and they seemed to what the efforts the school had made to change? Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n><n>### Response:		Authoritarian: this describes the sanction was what the school did to change the punishing behavior of the student.<n><n>### Input<n>There is an array of integers called A consisting of 5 even integers and 5 odd integers. The program displays the elements of the sequence in a list such that each element of the array is a distinct item in the list and each item appears only once.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>We want to write a for loop and then do a nested for loop to help generate the list.<n><n>A for loop is the main program because it is the one that generates the list. <n><n>The elements of the array are 5 even integers and then 5 odd integers. <n><n>The nested for loop generates each item in the outer for loop. <n><n>I want to loop from 0 to the number of elements in the array to ensure that my list goes from first item in the array to last.<n><n>The array has 5 even integers so I have 5 nested for loops to go from 0 to 5.<n><n>The first array has the even integers from 0 to 4. <n>Therefore, the loop begins at the second array from left to right to get the remaining odd integers.

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Joe suffered many consequences from stabbing a stranger to death.   Among them, the family of the victim did something to him. What was that? Choices:  A: knife wounds B: buy a gun C: bleeding D: jail time E: law suit<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Joe suffered many consequences from stabbed a stranger to death. Among them, the family, of the victim did something. The choices are: A knife wounds, B buy a gun, C bleeding, D jail time and E lawsuit<n>Rationales: This stabbing caused severe consequences for Joe. <n>The family of the victim knifed him.<n>They caused a lot of pain to him because he knifed one of their victims, <n>but he didn't know it would have a huge consequence to Joe.<n>The stabbing led Joe to buy a gun. <n>This resulted in further severe consequences of Joe.<n>He had to go through a lot of pain.<n>Hence, he bought a gun to save himself.<n>The last consequence is jail time. <n>A jail was set on sight after the incident.<n>He was being interrogated, questioned and sent to prison. <n>He served his time. <n>Now he came back and he still felt pain on the wound. <n>He also had bruises in his body. He was bleeding and he had bruises.<n>Finally there was a lawsuit to settle the family of the victims. <n>This is a terrible consequence of Joe.<n><n>Answer: A.<n><n>### Input:'I am happy to buy a house for us. Would you like it, and how much will you pay? Please advise about your answer.'<n><n>### Rationales:This stabbing caused severe repercussions for Joe. Because he knifed one the people,<n>this made them angry. The family of the victim knife him, and as a result, made him bleed and go through a lot of agony.<n>He bought a gun to protect himself from the situation, however this caused even worse effects upon him.<n>His family had to jail.<n>Then after everything was settled he had to buy a house for them.<n>So after all he still had to pay back from the incident.<n>He came back to the family and he was still bleeding from the wound.<n>So it wasn't a good result.<n><n>Answer: D.<n><n>###Input:Government wants to lower health spending by 25% over the next 5 years<n><n>###Rationales:Government wants healthcare costs on

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where in Southern Europe would you find many canals? Choices:  A: michigan B: new york C: amsterdam D: venice E: bridge<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Choice D – Venice, Italy<n><n>### Input : A person is playing a game where they can win one of four prizes. They cannot win more than two prizes. They can either win a bag of goldfish crackers (worth $2),  a pizza (worth $5), an A+ grade on their next math test (worth $6), or none of these items (worth $0). If you win both a pizza and a A+, which prize is worth the most money?<n><n>### Response : Bag of Goldfish<n><n>### Input  : A person is playing  a game where they can get one of four prizes, a bag of goldfish, an A+, a pizza or nothing. A+ is worth 60% of how much money a pizza is worth and a pizza is worth 80% of how much a bag of goldfish is worth to the same person. If 7% more than twice a person's money is less than 2.5 billion how much does that person make?<n>- Choices: <n>A: 700<n>B: 329<n>C: 293<n>D: 291<n>E: 340<n><n><n>### Response  : 329<n><n><n>### Input   : On a trip, a family bought two different magazines worth the same exact value.<n><n>Input: On a trip a family bought a magazine worth $6 and a magazine worth $3. How much money did the family spend on the magazines?<n><n>### Choices:<n><n>A. $7<n><n>B. $9<n><n>C. $3<n><n>D. $6<n><n>E. $18<n><n>### Response   : 3<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>In this assessment your response should be a step-by-step explanation that walks the instructor through your thought process while solving the problem. What do you think about that?<n><n>Rationales <n>Some people think it's wrong to make fun of people.<n><n>### Response<n><n>If you disagree, you can't possibly be right about that.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where is there usually a fiddle playing? Choices:  A: music store B: dance hall C: orchestra D: symphony E: tennessee<n><n>### Response:		D

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What do drugs do? Choices:  A: damage B: cloud mind C: lower i.q D: cause illness E: cause accidents<n><n>### Response:		There are many different drugs that do different things in your body. All can be classified into one of the following categories: depressant (like alcohol), opiod, and cannabis. Drugs are any substance that produces a certain effect when consumed by a living organism. For now, you are not going to be concerned about where they come from. <n><n>#### Depressants<n> <n>Depressants are drugs that have a sedative effect on the body and reduce one's level of awareness. Alcohol is a depressant. <n><n>Depressants have effects on a person’s brain. A depressant slows down a person’s ability to think quickly or focus. Alcohol affects most people for 3 to 4 hours and slows the body's central nervous system. Alcohol has a great range of effects. There is no specific effect it has on a person. The most dangerous effects are on your body's motor system. Alcohol affect the way the body moves and the way it breathes. Other effects include lowered in vision, poor coordination, and blackouts. <n><n>#### Opioids<n><n>Opioids are drugs that affect the body's endorphins. Opioids are one of the most commonly abused drugs. They are highly addictive. Opiods make you feel relaxed and comfortable. Opioids make you have slower reflexes and coordination and you have trouble thinking clearly. Opioids affect both the central nervous system and the endorphins. Opiods block and overwork the opioid receptors. <n><n>#### Cannabis<n><n>Cannabis or marijuana is a kind of drug made from the Cannabis Sativa plant. It impacts the user's brain receptors. The user becomes stimulated and relaxed and feel euphoria. This means that the user has a sense of well-being and pleasure. The effects last for 4 to 6 hours. Cannabis has no known lethal dose. <n>Cannabis affects the lungs and the nervous system. It can cause coughing, sneezing, and itching to the throat, eyes, and skin.<n><n>###<n>#### A: damage<n><n>Depress

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:He was receiving workman's compensation, he had tripped over a metal rod while building where? Choices:  A: factory B: construction site C: engine D: insides of skyscraper's walls E: shops<n><n>### Response:		<n>-A<n>-B<n>-C<n>-D<n>-E<n><n>### Instructions:A pizza company has to pay the delivery person, the pizza chef, and the cleaning person. The amount needed to pay the cheeses per pizza is $0.90, to pay the cleaner per pizza is $3.60, to pay the delivery person per pizza is $5.20. If there are 8 pizzas in an order, how much does it cost to make and deliver the order to a customer's house?<n><n>### Instructtion:Input:<n>```<n>12 6 52<n>```<n><n>### Demostration:<n>First sum the quantities to get the total. <n>```<n>12 + 6 + 52 = 68<n>```<n>Then, divide the quantity by the total to get each quantity as a percentage. <n>```<n>68 / 68 = 100%<n>```<n>Now, divide each quantity by 100% to get it as a fraction. <n>```<n>0.9 / 100% = 0.09<n>```<n>Next, multiply each item by the fraction. Now, add to get the total item cost. <n>```<n>520.09 + 0.09 * 3.6 + 0.052 * 5.2 = 145.11<n>```<n>Finally, subract the total item cost from the total to get the cost of the pizza. <n>```<n>85.29  − 145.9 = 60.62<n>```<n>Answer: 60.61902960821382<n><n>### Input<n>We are on track to complete this project by the deadline, unless of course the following occurs. Something goes wrong with our tools…<n>There are multiple tools and we just don’t know what will break down before the project deadline. So we are prepared for any and all cases.<n><n>### Options<n>Tool Break Down<n><n>Option A <n><n>Option B <n><n><n><n><n>Option C <n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The student needed to  get some new pencils, where did he go? Choices:  A: store B: classroom C: backpack D: cabinet E: teacher<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: The student is in class. <n><n>If he is in class, he is probably in the backpack. <n><n>Input: The student needed to get some pencils where did he go. <n><n>Choices: a - C: This choice involves going to a store to get some new pencil. <n>The student did not go to a store. <n><n>b - B: This choice is classroom. <n><n>Choice B is correct since classroom is in the backpack.<n><n>c - D: This choice is cabinet. <n><n>Choic D is wrong since the student is in a classroom and is not in the pencil cabinet.<n><n>d - E: This choice is teacher. <n><n>Teacher is not in the backpack and is not in the student pencil cabinet. <n><n>Therefore, choose B<n><n>Input:The student needed to get some new pancakes, where did he go Choices:  A. classroom B. kitchen C. cafeteria D. library E. restroom<n>Answer: I think the student went to the classroom. Since the student needs to get new pancakes for breakfast. And in the classroom, there are no pancakes. So it is logical to choose the statement that the classroom pancakes.<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Demotration:<n>Input : The student needed to get new pancakers for breakfast, where did he go choices : A)classroom B)kitchen C)cafeteria D)library E)restroom<n><n>Input : First of all, We need to find where we can find food. We need to find restroom for pee breaks and the cafeteria for food. so choose A and B<n><n>The student goes to kitchen, since it is right beside the cafeteria<n>The student needed to get new panckers, where did he go?<n><n>Answer : C, since he can not get new pancakes from the kitchen since it is right beside cafeteria<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where can meat last a long time? Choices:  A: backery B: ham sandwich C: fridge D: butcher shop E: freezer<n><n>### Response:		<n>Demonstration:<n>The question asks where meat lasts a long time. The first thing you should think is of places where meat is sold. Those are butcher shops, backery, and fridge. However, a fridge or the backery do not last a long time. That would mean that the answer is a butcher shop or a freezer.<n><n>Rationales: <n>First you have to think back to the fridge, the ham sandwich and the butcher shop, those would be good options to choose.<n>It does not say that it has to be a lot of time.<n>But it has to be long enough for it to be unedible.<n>If you took it out of the butcher shop after it being there for 22 hours, then it would still be there.<n>But if you take it out of the fridge it will be spoiled, that is enough time for it to be unhealthy.<n><n>Freezer: A freezer works because it is unhealthily cold, therefore bacteria do not grow and meat stays fresh for a long amount of time. But not too long because some people like to eat it after 30 days (https://www.verywellfit.com/expiration-dates-on-food-mean-what-5079580). Meat does last for a while as long as it is not left out at room temperature and has not been opened, (https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/how-long-do-meat-products-last-after-opened-refrigerator-180961007/)<n>Butcher Shop: This is a place where meat can stay fresh because it is at the right temperature and no outside bacteria could touch the food.<n>This type of meat last for a long time.<n>The average person takes meat out of the meat case 4 times.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The teacher told all the students that listening was key, it was the main way they would gain what? Choices:  A: empathy B: anxiety C: knowlege D: falling down E: hear things<n><n>### Response:		The answer is empathy.<n><n>### Rationale:The students' listening, or "absorbing" information, will give them empathy.<n>
