If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:It was a great rest, she had never felt this much what in the morning? (Select a) A: Panic B: Stay calm. C: Seek help D: Forgot (Notice the answer)<n>Rationales: <n>A panic could make matter worse because you might hurt yourself or others. <n>Staying calm will help you think better and react properly to the situation. <n>Finally, asking for help may not be a bad way to do since you may get hurt badly or worse if you try to help.<n><n>Input: For every hour at the grocery store, you earn $5, for every bag you bring, you earn $1; for every empty bottle you bring back, you earn $0.70. How many hours at the grocery shop did you spend and how much did you earn?<n>Rationals: At first, we need to calculate the total number of hours in which you made a total of $5, $1 and $0.70 per hour. <n><n>This can be broken down into this problem into the formula: x * y = z <n><n>5 * x = 10 <n><n>This can then be rewritten into an equation in which the unknown variables, or x, can be found. <n><n>5x = 10 5 x (x) = (10)x<n><n>x = 10 / 5 = 2 <n><n>Now, let's look at y, which is used to replace the variable x in the formula where every hour of time, you will receive a dollar. <n><n>Let's write y * x = 5<n><n>y * 2  = 5* 2<n><n>y = 5/2 = 25/5 = 5 <n><n>Now, on the last part about the per hour of earning, that is, finding the dollar value per hour is simply by using x/30 of it. <n><n>This will not only change the value of the dollar but will also change the value of each amount you have earned. <n><n>When 30 is divided into 0.7 of seconds, that is equal to 42. <n><n>Therefore, what y and x is all about: <n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If you're speaking to a lawyer about getting a divorce, what relationship status are you trying to end? Thursday afternoon<n>C. Friday morning<n>D. Thursday morning<n>E. The frostings in question come in four flavors: vanilla, cookies-and-cream, chocolate and strawberry. They are offering this special price from Monday to Thursday. From Friday to Sunday, they charge their regular price for these same four flavors. If you buy two containers of frosting of different flavors, the total price you will be charged is $13.40. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:WHat leads to someone's death when they are very depressed? Choices:  A: suicide B: overdosing C: sadness D: murder E: cyanide<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions: <n>Depression is a mental illness characterized by sadness and low self-esteem. It can lead to suicide. Suicide is the act of intentionally killing oneself.<n><n>Answer:

A python is eating a mouse. A python is eaten by a baby horse. An elephant is attacking a shark. A crocodile is eating a seahorse. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What will happen to skin pinched in something? Choices:  A: feel cold B: feel pressure C: feel bumpy D: itches E: feel clammy<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Rationales: <n><n>### Skin will itch. <n><n>The skin that is pinched in something will feel icky because it feels different; it feels clumsy, bunky, clammy, pressure, and cold.<n><n>### Answer:  D<n><n>### Input<n>> What will happen to something that becomes too hot? Choices: 1. feels dry 2. begins to dry 3. begins to burn 4. feels wet 5. will melt 6. feels sticky 7. will dry up<n><n>### Response answer:<n>> What will happen if something becomes too hot?  Choices: 1: feels dry 2: begins to dry 3: begins to burn 4: feels wet 5: will melt 6: feels sticky 7: will dry up<n><n><n>### Rational:<n>> Skin that are exposed to too much heat cause the human body to experience extreme discomfort. There are actually three stages of too much heat that humans experience: dry, wet, and hot.<n><n>Dry/sense of coldness is a mild discomfort.<n><n>Burning is the most damaging and painful stage.<n><n>Hot/sense of heat is extremely intense heat that causes pain and discomfort.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where is a tabby cat likely to be happiest? Choices:  A: box B: home C: alley D: lap E: barn<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>Input: The total revenue earned by a pizza franchise last week was $2,900. A total of 210 pizzas was sold last week. How much money was earned per pizza?<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Input: The total amount of revenue earned was $2900. <n><n>Input: The number of pizzas sold was 210. We know $2900 / 210 = $13.59 This is the cost per pizza.<n><n>### If 2 more cans were bought, the price would be 61% of their current cost. If only 2 cans were bought, they would be reduced by 61%.<n><n>### Input/Answer:<n>Total cans - 2 = (62 cans x $0.32 price per can) / (100% - 61%) = 61 cans<n><n><n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The new play was the go to performance of the year, all the crowds would stand and what? For this reason, the answer does not need to be a mathematical answer.<n><n>Answer: (64 / 2x3){71}<n><n>Answer1 should be 42. <n><n>Answer 2 should be 53.<n><n>### Multiple Choice Question:<n>#### Instruction: Choose the least/greatest number that is greater than 1.<n><n>#### Demostation:<n><n>##### 16 4 1 25 8<n><n>##### Answer: 25 <n><n>##### Demostration for (B): is 19, all the rest are less than 16<n><n>##### Demotrastion for (D): is the greatest, as all other numbers after 9 are less than 9<n><n>#### Demostraton for (A): is the least, all other numbers after 1 are less than 1<n><n>Answer should be 16<n><n>### Multiple choice answer:<n>#### Question: Find the missing value,<n>#### Demostrated answer: is<n><n>Answer: is 19<n><n>Answer2: 25<n><n>### Math question:<n><n>#### Instruction: Find the answer to the following maths equation in your own words.<n><n>#### Demosration: Find 27/3, dividing 3 by 7, gives you with an answer of 2, and then you divide again and get an answer

From those circles, you will mark the half of the number line.<n>The one that is half of 5 (the half of the number) = 2.5<n><n>### Instuctios:What is the next multiple of ten?<n><n>### Demo:<n><img src = "NextTen.png" alt="Demostrating of the question" width = "150%" /><n><n>### Next Ten<n><n>### Insttuction:Find the next number in the sequence.<n><n>### Demo<n><n><img src = '26-InTheSequence.png' alt="Demostrate" width="100%" /><n><n><n>### Math sequence<n><n>- The first number is 2<n>- The second number is 4<n>- The third number is 6<n>- The fourth number in the sequence is 1<n><n>### Instructons:What is the next number in the multiplicat sequence: 15, 33, 75

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Letters are sometimes delivered by hand through one of these. Choices:  A: mail box B: suitcase C: front door D: bowl E: post office<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```python<n>answer = input('Please pick one:')<n>if answer in ['suitcase','box']:<n>    print('That was correct. Letters can be carried by hand through a suitcase or a box.')<n>elif answer in ['front door']:<n>    print ('That was correct. Letter can be delivered by hand through the front door.')<n>else:<n>    print ('Answer was wrong!')<n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Instructions:Fill in the next letter, or you will be stuck without one. Choices: <n>A: T B: D C: H D: L E: A F: I G: J H: O I: P K: R M: S N: V N: P H: R I: T S: M I: E T: S<n><n>### Response<n><n>```python<n>letter = input('Please pick the next letter:')<n>if letter in ['D','J','H','P','T']:<n>    print(letter +'was correct.')<n>else: <n>    print('You are incorrect so the letter is:H')<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The president had to make a decision regarding the hate attack on his country, what did he do? Choices:  A: wage war B: fight enemy C: kill D: destroy enemy E: attacked his country<n><n>### Response:		Answer "b"<n><n>Input:You have read that "the great granddaughters of slaves were just a hundred years ago denied the privilege of voting." Is this fact correct? Choices:  yes  no<n>Input: You went to a supermarked without an item list. Which is the easiest to pick out? Choices:A) B) C) D) E)<n>Input:The number of cancels in your local town hall are about to be reduced. What will you do? Choices:A: B: C: D: E:<n><n>### Input:"Draco Malfoy's real name is Draco Lucius Malfoy and is an English actor."<n><n>### Response:"Yes this fact is true"<n><n>### Input"When are you going to learn maths?"<n>### Answer: "I already have"<n>### Instruction:"Do you remember what happened yesterday?"<n>### Response:"I forgot"<n>### Input:"You shouldn't walk on the roof."<n>### Answer:"I know"<n><n>### Instrument: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input:"How many friends do you want to invite for our birthday party?"<n><n>Answer:"I would like to invite five friends."<n><n>### Instructions Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Input1:In your hometown, how many supermarked do you have?<n><n>### Instuction:Anwer a.<n><n>### Demo:A) Yes<n>### Input2:How do you usually go to supermarked? A) Walking is the easiest way for me.<n><n>### Answer:b.<n>### Demo:B) I walk there<n><n>### Instution:"How do you enjoy your summer? A) I go swimming. B) I play football and play volleyball. C) I go out and buy things to play on the beach. D) I go out and party with my friends.<n><n>### Response"I prefer A"<n>### Demo:c

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If you tell you boss your suffering from boredom they'll likely tell you to get back to what? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where do you put a new dining table? The house is the only option that is suitable for the new dining table.<n><n>### Input :A: cafeteria<n><n>### Response : The dining table can stay there, since the cafeteria does not need it.<n><n>### CBSE Sample Paper Class 2: Answer the following question.<n><n>## Input: If 24 cakes cost $776 and 25 cakes cost $800.How many cakes cost $900?<n><n>## Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>## Rationale:<n>It is asked to find out how many cakes have to be purchased to cover the entire expense.The number of cakes required to cover the total bill = total expense/ average cost of cake. Therefore, 24cakescost$776 and 5cakescost$800so the average cost of a cake is $776/29 = \text{\small $26.73$}\newline\newline The number of cakes = \text{\small$26.73\cdot25$}\newline= \text{\small$670.875$}\newline<n><n>## Rationals:<n>## A: _____<n>## B: _____<n>## C: _____<n>## D: _____<n>## E: _____<n><n>## Instructions:<n>For the given question, there are multiple choices. The given instruction asks to find out the options that meet the criteria.<n><n>### A: The new dining table needs a small table to be placed on the floor.<n><n>### B: The new dining room needs more pillows.<n><n>### The new dining room is too small for the new dining room.<n><n>### D: The newly purchased dining table needs to fit in the small dining room.<n>### E: The new dining tables should be placed in the backyard.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Option A has to get the smallest table for the dining table because it will be placed on the floor of the dining room. Option D should get the dining table that fit in the backyard of the house.<n><n>### Answer: _____
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would someone learn to play an upright piano? Choices:  A: music room B: music store C: music class D: medium E: house<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n><n>### Input - Choice 1: If you subtracted less than 5, you lost a turn.<n>### Input - Answer 1: My turn ends.<n><n>### Response - Choice 1's Answer: Yes<n><n>### Input Choice 2 - Addition or subtraction? Choice 3: Choice 1: A: yes (answer) Choice 2: B: yes (Answers) Choice 3: B: yes (Anwer)<n><n>### Response Choice 3:  Answer:  Yes, I can choose to add<n><n>### Choice 4 -  If Betty picked 17 strawberries  and James picked 10 more strawberies than Betty and 6 more strawberries in all, they used their strawberies to make jam.  How many times is Betty's number of strawberies  times the numbers of times strawberries was picked?<n> <n>### Choice - answer 4: B: 15<n><n>#### Rationale:<n>  Betty picked 17 <n><n>James picked 10 more <n><n>6 more in all<n><n>Strawberry times the number of times is 17 + (10 -17)=17 + 20 =37<n><n>Number of times = Betty x James<n><n>Number times = 37<n><n>Answer - 12 more: Choice - 16<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Who is likely going in to a market? Choices:  A: stress B: food C: that you D: spending money E: walking<n><n>### Response:		Stress<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>1. Find the mean, mode and median of the data below:<n><n>2. What does it mean when a value in a set of data is an outlier?<n><n>3. Using the data, which of the means would be the best mean to use as a population mean?<n><n>4. Does a normal distribution always have a mean equal to the population mean?<n><n>5. In this activity, you will analyze data from different sources. Identify whether each distribution would be considered normally distributed. Remember: A normally distributed set of data should have a mean (of the entire set of data) equal to the population mean and a spread that follows the shape of a bell curve.<n><n>### Input<n>1.3<n>1.5<n>0.2<n>11.7<n>3.6<n>5.2<n><n>### Response<n>- Mean: 2.4<n>- Mode: 1<n>- Median: 1<n><n>### Instructiom:<n><n>- 1. Which of the graphs below represent a normal distribution? Explain your answer.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>### 1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you be able to hear a bassoon played in an unpleasing fashion? Choices:  A: orchestra B: baritone woodwind sound C: symphony D: play music E: high school band<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: orchestra<n><n>### Input:"A penny for your thoughts"<n><n>### Response:"I'm not that cheap."<n><n>### Input"What do you prefer, music or math? "<n><n>### Response"Music."<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where could a printer be used by thousands of people? Choices:  A: school B: home office C: people store D: print shop E: newspaper office<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A:<n><n>Schools need many printers because they need to print a lot of documents such as papers, booklets, handbooks, notebooks, and exam papers everyday.<n><n>#### B:<n><n>Home computer are equipped with printers so they can make printed documents at home.<n><n>#### C:<n><n>A people store sells a lot of stationary items and printers and they sell to the public who needs it.<n><n>#### D:<n><n>Print shop prints all the documents such as papers and books or handbooks for the community. <n><n>#### E:<n><n>Newspapers and magazines all the articles are printed in a newspaper office. <n><n>#### Answer:D and E<n><n>### Input : A store sells the following items: Toothpaste for $ 1.75 per toothpaste tube and toothbrushes for $7.50 per toothbrush. The store gives buy-one-get-one-free on these items. It has 18 tubes of toothpaste and 29 toothbrushes. How many tubes of tooth paste and toothbrush could it offer at BOF?<n><n>### Response :<n><n>1) 16 tubes of toothpastes<n><n>2) 20 toothbrushes<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>Since it is buy-one-get one free <n><n>for toothpastes:<n><n>buy 18 at BOF <n><n>18 ÷ 2 = 9 per set <n><n>get 9  (give it 10) <n><n>9 x $1.75 = $15.75 <n><n>so 18 BOF is: <n><n>18B x $1.72= $32.64<n><n>for toothbrushes:<n><n>buying 29 at full price<n><n>29 x $7.50 = $212.50<n><n>then getting 2 more so<n><n>20 x $7.85 = $157.00<n><n>so 29 full price is <n><n>29 x 2= 58 <n><n>58x $7.50= $425.00
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What could you add a line to? Choices:  A: bus stop B: graph C: post office D: grass E: play<n><n>### Response:		<n> <n>1. A: <n><n>2. B: <n><n>3. C:<n><n>4. D:<n><n>5. E:<n><n>### Input:"What else would you add?"<n><n>### Response "Add a line to add a bus stop or playground.<n>

Choices:  A: shake hands B: control events C: talk to each other D: think creatively E: dress themselves<n><n>### Response:		Choices: E: dress themselves <n><n>### Input 1:There are 4 people in class. They want to buy 3 hamburgers. How can they divde the money so that each person gets the exact same amount? CHOICES: A: The person who paid the most should get double the money paid by the other person. B: If the person who paid the most has more money in their wallet than the person who paid the least, the person who paid the highest should get 10 dollars more than the person who paid less. C: The person who paid for the most hamburgers should get twice the money paid for the other hamburgers. D: The person who had the most money in their wallet should get two times the hamburgers they bought. The person with the least amount of money should get half the hamburgers paid for by the other person.<n><n>### Response 1:Choices: B,C,D,E <n><n>### Instructions:<n>**Step 1: Ask the student to brainstorm 3 possible answers for each choice presented in the first part of this task**<n><n>### Instructor 1:A: The person who paid most (highest amount of money) should get double money paid for by the person who paid the lowest (the least amount of money). B: If the person on the top has more money in their pocket than the person on the bottom, then the person on top should get 10 bucks of more than the person on the ground. <n><n>### Student 1:A: Doubling the money who paid the least. B: Money on the top who is less in the pocket than the person on ground, get 10 buck more than the person who is on the ground. C: Half the person with the amount in their pocket, and double the person with less money. D: If the person who had the most got less money in the ground, he would take twice the amount of money.<n><n>### Step 2: If student has more answers select another student to continue. If student has the same answer the instructor can select another student or accept it. For the next student instructor will ask 2 more questions.<n><n>### Student2:A: The same person that bought the most should pay for those hamburgers. B

The spine and the hardware store are not damaged if you throw a rod.<n><n>### Input<n><n>A farmer sowed 110 acres of corn with 30 acres of that also sowed with corn seed. If the corn seed cost $0.90 a bushel, what was the cost of the corn seed?<n><n>### Response<n><n>The corn seed cost $368.00. <n><n>#### Steps: <n><n>1. First find out how many acres of corn the farmer sowed.<n><n>- a : $110 acres ÷ 30 acres = 3.7 acres<n><n>2. Next find out how many bushels of corn seed were used for each acre of corn. <n><n>- b : $0.90 bushel<n><n>- c : 3.7 acres * $0.90/bushel = $36.30<n>- $478.70 - $36.3 -=$442.40<n><n>## Instructions<n><n>Input:<n>If you are driving 45 miles per hour to pick up your friend 40 miles away and you turn off the radio and put on some music 80 minutes later, how many songs do you hear? Choices: 1: 40 minutes 2: 20 minutes 3: 80 minutes 4: 120 minutes 5: 2.5 songs<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Answer: 5 - 80 minutes<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>If you are driving at a speed of 45 mph for forty minutes then you will travel forty miles. <n><n>If then you turn the music on while you drive 60 minutes then you will travel fifty miles and you will travel one mile after you have turned the radio on. <n><n>Therefore if you travel one mile less than 50 miles then you will travel for 49.9 miles and travel for 1 hour. <n><n>There is an answer choice of 5/80 minutes which is twenty minutes, so this is not the correct answer choice. <n><n>Furthermore there

C: 18<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What are you hoping to achieve when talking to someone? Choices:  A: communicating with others B: hurt feelings C: dry mouth D: intimacy E: changing behavior<n><n>### Response:		A: communicating with others<n><n>### Explain:<n>In this case we would use A, because we are trying to communicate with someone else.<n>This is especially important in customer service roles.<n><n>### Input<n>Which of the following statements BEST completes the sentence?<n><n>### Choice: Which choice BEST completes the statement?<n><n>### A. I’ll have no trouble convincing you.<n>B. You’ll easily be changed.<n>C. It's hard to convince you.<n>D. It’s hard to change your mind.<n>E. It may be harder to convince you. <n><n>### Response<n>This problem includes information about which of the following best completes a sentence. <n>In this problem statement, the sentence states:<n>"It may be harder to convINCE YOU..."<n><n>Here are the choices: <n>A: I'll have no trouble convinCEING (sic) you. <n>The sentence can be corrected to read "It may be harder to convinCE YOU..."<n>B: You'll easily be changed. <n>The sentence cannot be corrected to read "You'll easily be changed."<n>C: It's hard to convinCE you. <n>The correct form is "It's hard to convincing YOU." <n>The sentence can stay the same.<n>D: It's hard TO convincingly  change your mind. <n>The sentence should be rephrasing with this choice: "It's hard TO convinCE your mind to change."<n>E: It may be HARDER to convinCE you.<n>The sentence is already grammatical, so no changes needed.<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input 2<n>You had breakfast 5.65 hours after eating last night. Then you ate dinner 13.55 hours after dinner last night. How much time passed between eating last night and dinner tonight?<n>Response:<n>Between eating last night and eating today a total of __.5__ hours has passed. The time to determine the answer cannot be calculated since it is missing.<n>Answer:<n>The input problem can be calculated by multiplying 1/2 of an hour. <n><n>## Other Resources<n>* [How To Take An Online Test?] (https://www.test-prepar
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If your watching television and accomplish nothing what have you done? Choices:  A: getting fat B: get fat C: typing words D: falling asleep E: wasted time<n><n>### Response:		Choice E<n>### Rationale:<n>Input: If your watching television and accomplish NOTHING what have you done? <n>Choices: A Getting fat B getting fat C typing words D falling asleep E wasted time<n><n>First you have to understand what watching television means is like you are in front of your television. <n>In this case you are sitting down and accomplish nothing, like watching a movie.<n><n>You have to think also, if you're accomplishing nothing, you have no action, so you have to answer with E. <n>The only choice you can't find the action accomplish is C.<n><n>### Input : A: getting fat B : get fat C: typing word D: falling asleep  E: wasted time <n><n>Answer : E<n>### Instruction : 50 percent of the children in a particular school attend art classes. Each class has 16 students in it. Choose the correct statement about these classes.<n>A. Each classes have children.<n>B. If two classes meet together the number of students is 32.<n>C. The number of children in two classes is 96.<n>D. There are 32 students in one class.<n>E. Each class has 8 children.<n><n>### Rationale : <n>It is given that there are 16 students in each classes, and there are 50% of children in a school attend art classes.<n><n>So, If there are 16 children in each classes. Then in one class there will be 16 x 1/2 = 8 children. This means there will be 8. children children in each Class.<n>From this statement we can conclude that, there are 16 x 50% = number of childs in each classes are 8.<n><n>### Task : <n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input: A: -C20 B: -A20<n>Output: 40<n>rationale:<n>A - C20 is negative so, C20 - A = A -C20<n>and (-X) + X = X + ( -X)<n>A - C2 +C20 = A + ( -C2+C20)<n>A - ( C2+C20 ) = A + C2<n>Then 16 - (20

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:In the middle of the day what will someone do because of being hungry? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: make bread C: eat in restaurant D: have lunch E: make bread<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>* Let us start by understanding that what hunger means is when the stomach has no food in it. Therefore people need to do something so that they can satisfy their hunger.<n><n>* When they want to eat something they usually have something from the kitchen, but sometimes they don’t have any food in the kitchen.<n><n>* The choices that they can choose are making BREAD or EAT THEIR LUNCH. There is no choice where they can eat in the restaurant because they do not go out, therefore they can’t be in a restaurant.<n><n>* In the options A – D, BREAKFAST is excluded because they are not having breakfast. Breakfast means it must be the first meal of the day.<n><n>* One way to satisfy their hunger is eating lunch or BREAD.<n><n>* EAT IN THE RESTAURANT is not an option because they can’t go out, so it is not allowed to eat outside.<n><n>* Another way that they can satisfy the hunger is cooking DINNER.

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where can peanut butter be stored? Choices:  A: container B: supermarket C: pantry D: sandwich E: jar<n><n>### Response:		 A: container<n><n>### Input and output for the task:<n><n>* Input:Where can flour be stored? Choices A: container B: cabinet C: fridge d: freezer<n>* Rationale:A container that holds flour is stored in the kitchen.<n><n>* Input: Where can cocoa powder be stored? Choices  A: container B : freezer C: cabinet D: fridge E: sandwich<n>* Answer: C<n>* Rationale: The sandwich should not make this decision, the fridge or freezer are for food that will last more than a few days to a few weeks, or will possibly become spoiled if not in the right environment. The cabinet may hold a variety of foods, but would not be able to store cocao powder indefinitely.<n><n>* Input  Q:Where can peanuts be stored? Choices : A: container B: pantry C: supermarket D: fridge E. freezer<n><n>* Rationale: A pantry or container can hold peanuts for a long time, even outside of any room where food goes. They are very low in fat, and long lasting, and not in danger of spoiling or going bad in the pantry.<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Two friends wanted to spend a quiet evening together, what did they go see? Your friend just told you that they can give you ride. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Jackson is a popular city name, but the one with a governor's office is where? Choices:  A: michigan B: wyoming C: mississippi D: tennessee E: mississippi<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>Answer:  Jackson, Mississippi<n><n>### Instuction:Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>### Input Choices A or B<n><n><n>### Demstration:<n>Input Choices Choice A or B<n><n>Answer: Either A or B<n><n>### Input<n>Jackson is a popular nick name, but the one in the governor's office is in Michigan.<n><n>Choice A or B<n>Choice A: Michigan<n>Choice B: Wyoming<n><n>### Demostration<n>Input Choices Choices A or B <n><n>Answer Either A or B<n>Answer: A and B<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration: <n>Input Choices:  Choice A or B:<n>Answers: Choices A Answer: B<n>Choice B Answer: C<n>Choice C Answer: A <n>Choice A or B: Choice A: Choice B:<n><n>Answer: B<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple- choice question.<n>Which of the following statements is correct when adding and multiplying integers using the "exchange" method? The sign of the larger integer is kept and a negative sign is added to the smaller integer. The negative sign of the larger integer stays the same, but the sign of the smaller integer is changed. 1) The sign of the larger and smaller integers are changed.<n>2) The sign of the smaller integer changes.<n>3) The sign of the negative integers changes.<n>Answer: 2<n><n><n><n># Data Manipulation<n><n>### Problem<n><n>### Insturction: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demosration: <n><n>Input: Which of the following commands lists all the records in the "Students" table? Choices: A: SELECT * FROM Students; B: SELECT * FROM Stud; C: SELECT * FROM Student<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Instution: <n><n>Answer the following multiple choice-question. Which of the following command lists all the records in "Students"-Table?<n><n><n>### Soloution<n><n>### Input : <n><n>Answer : A<n><n>### Demossration<n><n>### Input <n><n>### Demotions <n><n>### Input and Output<n><n>##
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The man wanted to take a bus, but all the chars were full of people doing what? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Though nearby, an apple from an apple tree where would be an imported product to the USA?
