Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What are you hoping to do when listening to an expert speak? Choices:  A: learning B: fatigue C: mercy D: empathy E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		In the context of education, it is a good thing that you as a student are not fatigued by the session, anxious about what the expert has to say or showing mercy to your expert because you want to appear compassionate for him or her. Learning new things from the learning sessions is the main goal. Thus, the choice you picked is the best because learning is the best thing to do in your life.<n><n>### Input<n>In your community, many people are homeless, with no shelter or food. <n><n>### Demand and Supply<n>This is the point in the lesson where you discuss how demand (and supply) affect prices.  <n><n>If many people in your community are homeless and hungry, <n><n>### Instructor Guidance<n>what will happen to the price of food?<n><n>### Demostration: <n>- The more food is in the community, the less expensive it will be for the homeless. <n>- The less food is in the community; the more expensive it will be for homeless people to get food.<n><n>### Choice: If many people in your community (the homeless population) is hungry, what will happen to the price or food? Choices: A Price will go up. B Price will go down.<n><n>### Demo:<n>- The more food there is in the community, there will be more people for a store to sell its products to. <n>- There will also be more stores to enter the market to sell food at different prices to people who need food badly.<n><n>### Answer: <n>- When a lot of people are hungry, the supply increases because each store is going to try to sell as much as possible. <n>- The demand (the number of people buying the food) increases because more people are going to stores to get food.<n>- So, the prices will go down because stores have more food so there aren't as many people fighting for it. <n>- The prices go down for the homeless to still eat.<n><n>### Comment:<n>- Food prices will go down because there will be more stores in the homeless community to sell to each of them individually. Since they need to eat, food prices won't stay the same and the demand will go up and the prices will go down for them. <n><n>## Demonstration: <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The snake was a cottonmouth.  It was an American, from where? Choices:  A: georgia B: tree C: nature D: under the rocks E: france<n><n>### Response:		Answer a<n>### Instructions: Choose the correct responses from the following choices.<n>### Explanation: The snake is from Georgia.<n>### Rationale: The snake is American.<n>### A) Georgia [B] Tree [C]Nature [D]Under the rocks [E] France<n>### Answer: A) Georgia<n>### Instructiona: Answer a question by completing the instruction.<n>### Rationales:<n>### Demonstaration:<n>### Instruction and Choice: Where did the snake live?<n>### Choices:<n>### A: georgia<n>### B: tree<n>### C:Nature<n>### D: under the rocks<n>### E: france<n>### Answer: <n>### Correct Answer:<n>### Rationale<n>### Instruction 1:Answer a by completing the instruction and selecting an option:<n>### Explantion:<n>Cottonmouth, American, and Georgia.<n><n>### Input:"Science is based more upon evidence rather than faith". Explain if you agree or disagree with this statement. Why? Be specific"<n>### Response:<n>Science and faith are very opposite. Science is based on logic and evidence whereas faith is based on one's belief. Science cannot be based on faith alone because science deals with evidence and proof. If only science dealt with faith it wouldn't be science anymore. Science is based on a lot of evidence and when faith comes into play it gets more complicated. Faith goes through a lot of doubts whereas science is very certain. Science is the only truth which cannot be doubted while faith is only a set of beliefs. For science to be based on faith it needs to not be science anymore. Science will require all your faith in it in order for it to work. For me I cannot have faith in something because I will have no proof and I always want proof. If I'm going to study a subject it is because I need proof or evidence.<n><n>### Rationale Be specific:<n><n>### Instrucctions: Write the correct answer to the following question.<n><n>## Rationales:<n><n>## Instructions: Choices:  a) 1.10- 43<n>## Explanation:<n>Rationales: 28.

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A person writes a check to a clerk, where does the clerk put them? A person writes a check, the clerk writes down where they are put on a check log. To get that check, the clerk will put it in the cash register or on the desk.<n><n>### Input:"This question is from 10 to 15."<n><n>### Response:"This question is from between 10 to 20 inclusive"<n><n>#### Rational: The answer that is being asked in this sentence from 10 to include 15. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is love when everyone keeps feeling it? Choices:  A: contagious B: wrong C: last forever D: painful E: blind<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Answer:E<n><n>## Rationale:<n>A) Love could be contagious - you can catch it, like the flu - but it is not. We are all able to chose who we love. We're able to know them and love them, and if your heart isn't in the right place, or they're just not the person for you, you could never catch them. For example, you could never catch your best guy friend.<n><n>B) Wrong? Love cannot happen if no one is in love. Is love unnatural? I think not.<n><n>C) Love cannot last forever - It's not practical. We will come and go, as we change jobs, homes, and more. Our hearts never stop, but eventually they will find love again. The same way you could never hold onto your very first puppy, to keep it as your pet for your entire life, you can't keep your first love for life. Love is always changing. (and I'm pretty sure animals don't 'last forever' either, unless you can't get a decent dog from an animal shelter anywhere in America - I'm not talking about the dogs you see when you first visit or take your parents to, because they likely won't be your forever dog. I mean, my brother had 2 dogs in his life, until they went to dog prisons when he couldn't afford to pay anymore).<n><n>D) Painful? We don't see love that may bring pain, if the individual doesn't care. The person must understand the pain could be caused by their love or choice. Love must be there, to do any harm.<n><n>E) Blind? Love is blind, right? We make poor decisions for love, we don't always have our eyes wide open. We don't have all the facts, we don't understand every decision the other person makes, or has made in their life so far. We love so strongly, that the heart can sometimes make up its own facts, and go forward, and make up for others faults.<n><n>### Input and answer the following two- part question by selecting the letters.<n><n>Which letter represents the answer that goes with each choice?<n><n>1. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Billy bounced the ball off the wall. She spent a total of $85.10 and received a discount for using her credit card. How much change did she receive?<n><n>We need to find the change she got. The cost of the items to find the change = 2.75 – 1.10. <n>The change she received = 2.70.<n><n>Answer: 2.70<n>Input: If a car travels 166 miles, will go 160 miles on a gallon of fuel?<n><n>### Input & Rationales: If a car travel 166 miles will go 166 miles on a gallon<n><n>Answer: yes<n><n>### Input:"Directions:  A rectangle's height is 130 feet plus twice its width.  The width and height measures are 58 feet and 50 feet.<n><n>#### Input and  Rational: The height is 138 + 2 x width = 138 +2 58 =155 50  =150<n>50+40 = 90 <n><n>#### Input and Rational: The height = 170 feet <n><n>### Answer:"Answer: 210 feet<n><n>### Input"Directions:  Rational: Choose all of the possible numbers in the <n>set:<n><n><n>A: 1 <n>B: 5<n>C: 15 <n>D: 9<n>E: 22 <n>F:  19<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:what do you do before going to party? Choices:  A: call 911 B: enjoy yourself C: get drunk D: having sex E: meet new people<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: D: having sex<n><n>What do you do before going  to party? Choices:(911 A, enjoy yourself B, get drunk C, having sex D, meeting new people E)<n><n>Option: D: having sex (This is correct because the party is not a boring topic, but it is not inappropriate, so the answer is D)<n><n># Multiple Choices<n><n>### Input:"I would have ate my favorite food, if I only had some money in my account", which option is the best completes the request. Choices  A:I will spend the money on my favorite food.   B:I will open a bank account.   C:I will work to obtain money in the account.  D:I will save the money for the future.<n><n>### Reply:<n><n>Input: D:I will save for future (correct answer)<n><n># Multi-Part Questions<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Which type of question has multiple parts?<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>Choose all that answer what type of question<n><n><question>  A:True or False   B:Fill in the Blank   C:Multiple Choice D:Multi-part Question<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Multiple choices questions <n>Multi-part questions<n>Fill in the Blank<n>True or False<n><n>Multiple choices questions<n>Multi-part Questions<n>Fill in the Blanks<n>True or False<n>Choose this type because it has 2 parts like this: True or False.<n><n>### Input<n>How many apples do you buy? (A) 2 (B)2(C)3 (d)6 <n>### Reply<n>Which is the best answer? <n><n>Input: A:2<n>Reply: A:2<n><n>### Instraction:<n>Choose all that apply.<n><n>### Demo<n><n>Choose what type is fill in the blank  <n><n>Input:  A:Fill in the Blanks   B:True or False   C:Multiple choice   D:Multi-part questions<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Fill in the blank<n>Multiple choice<n>True or False<n>Multi-part questions <n><n>Choose all what apply   (true or false, multiple choice, fill in the blank)<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The delivery man was delivering a whole crate of shampoo, they went through a lot of it at the what? Choices:  A: supermarket B: motel C: at hotel D: shampoo bottle E: hair salon<n><n>### Response:		Supermarket<n><n>### Output: The correct answer is supermarket. Let's look at the choices.<n><n>### A: supermarket<n><n>Supermarket is a place where people buy clothes, fruits, vegetables, meat, etc.<n><n>Shampoo is a product that can be found in the shampoo industry. Therefore, the delivery man was delivering shampoo to "a" supermarket. <n><n>### B: motel<n><n>Motel is like a hotel. However, motel has fewer services offered. Motels only provide places to sleep. Motels don't have restaurants or shops.<n><n>### C: at hotel<n><n>"at" means there is a hotel not far. The correct answer is not "at motel" but rather "at hotel". <n><n>### D: shampooo bottle<n><n>Shampooo bottle is a container used for storing shampoo.<n><n>### E: hair salon:<n><n>Hair salons provide services to the hair industry. They don't sell products, they just sell service.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:James didn't know what to do.  He felt that he'd ruin his relationship with Jen if he took it further, and he didn't want to do that.  At the same time,  He fight that pushing farther might do what to something good? Choices:  A: found B: destroy C: construct D: fix E: produce<n><n>### Response:		It must be "construct" or "build"<n><n><n>### Instructions: Select the response that most accurately completes the request and provides the correct rationale for each. <n>Rationales: Use the words from the instruction to complete the task.<n><n>### Response 1:<n>1. Choices: A: found  B: destroy<n>Rationale:  You are not constructing anything by found something. <n><n><n>### Response2:<n>1. Chooses: C: construct<n>2. Choose: D: fix<n><n>Rationale:You are fixing something when you construct it. <n><n><n>

Johnny wanted it to be over.  What might he choose to do? Choices:  A: control people B: settle everything C: buy food D: increase power E: kill bill<n><n>### Response:		<n>This may be difficult to answer without any context. I have created some additional questions to help answer this question.<n><n>1. Did Johnny say anything to bill?<n>2. What did bill say?<n><n>### Instructions:For the following question, pick the correct answer from the first, second, or third set of choices.<n>Input: The ________ are a species of bony fish in the ray-finned fish order. <n><n>### Demostration:<n>Rationales: <n><n>### Answer:<n>### Instrucions:For the following question pick the correct answer from a,b, or c.<n>Input: How did the fish get into the ocean? <n><n>### Rationale:<n>The ocean is a big body of water made up of salt water.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Instuction:For the followiing question,pick the correct choice from A B or C.<n>Input:The fish needs a place to stay, The fish needs to eat something, The fish needs to be cool. <n><n>The correct answer: C<n><n>###Demonistation:<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>### Answer
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What European country is famous for its potato industry? Choices:  A: idaho B: casserole C: new hampshire D: root cellar E: ireland<n><n>### Response:		<n>The country is C: Ireland.<n><n>### Input : What is the most expensive beef? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Input: What’s a number between $150 and $200?  Choices: 99, 199, 299 Answer: 299<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Your friend told you that x dollars is the price of an object, but he does not tell you what the price is. <n><n>Your friend asks how much one dollar is worth.  Your friend is using the first price to calculate the second. <n><n>When the first price is the last price, it means that the relationship is not commutative. <n><n>In simple terms, the statement that x dollars is the object’s price means the first price is not the object’s price. <n><n>How much one dollar is is the first price because the dollar has a known value. <n><n>So, the first price is the only number between the dollar’s value and the price of the object. <n><n>## Input:<n><n>What’s the difference between $27.75 and $33.25? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What do humans do when they want to reproduce? They use their bodies to make babies.<n><n>### Input : A  ball, a penlight, and a ruler measure 51 centimeters, 27 centimeters, and 25 centimeters. What is the total length of these objects?<n><n>### Response : 104 centimeters [Correct]<n>### Demostraton: <n>A ball has a volume of 51cm^3. The ball is 51/3 of a meter and since there are 100 centimeters in a meter so in reality the ball would only have the volume of 16.7cm^3<n><n>A penlight has a volume of 27cm^3. The penlight is 27/3 of a meter so in reality its volume is 7.53cm^3<n><n>The ruler is 25cm. Since there are 105cnetimetors to a yard so the length of the ruler is 22.33mm long.<n><n>After putting each object together you will find that the total length of the objects is 13.344cm.<n><n>### INPUT: Which 2 sides of a right triangle equal 34 cm in length?<n><n>	### ANSWER: 43cm and 52cm<n><n>### EXPLANATION:<n><n>Since we know that the sum of all three sides of a right triad equale 180 degrees, 34 is a divisor of 180, and therefore 34 can be divided by any number for that number, if that number is greater than 1, to equal a degree. Therefore the sum of opposite and concurant sides will equal 34, and that the adjacent side will equal 146, as shown below.<n><n>### EXAMPLE<n><n>### ANSWERS<n><n>### 					 28 cm  8 cm  42 cm<n>### EXPLATION:<n>

Choices:  A: injuries B: fatigue C: traffic jams D: tired E: accidents<n><n>### Response:		 Traffic jams and Accidents<n>Output: Input: 33 students and 250 pairs of socks were collected for the canned food drive. How many 50 centimetre long pairs of socks were bought for the homeless shelter? Choices:  Eighteen pairs F: One hundred thirty pairs G: Forty pairs of socks H: Nineteen and a half socks I: Ninety five pairs J: Sixty paired socks <n><n>### Response Let's first add 250 together and so does 30 + 33 The next step is we will need to add 250 pairs and 33 pairs together. Which means we will have 283 pairs. The next step is we have to divide by 2 (since they gave 283 pairs and we will need socks for 25 people because 30 people and 25 people were involved in the project) which gives us 41 and a half pairs The next step is we take 41 and a quarter and divide it by 50 (since 50 is the length and 41 and a fourth is 41.25) and then multiply 41.20556 by 0.25. This gives you 9.7672 pairs of 50 centimetres socks!<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where is a ferret getting lots of attention likely to be found? Choices:  A: trouser leg B: sick bay C: own home D: petting zoo E: mother's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions<n>Answers the question following each question.<n><n>## Input:Where is a hungry baby getting the most food likely to be found? <n><n>### Answer:<n>1)<n>trouser leg<n>or if there is a mom around,<n>b)<n>mother's breast<n>2)<n>petting zoo<n>or if there is another ferret around,<n>c)<n>the ferret's cage<n>3)<n>petting zoo <n>or mom's hair<n><n>4)<n>cage (unless mom is around)<n>or if mom is around,<n>d)<n>mom's hair or breast<n>5)<n>petting zoo (unless mom is around to feed baby first)<n>or mom's breast (only if she is around to feed the baby)<n>or if mom's breast isn't around,<n>b) <n>mom's pocket or trouser leg<n>6)<n>c) petting zoo (unless mom's breast is available)<n><n>## Input:<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Blah blah<n><n>### BLAH BLAH blah<n><n><n><n>## Input:What can a teacher do to make it likely that a student will be a good classmate? Choices: <n><n>### A: allow the student to talk out loud <n><n>### B: allow the student to have a turn at the board <n><n>### C: choose the student to answer questions <n><n>### D: allow the student to help set the seating chart <n><n>### E: choose the student's seat in the class if they have not been given one <n><n>### F: let the student know how they can help and when <n><n>### Talking loudly<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The animals weren't good at swimming, so it was hard for them to do what? Choices:  A: pass water B: bathe C: listen to each other D: feel pleasure E: reproduce asexually<n><n>### Response:		The animals weren't able to bathe.<n><n>### Reason: The question involves finding which of the given choices the animals weren't doing.<n><n>### Explanation: The animals weren’t good at swimming and therefore were not able to bathe, listen to each other, feel pleasure, or reproduce asexually.<n><n>Rationales: the answer choices are listed in the first part of the question and the part of the question about the animals' ability is in the second half.<n><n>### Input:"Isaac asked a friend a question and his friend thought the question was interesting. In response, Isaac’s friend asked Isaac a question"<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>###Input:  Isaac: "When did the dinosaurs go extinct?" Friend: "32 million years ago"<n><n>###Output:<n>Rationales:<n><n>###Explanation:<n><n>Rationales:"When did the dinosaur go extinct?" and "How old is Isaac's friend".<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The disease was spreading fast, so what were researchers desperately seeking? Choices:  A: cause spots on leaf B: healthy C: wellness D: ball stopped E: cure<n><n>### Response:		4.C <n><n>### Explain:C is correct because spots on the leaf are the symptoms of the disease. The symptoms of the disease is a result of what the disease is doing at the cellular level.<n><n>### Sources:1. https://www.google.com/search?q=what+are+some+symptoms+of+sickness&oq=what+are&aqs=chrome.0.69i59j69i57j0l2j69i60j69i61j0.7109j1j9&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8 <n>2. https://www.merck.com/mmhe/sec19/ch079/ch07<n><n>### Instructions:Below, you'll find a set of two statements marked as (#1), (#2), and so on and (#1), (2)…. Use common sense to determine if statement #1 and #2 is a pair or a group <n><n>### Input example:Example:<n><n>### 1. The cat is sitting on the rug.<n>### 2. The chair is on the wall.<n><n>### Response example:<n><n>### Yes/No<n>### 1, 2  Yes, 1 is a pair <n>### Yes/Yes<n>### 1 yes, 2 yes <n>### No/No<n>### Either 1 is false and 2 is true <n><n>### Instructed to respond that the statements are a group, give an example that indicates this <n><n>### <n><n>### Screenshots:<n><n>![](https://github.com/jovianal/AlgoLogic/blob/master/Images/2022-02-07-algorithm-question-33-image2.jpg)<n>![](https://zenodo.org/badge/221187748.jpg)<n><n>

Choices:  A: telephone network B: freeway C: company D: wall E: airport<n><n>### Response:		D: Wall<n><n>### Instructions:What is the correct answer?<n>### Demonstation<n><n><n><n>##### 600<n><n>Input:<n><n>1. Write a sentence describing a task in which you are given an instruction to find the length and width of a room.<n><n>The instruction given to me was to find the length and the width of a room. Length and width are both linear measures of the quantity of distance. A room is a room that is meant to be used such as a toilet room or a room for sleeping that is usually furnished with a bed. By this time we learned to find the area of a room by multiplying the length by the width. You can also find the perimeter by adding the linear measures of the four walls around a room.<n><n>2. Write a sentence that describes a different type of instruction than the one you used to solve your problem.<n><n>The different type of instruction is an instruction that a student will have to follow when he is a student.<n><n>3. Write a sentence that includes a realistic task involving a linear measure that might be given to students in a mathematics class. <n><n>Realistically, students in a mathematics class will receive an instruction that involves a linear measure. For example, in the class of geometry they might be asked how long is one side of a square, they might be asked if the square will fit on a line drawn on the wall and so on.<n><n>4. Write a sentence that explains why your work as a tutor may prove useful as an educational resource for other math teachers.<n><n>Using my work as a tutor to other teachers is helpful because you would be able to have a better knowledge of what you are doing as a teacher. This is helpful because you will be aware of what you are doing and what are the areas that need improvement from you as a teacher.<n><n><n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Jan went to the auditorium and listened to the speech. Where might he be? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The wheel was loose, and threatened to fall off when they were what? Choices:  A: footloose B: sailing C: fast D: tighten E: bind<n><n>### Response:		Sailing<n>Input:When they were sailing, the wheel was loose, and could fall off.<n><n>Input: You can make 13/5 ounces from each chicken egg.<n><n>Input:You can use 2 chicken eggs to give 4/5 cups of milk.<n><n>Input:Mary had 8/9 cups of milk to cook her cereal. <n><n>Input:1. You have 3 apples and 2 oranges. You have to make 2 apples + 1 orange and 3 apples + 1 oranges. The final amount after the addition of the 3 apples and the 2 oranges is? Choices:  2. A:2 apples and 1 orange    B: 3 apples and  2 oranges    C: 1 apple and  3 oranges   D: 2 apples and  3 oranges  E:4 apples and   1 oranges F: 1 apple and 5oranges<n><n>### Response<n>1. 2 apples and 3 oranges<n>2. 1 apple and 1 orange <n>3. 1 apple and  4 oranges<n>4. 4 apples and 1 oranges<n><n> 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The teams were evenly matched when competing against one another, what did spectators want to find out? Choices:  A: envy B: resentment C: winning or losing D: one winner E: two winners<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is "E". <n>The teams were evenly to compete against one another so if spectator wanted to find out wether there is no winner is the second option, A or B.<n>The second answer to this question is D because when there are two teams that have an even number each, a spectator is expected to be excited because there will be two winners.<n>In other words, Spectator will enjoy watching 2 teams that have the same number of players and compete against each other because when teams have the same number that means there are two winners of the competition.<n>Answer: E.<n>

Choices:  A: city B: strip mall C: clerk D: neighborhood E: rooster<n><n>### Response:		There could be a city, a strip mall, a clerk, a neighborhood, or a rooster in a beauty salon.<n><n>### Rationale: A beauty salon is an establishment that offers beauty services. A city is a complex of people and buildings that make up a large urban area. A strip mall is a group of small shops and stores that sell goods and services arranged in one or two floors. A clerk is an employee who has authority to issue goods and services to customers. A neighborhood is a group of houses, blocks, land, and roads in a particular area. A rooster is a male chicken with a comb, crow, and a tail.<n><n>### Input The grocery store had 8 cartons of yogurt and sold 10 cartons.<n>### Rationale A grocery store is an establishment for the selling and buying of foodstuffs. <n>8 (cartons of yogurt) + 10 (cartons of yougurt sold) = 18 cartons of yougurt.<n><n>### Answer Question: How many of the cartons of yougur did the store sell?<n><n>### Input<n>Input: How long did it take for David to ride his cycle from home to school? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What feeling might propel one to instituting civil action? Choices:  A: complications B: tiredness C: anger D: trial E: court case<n><n>### Response:		<n>* B<n><n>### Input:: <n>Gordon is trying to make 3,645,600 for a video game store, but will only accept checks from his account at The Big Bank. 487.59 of his account remains, but The Big Bank does not charge overdraft fees for less than 5,063, because they are still too busy to give him a good rate. If he deposits $3,000 into his account right away, he does not qualify for overdraft protection because he has 487.64 more remaining after deposit. <n><n>To save 5,065 over two weeks, Gordon must take out at least $9,756, he must take out no more than 1,352, and his payment must be 4,050. How much money does Gordon have to borrow? <n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>First, Gordon wants to save money for his vacation to Italy. He wants to make 3900,000 for his vacation in 5 months. <n><n>1723 months x $39000000=970,954,00<n><n>Next, Gordon is going to put $3000 in his bank account today because he will need the money. <n><n>The first problem in the question is to find out how much money Gordon needs to save for his vacation. <n><n>To find this out, Gordon needs to divide $4050 which is the amount of pay for every two weeks by $3900, which is the amount of money he needs for every two weeks to pay the $4050. <n>The result is $4050/3900=3900<n><n>Therefore, the amount of money Gordon needs for every two weeks is $3900. <n><n>The next problem to solve is to find out how many months it will take<n><n>To find this answer,<n><n>$3900 / 5 = $780<n><n>Since Gordon is going to put in $3,00,00, we need to subtract $3000 from $3900 and get $3600.<n><n>The last problem to solve is how

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where can you buy a fishing rod? Choices:  A: furniture store B: fishing camp C: hardware store D: sporting goods store E: engine<n><n>### Response:		E    <n>Fishing rods are sold at sporting goods stores or fishing camps.Fishing rods are not sold in furniture stores, hardware stores, or engine part stores. <n><n>Rationales: Fishing rods are sold in a sporting goods store or a fishing camp.<n><n>### Input : The cost of gas is $2.25 per gallon and it take 16 gallons to fill up a gas tank of a Honda Civic. If the vehicle owner can fill up a gas tank half as much as it takes to fill up a gas tanks, what amount of gas could be saved annually?<n><n>### Response : 11.96 gallons would be saved<n><n>### Rationales: Using the relationship between 16 and 8 gallons, we can fill up half as much (8) as it takes to fill an entire tank (16).<n>We start with the equation: 16 / 16 = x<n><n>Saving half would mean finding the following equation: x * 2 = (1/2) 16<n><n>After solving for x the final equation is: 8 = (1/2)(16)<n><n>Then, all we have to do is plug in the information about Honda Civics and we have x = 17, and we can then find out how much gas could be saved annuallly by multiplying 8 gallons by 12. <n><n>17 x 12 = 208 <n><n>### Input How are mangoes like water? Choices: A: they fall from the tree B: they ripen in summer C: they are delicious D: they are expensive E: they are grown in hot climates F: they have a fibrous texture<n>G: they are usually yellow<n>H: they both make your skin glow.<n><n>### Response D: They are expensive<n><n>### Rationale:All the choices except for D and H describe attributes the mangoes have in common.<n><n>### Difference in the way they ripen<n><n>### Similar way they're used<n><n>### Similar textures and colors<n><n>### Similar time of year they are available<n><n>### Similar place where they are grown<n><n>### Similar color they are <n><n>We can

They are not the best answers to what the family was doing because they only describe how people are playing cards and how much money they are loosing or gaining. Choice D is a vague answer meaning the family was playing the card for their own entertainment. Choice E is the strongest and best answer to this question because the correct answer is to describe exactly what the family is being entertained by doing.<n>Chosen Answer: This is an activity to pass time.<n>

Choices:  A: misery B: sadness C: bad time D: sorrow E: play time<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The correct answer is B. This is the only answer that matches the phrase 'but DESPITE that this was a'. The other choices begin with sadness or something that makes someone sad or something that may bring sadness to the woman. The phrase "but despite that this was a" already states it as a happy time so the next phrase "what is a misery" does not make sense in the context.  <n><n><n><n><n><n>![alt text](https://res.cloudinary.com/sandiegocodecamp/image/upload/e240c5ef_0.png)

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:John is studying animals.   What is one of the many things he has to watch them doing? Choices:  A: bathe B: bite C: die of cancer D: obesity E: copulate<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input<n>For every 10 sticks of wood you burn, you get $5 from your parents. Every time you pick up trash in the neighborhood, you get $1.<n>If you pick up 100 pieces of rubbish and burn 20 sticks of wood in a week, how much money do you get from picking up trash?<n><n>### Response<n>400<n><n>### For every 120 cans you recycle you receive $0.25, and for every 25 pounds of newspapers you recycle you receive (3)^(5)dollars. If your family collected one-sixth of a ton of newspapers and a half a ton of cans, how many dollars did your family earn in all?<n><n>### For each question there will be an instruction that describes a problem or task. Write a response<n>that appropriately completes the instruction by answering the question.<n>    <n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple-choice questions. There may be one or<n>more parts to each question. Answer each part independently in the space provided.<n>    <n>       1.Input: John is studying animals. What is one of the things he has to<n>watch them doing? Choices (a) Bathe, (b) Bite, (c) Die of cancer, (d)<n>Obesity, and (e) Copulate. What is the correct choice?<n>    <n>      Rationale: To answer a multiple-choice question, read the question<n>      carefully and look for the appropriate answer, usually by eliminating<n>      incorrect choices. The answer we need is E) Copulate.<n>       <n>     Instructions: Answer each question in the space provided after the<n>question.      <n><n> <n>

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What do only some types of police do? All types of police arm themselves because when they go to a crime they always take some sort of weapon. Therefore, the answer is 16 cm.<n><n>#### Response 2:<n><n>If the answers were 4, it would make a square. If the answers were anything else, it would not make it a square. Therefore, it is a square.<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Choices:  A: perfume B: air C: fountain D: swamp E: puddle<n><n>### Response:		The answer is E, Puddle. If you have ever been in a public restroom and used the dispenser on the wall for the hand sanitizer, chances are it smells like a fountain. Maybe the water is slightly colder, or maybe there is something in the water that is unpleasant, but whatever it is, it's not worth the risk of getting sick by touching something that you don't know the origins of.<n><n>---<n><n>#### HackerEarth's solution -<n><n>In order to answer this question, you need to understand what question writer is looking for:<n><n>**He'd rather spray herself with water, rather than what?**<n><n>Now that the question is clear, we can narrow down the choices to B, C and D.<n><n>- I am no expert on perfumes, but let's assume that if her husband likes the smell of perfumes, and her boyfriend prefers to smell fruits as opposed to smelly perfumes, that leaves only 2 choices: air or water. This question is about a woman and the word 'herself' indicates that we should think about only female-related options. This is where D (water) seems to better than B (air).<n><n>- To me, swamp and puddle sound different, which means that B or D is most likely right.<n><n>- Now, B (air) can be discarded because the only things we were asked to eliminate were air and water.<n><n>Therefore, most likely answer is given by E (puddle).<n><n>![](https://i.imgur.com/35Rp6R6.png)<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. (for instance, if the news papers are dirty it will cost $5.0, if they’re clean they’ll cost$3.0). The family recycled 116 pounds or 58 gallons of news papers. (The news papers cost $5.8 and $3.9).
