Choices:  A: loss of consciousness B: relaxation C: snoring D: dreaming E: talking<n><n>### Response:		C<n>### Justification: <n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Instructions<n>-In each of the following exercises, you will be asked to analyze a mathematical system model, solve the model, and write the rationale for your solution. These are the same items that were on the exam. Use the data in each problem as given and be sure that all assumptions made are clearly justified.<n><n>### Exam Preparation Task<n><n><n>### Input Data<n><n>| Number | Description |<n>| --- | --- |<n>| \(t\) | Time in years |<n>| \([t]\ne0\) | \(t\) > 0 |<n>| \([c(t) = 0 ]\) | \(c(t) > 0\) |<n>| \[T\] | Lifetime in years |<n>| \[p_{t}\left( T_{i } ^{0}\right)\] | Probability at time \(t\) that person \(i\) lives until they reach age \(T_{i}\) at time \(t\) |<n>| \[p_t\left(j\right)\] | Proability that the person dies in year \(t\) |<n><n>### Instuctions<n><n>### Exercise 1: Probability of Survival Exact<n>When modeling human longevity, it is common to model the life table of people in a population using a discrete-time Markov chain. In such a model, when it is time for a person to die (and thus make the next transition state), his or her age at the time of death is a random variable that has no upper bound. We then consider events that involve a person living from some age \(t\) up until some age \(T_i^0\). The probability mass that this event takes on is \(p_{t}(T_i^0)\). The following equation models a person's probability of survival from a given age \(t\).<n><n>\(p_{t}(\tau ) = \left(1-p_{t}(A_{n} ))\right)^{T_{n}^{0}}\)<n><n>where \(A_n\) is the state where the person dies at age \(n\). The person dies in \(A_{n}\) if they live to age \(n\) and are \(1\) at age \(n\),
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of a village? Choices:  A: rural area B: africa C: ohio D: big city E: tribe<n><n>### Response:

They are: the surface of the earth, the house, the charming place, and the space shuttle. This is because a house is made up of many rooms, each room is occupied. When a person enters a room and leaves, the air in that room is replaced. This is also the case with a household, and when everyone is home at once, there are many people occupying the rooms all at once, and this makes for many people breathing and passing on the air.<n><n>This is the reason why one person can inhale a large quantity of air from another person, for example at a house. Likewise for the surface, where many people occupy the space and also breathe, and exchange the air. Lastly, the charming place in the same way. But not only houses, but also the places where people congregate often is where we find the same thing happening. For example, many people stand and/or sit on the train, and each time the entrance is opened and people enter the compartment, the air is replaced with new air. The student must replace the missing words and punctuation to accurately create the question.<n><n>The scaffold for the instructions is below:<n><n>Please fill in the blank spaces.<n><n>The student must create a full question of his own and not copy/paste the given answer.<n><n>## Guides<n>### What is a guide?<n><n>Guide is the most basic and simple example of Scaffolds, which shows students
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What would someone wear to protect themselves from a cannon? Choices:  A: ungulate B: bomber C: body armor D: tank E: hat<n><n>### Response:		A: Ungulate<n><n>### Rationales: What kind of person would use a tank to protect themselves from the cannon? <n><n>An ungulate uses hooves instead of paws and they are mainly running animals. <n><n>They use hooves instead of hoses.<n><n>The answer to the question What would someone wear to protect them self from the cannon, was A: Ungulate<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where does someone not happy to take their car? Choices:  A: down a river B: city C: repair shop D: parking lot E: neighbor's house<n><n>### Response:		C: repair shop<n><n>### Input (Ski Resort):<n>A ski resort offers a season ski pass, half-day pass or daily pass.<n>A season ski pass costs $325.<n>A half-day pass is $35 for ages 14 and under, $45 for ages 15 to 69, and $40 for ages 70 and up.<n>A daily pass is $45 for ages, 14 and under $50 for ages 15 and up.<n>Lily enjoys skiing and is planning on going to a ski resort five times. She is 70 years old, which means she is an adult. A season ski pass costs $42.50 more than all daily passes combined. Is she most likely to buy:<n>A) a season pass<n>B) half-day passes<n>C) daily passes<n>D) none of the above<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the question.<n><n>## 2. How Does Ms. White's Dog Make Her Feel When She Is Sleeping?<n><n>"<n>It's just like I have a little baby with me! He loves to curl up on my chest when I am sleeping and paw at my face. When he has to pee, he makes that "ny, ny, ny" sound and then waits for me to get up. The other day, he tried to walk with me while I was watering some flowers. When I picked him up and hugged him, he purred... " <n><n>Read the passage and determine how Ms. White' s dog **makes Ms. White feel when she is sleeping.**<n><n>### Input<n>" <n>It's just liiiike I havea littlere babay witn meee... He loves to cuurrw upp on my chest when i am sleepinnng and paw at my fayce. Wnen he has toe pee, he makes dat "ny, ny, iy" sonnd annd then wate for meee toget upp. Thtae othr daye, he trerri dto walkee yyhile i was wratering ssome frwloweers. When i picked him upp ahd hugedddd him, he purred..." <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:To gain her trust the real estate agent was very polite, delightful and all around what? Choices:  A: manipulate B: charming C: deceive D: exaggerate E: incompetent<n><n>### Response:		Her real estate is manipulating for trust (not to gain trust).<n><n><n>### Input<n>- Which is the best way to increase the number of donations to a charity? <n>1. Holding a sale; 2. Hold a race; 3. Holding a bake sale; 4. Holding a concert; 5. Selling candy bars; 6. Holding an art show. <n><n>### Demnstration<n>#### Tasks:<n>- How many times can you multiply $3 in the same way?<n><n>Multiply the given amount by $3 as many time as you want. <n><n>- If you were to increase the sales amount by 20%, what would the sales amount have to be to have a sale total of $950?<n><n>To increase the sales amount by the given percent amount, multiply the sales amount (before the percent amount increase) by 1 + amount by which to increase the amount by percent.<n><n>$950 = ($950 × 1 + 20%)<n><n>### How to solve the tasks<n>- If you were t increase an amount by a percent amount, first multiply the amount by the percent amount (e.g if you wanted to increase $300 by 30%, multiply $300 by $\frac{3}{10}$). <n><n>Then after multiplying the amount by the percent increase, add $1 for every time you multiplied the amount by the percent.<n><n>- If you wanted to increase the amount raised by 20%, multiply the amount raised (before the percent increase) to give you the amount raised after the percent increase.<n><n>For the second task, $950 is raised from the sale of 1785 cans. The task instructor wants to increase the sales amount to $950 but the amount is multiplied by 0.20.<n><n><n>First, he/she has to multiply $950 with $\frac{3}{20}$.<n><n>$9550 =  950 × 9 + 1785 × $\frac{3}{5}<n><n>The task instructor has to increase the amount of cans per sale and multiply 9550 by $\frac{17}{20}$.<n>$955 = 9550 ×

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What corner areas have lots of windows? C is 1 pint - 1/2 cup, which is 0.5 pints - not 1/2 pint.<n><n>### Note for the next one:<n>Make sure to include the unit in your answer.<n><n>### Question: You make homemade juices after meals. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A person would carry a large netted drawstring bag to what sort of place? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Why would I want to be exercising? Choices:  A: fatigue B: relaxation C: tiredness D: muscle weakness E: losing weight<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions: How many cans of pop should she buy?<n><n><n>### Demostration:Input: You have $6 and you can either buy 3 boxes of frosted pop tarts or 2.5 boxes of plain pop tarts.How many pop tarts should you buy?<n>RationalesYou must buy at least 3 boxes to have enough pop tarts. <n>Otherwise, there is no solution that does not involve purchasing frosted pop tarts as a solution. The answer could be $0 or $12 (for buying 3 boxes) as long as at least 3 boxes are purchased.$6 can be spent on 2.5 boxes, or $2.5 each for 2.5 boxes. This solution should be rejected if $6 cannot buy at least 3.5 boxes because the other boxes should have been purchased in order to have a reasonable amount of pop tarts. 7 boxes of pop tarts for a total of $18 cannot be purchased because $6 would not be enough to purchase 3 boxes. To arrive at 7, we have to multiply by 3/2 because 3 boxes would have to be purchased in order to have 7.<n><n>Input: How much money did it cost to rent a car?<n><n>Rationales: One reason why an answer was chosen is because it has the smallest value out of the choices. One box has enough pop tarts for a reasonable amount, so that answer was picked. <n><n><n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The wind tore off the shingles, what was the wind like? Choices:  A: dry hair B: spreading C: blowing hard D: change direction E: wave wheat<n><n>### Response:		I think that the wind was blowing hard, because the wind was tearing off the shingles from the house.<n><n>### Justification: The words wind and strong are describing that the wind is blowing with a lot of force.<n><n>### Input<n><n>The wind tore off some shingles of the roof of my grandma's house. She has been trying to fix it all afternoon, but the wind is strong. And so are the shingles.<n><n>### Response<n><n>The wind was blowing really hard.<n><n>#### Justification<n><n>The wind was really strong, it was going fast and really wild like. The last thing that tells me that it was wind was the strong shingles, they were really strong. This was blowing hard.<n><n>### Expert Commentary: <n><n>This task has clear, precise writing requirements. The language used in the instruction helps us understand what is being asked in the task. The explanation provided at the bottom of the question is a good guide for writing appropriate responses. Notice that the explanation states that the solution must be written in the form of a question. This means that the response must ask a question. The use of the word "must" provides clarity about the requirement.<n><n>### Review and Evaluate Students' Work <n><n>When reviewing students' writing, you should look for:<n><n>  * An appropriate verb. <n>  * A question word. <n>  * An appropriate number of words. <n>  * Appropriate use of and punctuation. <n>  * Correct capitalization and spelling.<n><n>If there are areas for improvement, have students identify them and discuss how to correct them with a peer or teacher.<n><n><n>### Tips for Review<n><n>If you need to help students with their writing, you should first identify the types of errors students made.<n><n><n>## Supporting Ideas<n><n>We can identify students learning needs easily with the use of Supporting Idea, which is in the body of a writing task. This strategy will help writers to organize their ideas and improve the logicality of their writing. This strategy also allows the writer to develop more sophisticated vocabulary.<n><n>The supporting ideas are phrases, sentences and main ideas that will be used to support the central idea. The supporting ideas should be used to enhance the main ideas. They

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Ice fishing can be done surprisingly far out most winters on what greatest of the Michigan's greats? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:If there is a stale smell in the air coming from the kitchen, what should one check for the source of the smell? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Collections of atoms called molecules make up everything you can hold in your what? Choices:  A: atom B: anything C: air D: feet E: hands<n><n>### Response:		Correct response is A)Atom. We have the two subatomic particles neutron, proton and electron. What you see is actually the electron, but the neutral atom is composed of all these three particles.<n><n>#### Response 1: Incorrect response. The correct response is Atom<n><n>#### Response 2: Incorrect response. A, B, C, D, and E are all incorrect responses.<n><n># Question 12April 25th<n>### Demonstation:<n><n>In one particular set of digits from 1 to 9, which two digits are used more than once?<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>$2, 5, 7, 9$ are used more than once.<n>### Answer:<n>**2, 5, and 7** are used more times than the others.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>First, find the elements that are more than once. <n>Second, count the elements that are more, and then subtract it from 1 to 8. The answer is **2, 5 and 7**.<n><n>### Input 12a:<n>Write a math expression to replace the question marks below. Expressions containing more than 2 question marks or using the same term more than once are NOT correct.<n>The sum of two numbers is 36. If 5 is subtracted from each number, what is the result?<n>Answer 12e: <n>```<n>Sum of 2 numbers = 36<n>(a + b) – 5 <n>```<n><n>### Input12b:<n>Write a math expresion to replace the question marks. Expressions containing more then 2 question marks or contain more then one term more then once are NOT correct. <n>The sum of two different prime numbers is 91. If 10 is added to each prime number, what are the numbers?<n>Answer: 15 + 23 = 38<n> <n>### Input13a <n><n>```<n><n>Write a math expression that replaces the following question marks. Expressions using more than 5 question marks, or containing more than 5 terms, are not correct.<n><n>The product of three prime numbers is 146. If 15 is added to the first number and 23 is subtracted from the second number, what are the three prime

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What do horses do to get energy? Choices:  A: eat grass B: play C: kept in stables D: dominated E: drink coffee<n><n>### Response:		Choice D.<n>>I'll just explain the process of the brain instead of just typing it, because that would make it way too boring for the rest of you students in this class.<n><n>### Input;<n>Diana decided to create a table to organize her data.<n>Each row (i.e., entry) represents a single unit of recycling materials. <n>Each column (i.e., data item) measures a single attribute, <n>and each value is a count for a certain column.<n><n>|Recycling material|# of units|<n>|:---:|:---:|<n>|Newspaper|14.5|<n>|Laminated paper |13|<n>|Aluminium cans|10.5|<n>|Plastics | 12.5 |<n>|Other (i.e., glass, steel, or carton)  | 18|<n><n>### Response;<n>Answer: (14.5 + 13 + 10.5+ 12.5 + 18) <n>>I'll try my best to explain this problem, just in case there are students that are not able to understand this problem.<n><n>### Your task is to find the sum of all data items.<n><n>### To find the sum of all the data items, we must add all the numerical values of each data item. <n><n>### First, we determine the total number of newspaper, laminated paper, aluminium cans, plastics, and other.<n><n>### newspaper = 14.5<n>laminated paper = 13<n>aluminium cans = 10.5<n>plastics = 12.5<n>glass, steel, or cartons = 18<n><n>### Then, we sum up all the numbers of each data item together to find the sum for each data item.<n><n>### Total newspaper = 14 (for 14.5)<n>laminated paper  = 13 (for 13)<n>aluminium can = 10. (for 10.5)<n>plastics =12. (for 12.5)<n>glass, steel, cartons = 14. (for 18)<n><n>### Finally,

This video explains how to answer the above question. <n>### Instruction(2):<n>Directions:<n><n>### Demostration<n><n><n>Rationales:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>You are given a table of numbers and are asked to answer the following question: If the product is $43,456, what is the value of a?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>To solve for the value of a, we will need to determine how to get from the table to the problem statement.<n><n>Starting with 12(2)10(a)<n>We simplify and subtract:<n><n>Subtract 12:<n><n>$12(2)-12=10(a)-12$<n><n>$b=10-12=-2$<n><n>Next we subtract $10a$:<n><n>$a=10a-10$<n><n>$a=-10$<n><n>Rearrange and simplify, giving: $\frac{-10}{-2}=50$<n><n>Multiply both sides by -2 to get:<n><n>$-10\times 100=-$<n><n>$=2000\mbox{ } (Ans)$<n><n>Answer: $2000$<n><n>### Instructin(3):<n>Write a response that appropriately answers the question.<n>*If it is 23°, what is the Celsius equivalent?<n><n>### Demontation:<n>If it is 29 degrees celsius, what is the Fahrenheit equivalent.<n><n><n><n>

Choices A, B, C, and D are not valid.<n><n><n>### Input:"Which option is the best choice?" Choices:  A.  They should not go to the party B.  They should go to the party C.  They should talk to their parents first D.  They should decide together E.  They should tell the other kid not to come to the party <n><n>### Response:"They should not go to theparty".  This is a wrong choice.  They should talk about the party first and then they decide together who is going to the party.  All the other options are what the kids should do, but not necessarily answer the question.  Choices B, C, and E need to be eliminated.  Choice D is a good choice, but the kids can also answer this directly.<n><n>### Input:(1, 3, 15) + (1, 1, 2) = 26<n><n>### Response:(1, 1, -2) + (3, 2, -6) = -19<n><n>### Input:-120 % 12 = -10<n><n>### Response:-120 % -12 = -1 12 % -12 = 1 <n><n>### Input (a, b,c, d, e, f, g) = (2,4,3,8,1,0,2)<n><n>### Response 243 g f h i (a,b, c, d, e, f, g) = 1<n><n>### Instructions:Find all the values for which the expression is true. <n><n>### Explanation:The expression 4 -2n + n is true when n = 2.  In general, we have 5a - 2n + n = b and b = 5a -n = 3 when n = 1 and b = 5 -n = -2 when n = -1. Your collection is listed below. What type of geology will you use to study these rocks? Choices: A: The Geochemistry of Metals B: The Geology of Volcanoes C: The Geology of Minerals D: The Geology of Rock Types<n><n>### Answer   :  Choice: C<n><n>### Instructor:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>##Instruction 1:Answer the question.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What is a convenient place for a bus station? Choices:  A: maps B: street C: catch bus D: city centre E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n>A B C A B D B C D E B A E B B E<n><n>B B B A D B D B B D A B B B D <n><n>or B A E B E D C B E D B B D C E <n><n>1. Choices: A C E D B B A E C D A<n>2. Choices: A B C D<n>3. Choices: A E B B C B A<n>4. Choices: A D B B C B E<n>5. Choices: B A E B C E B D<n><n>### Solution:<n>C: For convenience, I will use both map and bus station because not every place has convenience store or a bus station.<n>A street is where street light is available but I can't drive easily.<n>Catch buses is in bus station.<n>City centre is where I can't see buildings or place to hang out.<n>School is a place where people have a good nightmare or a good day<n><n>### The answer doesn't come out as it says.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would you put an account book if you are leaving and do not need to bring it with you? Choices:  A: kept at accountant B: purse C: desk drawer D: bank E: keeping track of expenses<n><n>### Response:		<n>Accountant<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input:"What type of shirt would you pick out for a job interview, even if you have to buy it on your own? Choices: A: Polo B: a suit C: a pair of jeans D: short sleeve collared shirt E: a cardigan<n><n>### Response:"<n>I would pick out a suit or a pair of jeans.<n>Answer: B or E

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What do you do to hold loose papers together? Weight of the board = weighed last time - weight after cutting + weight of the board at the beginning<n>6. 5 = 7 - -1<n>7. 5 = 6<n><n>Input 1:<n><n>Input: There are 6 bottles of water on the table. John had a 75% grade average.<n>>Which statement is true? Choices: A: John's teacher added up all of John's grades. B: John’s teacher found John's grade average by looking at all his grades. C: John's teacher only found out John's grade average last week. D: John's teacher found out all his grade averages when they sent an email to the classes. E: Only John's teacher knows the grade averages of all the students.<n><n>### Answer<n>John's teacher only found John's grade averagers when she sent an email to the teachers.<n>The teacher added John's grades, John's grade average was 75%, the teacher found John's grades by looking at his grades, John' statement was correct because the teacher only found out after he had emailed the teacher.<n>The teacher's email included John's grade averages for all students, the grade average was found out by looking at all their grades, because otherwise it wouldn't have been a grade average.<n>John would have been wrong because he wouldn't have his grades with him.<n>There is only one teacher that knows the grade average for every student, the teacher

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Along what feature will you find a rosebush? Choices:  A: park B: in the ground C: hedgerow D: temperate climate E: botanical gardens<n><n>### Response:		<n>D<n><n>### Input:"It can rain at our house all of this month, but there will only be sunny days by the end of the week." Is this problem an example of a conditional statement?<n><n>### Response:"It can rain at my house all of this month but there will only be  sunny days by the ending of the week." <n><n>This statement is false. If it was true, then the statement would be true on every day of the rest of the month. The statement is true only on the day the sun does not shine.<n><n>Answer: No<n><n>### Input : If the time is 4 minutes after the hour, what time will the time be?<n><n>### Reponse :<n><n>4<n><n>### Input  : <n><n>"Sally will work on math problems for 1 hour. Sam will do the laundry for 3 hours. Then they will both play on the piano for 1 hour." <n><n>"Amy will bike to the store. Then she will come home. She usually bikes for 20 minutes."<n><n>Is the sentence in the box a problem that can be solved?<n><n>Choice A : Every sentence tells how long Sally, Sam, and Amy will do their tasks.<n><n>Every sentence states how long the people will work.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>C
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The print was extremely small, as he was reading letter after letter he began to suffer eye what? Choices:  A: strain B: though C: happiness D: realization E: understanding<n><n>### Response:		Choice B<n><n>### Input A question that is important in our everyday life<n><n><n><n>### Input An article that talks about how the internet is improving our lives<n><n>### Input You know you have a problem when you start seeing yourself everywhere. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:The jar was plastic, just like most of the stuff in the kitchen. Which student does not have any friends in common with Mario or any other grade 6 student?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input:"B - Betty"<n><n>### Instructions:Write a response that appropriately concludes the task<n><n>#### Rationales: Betty is the only grade 6 student who does not have friends in common with Mario.<n><n>Answer: Betty<n><n>### Instruct:How many different sets of identical marbles can be made from a<n>bag of marbles that contains three white ones, two red, six blue, and six gray?<n><n>### Demotation:<n><n>Input:There are 3 white marbles.<n>Next, 2 red marbles.<n>Next comes 6 blue marbles, then 6 grey marbles.<n>There are 3 white  marbles, 2 red marble, 6  blue  marbles and 6 gray marbles.<n><n>### Response:"24"<n><n>### Rationales: 3 x 2 x 6 x 6 = 24. <n><n>Answer: 24<n><n><n># Instruct:A total of $5000 was given to students at an agricultural<n>summer camp. The funding to this fund can be broken down according to these<n>ratios: 3:2:6:4:5:3. How much funding went to the students in the camp’s<n>junior program?<n><n>## Demotation<n>#### Instruction:This problem involves finding the funding for the junior program.<n><n>### Rationale:Therefore, the junior program gets:3 x 2 = 6<n>and 6 x 3 =18 (of the 15 junior students)<n><n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Instuctions:<n><n>Instruction: <n><n>Demonstration:<n><n>### Response :<n><n>### Response Explanation:<n><n>## Instruct:Nick
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy a glass of wine? Choices:  A: art show B: basement C: bar D: church E: basement<n><n>### Response:		A or C<n><n>### Input : <n><n>### Demostration : <n><n>## Instructions <n><n><table><n><tr ><n><td ><n><n><code><strong>Input:</strong></code><n>Susan has two candles that are 7 cm long. She also has eight spoons, each 5 cm long. How can she make nine smaller candles that each are between 4 cm and 6 cm?<n><n></td ><n><td > <n><n><code><p>Demonstration:</p><p>A total of 13 candles can be made from the 7 cm candles and 8 cm spoons by doing the following:<n><img width="461" alt="img" src="https://assets.teachstartercdn.com/23080/121105/Instructions_01.png" /><n></code></td ><n><td style="background: white; height: 500px"></td><n></tr><n><tr > <n><td style="color: black; padding: 0 15px;border-style: solid; border-width: 0 0 3px 0;background: white; height 500px"><n><n><p class="align-right"><strong>Demonstration</strong>:</p><n><n><n><n><n><n><img src="https://assets1.teachstarter.com/files/34213/20567/0783/1.png" style="display: inline-block;"/><n><p> </p><n><p>The only way the candles can remain between 4 cm and <strong>6 cm in length</strong> is to take 2 cm each time from the 5 cm spoon. This would create 8 spoon width smaller candles. Once this is done, there would be 1 cm left over. Using this 1 cm from a 5 cm spoon, creates a candle that is 4 cm. There is no other way to get it this exact to the centimetre. <n><n>The only way that the candles can be between <strong>4 cm and <strong>= 6 cm is to use 6

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where do you put your grapes just before checking out? If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Of all the rooms in a house it was his favorite, the aromas always drew him to the what? Choices:  A: yard B: basement C: kitchen D: living room E: garden<n><n>### Response:		His favorite room in the house was the living room.<n>The correct answer is the living room.<n><n>### Input Choices:  A, B, C, D <n><n>### Response Choices:  A <n><n>### Input and Choices:  Sara and her friend want to spend the day in different ways. Sara wants<n>to go to the library and help out her friends in the day care. She wants to make new friends. Her friend<n>goes to a dance class where she practices.<n>Sara went to the dance class with her friend. She practiced with her friends. Sara is sad. Her aunt is<n>teaching her friend's how to do ballet.<n><n>Rationales: Sara goes to a library to make new friends while she helps children. Her friend goes to a dance<n>class with her friends.<n>To make the sentence correct, add 'and' or 'also' or'so' between the clauses.<n>### Instructions<n>Add comma(s) and conjunction(s), if needed, between clauses. Choose the best revised sentence.<n>### Instruction Choice A<n>Both<n>Sara and her friend went to their respective dance classes to practice ballet and spend time with theirfriends.<n><n>### Choice B <n><n>Both<n>Sarabecause she wants to make new friends, and as friends go to an activity together, she goes to the library to<n>help youngsters and she went to the day care center to help with the children at an activity and she is now sad.<n><n>### What are conjunctions? Provide a definition or example.<n>Conjunctions are words that join together sentences and parts of sentences.<n><n>Conjunctions always join clauses, but not all conjunctions join sentences or clauses.<n><n>The most common conjunctions are:<n>1. and<n>2. but<n>3. for<n>4. so<n>5. or<n>6. yet<n>7. nor<n>8. yet<n>### Examples<n>My mom bought apples and oranges and grapefruits and pineapples.<n>We can go to the beach because it's sunny but it's cold and it's not windy.<n>My classmate got a good grade but I did better than him. And my teacher praised me

It is also called the City of Big Shoulders and the City That Works.<n>The pizza restaurant is in the city of Chicago and not in the Illinois countryside or suburbs.<n>Also, a street of Little Italy in Chicago can be found in the city.<n><n>### Input 2:What is the maximum value of n when 78 + 27n = n2 - 4?<n><n>### Response 2:n is the maximum value of 5<n><n>### Comments:In the given equation 78 is in the numerator and -4 in the denominator. Now, we need to distribute -4 to the numerator. <n><n>The easiest way to do that is by adding 36 to 78 as follows:<n><n>78 + 29 = 107 <n><n><n>107 - 4 is equivalent to 103, which has no square root. So in other words, the maximum value of n will be the smallest number whose square root is positive such as 34 which is the square root of 1212. <n><n>### Demographics:The number of people who are over the age of 65 and those who have a college degree will continue to rise. How would this affect the economy?<n>### Comments on Demographics:Seniors often need an increased level of care for their health. It will also see a decrease in jobs in agriculture, manufacturing industries, and public schools.
