Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:It was a vast complex, the launch pad was just one part of what? Choices:  A: movie B: cape kennedy C: space center D: military installation E: spaceship centre<n><n>### Response:		A: Cape Kennedy<n><n>### Explanation:Cape Kennedy is the proper name for what was formerly known as Cape Canaveral.<n><n>### Source:https://www.britannica.com/topic/Cape-Canaveral<n><n>### Rationale:Cape Kennedy was established as the Cape Canaveral space center in 1963 because of President Kennedy's vision of the United States becoming a prominent player in the Space Race. Later, it was re-designated as the John F. Kennedy Space Center.<n>### Input:Aaron and Bob can build a wooden bench together in a week and Fred and Jerry can build one together in 5 weeks. If Aaron, Bob and Fred work together to finish a bench, in how many weeks will it take them to complete the bench?<n><n>### Response:- <n><n>### Explnation:- We notice that the time to build the bench is in weeks.<n><n>### Exptential:- If Aaron, Bob, and Fred can build a wooden benche in ______ weeks then they can build it in(We write the bench using the same format as the statement) = 5/6 weeks<n><n>### Logical:- If Aaron and Bob build in 1 week then Bob and Fred build in 5/6 week <n><n>And Jerry and Bob build in 5/14 week<n>then Aaron and Bob build bench in 5/6/5/14 = 10/8 = 5/2 = 3/1 week<n>So the ans is that the time taken in days can be calculated using the formula given below<n>- If Aaron, Bob can build a wooden in a week and Fred,Jerry can build a bench in 5 weeks <n>then the time taken in days = 1/(5/2) =1/(3/1) =5/2=2.5 days<n><n>- The time for a bench using 3 people =5/2 * 2.5=31.25 days which is rounded off to 31 days<n><n>### Source:-https://www.hirestutors.com/solved/if-aaron-and-bob-can-build-a-bench-together-in-a-week-and-fred
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:He wore the wrong shoes while walking all day, now he has what on his heels and toes? Choices:  A: exercise B: moving forward C: feet D: blisters E: locomotion<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>> The correct answer is locomotion<n><n>> **Rationale**<n><n>He could use locomotion (which means moving) with whatever shoes he wears. If its socks then he has socks on his heels and/or toes.<n><n>### Input :There are 3 shirts in your closet, 6 socks in the drawer, and a pair of pants, 2 pencils, and pair of sneakers. Your neighbor wants a total of 18, 26, and 44 how many of each do you have to give him? Choices : A: 7, 6, 10.B: 8, 7, 15. C: 9, 7, 24.D: 10, 6, 44.E: 11, 8, 39<n><n>### Response :The correct answer is E (11,8,39)<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>> The sum of the total of your shirt, sock, pant, pencil and shoe are equal to 18 + 26 + 44 = 98. So from 98 you are supposed to give some numbers and that makes it an equation. Adding the clothing, we get 3 + 6 + 2 + 2. Therefore 11 + 8 + 39 = 58. So the solution of that equation is 58 x 2 = 116. Hence the shirt is 11, sock is 8 and shoe is 39.<n><n>## Riddle-<n>I came across a person, I have never seen before. <n>What am I?<n><n>### A: Turtle<n><n>Turtle looks like a person, and it’s kind of rare. <n><n>### B: Manhole<n><n>If it's a manhole, It's like a person that is on the ground or grounded. <n><n>## Riddle 2 -<n>Six of them are on the farm.<n>Nine of them are black.<n>If you take just two away from the six you still have an equal number in the group.<n><n>### A : Black cows<n><n>B : Six black c

Choices:  A: look at B: write down C: learn new D: think about E: discovery of new<n><n>### Response:		Discovery of new<n><n>## What is a recursive function<n><n>The definition and uses of a recursive function. Recursion is the procedure of defining a function in terms of itself. For example the factorial function can be defined, like any function, by choosing an object and a procedure for determining the value of the object given the value of the object, this latter object, and the operation chosen to determine the value of the object from the value of an object and the operation chosen to obtain that object's value from the object's value, and so on and so forth. One method for doing this is to let f(x) be the object (that was previously defined by the chosen procedure) and f(x) the result of the procedure.<n><n>### For Every Input, there is an Output<n><n>What each number in the language does (for every number there is an output)<n><n>Number: input<n><n>### If, Else<n><n>If and Else are a programming language statement used to specify conditions or branches<n><n>If (then):<n><n>If a variable is true, this part of the code is executed<n><n>Else:<n><n>If the variable is false, this part of the will be entered into the code instead of the "then" portion<n><n>### Math Example<n><n>```<n>if(a < b)<n>	if (a+b > c)<n>  	  p= a+b;<n>else<n>	p=a-b;<n>```<n><n>### Examples of Math/Calculus Problems using If/Else<n><n>```<n>3+4<n>```<n><n>## Code<n><n>### Exercise: Functions<n><n>#### Write a function called sum that takes two numbers and adds them.<n><n>    function sum(x, y){<n>        return number is sum;<n>    }<n><n><n>#### Write a recursive function called triple that takes any number as an input and returns the triple of that number. For example, triple(6) should return triple(3)(2)(1).<n><n>    Function triple(number){<n>        return triple(number);<n>        if(number == 2)<n>            return number+1;<n>        else<n>            return (three(number)+one(number+1))<n>    }<n><n>#### Write a sumRec function that takes any amount of number as an input and<n>returns the sum using recursion.<n><n><n>#### A
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A common saying, Sam thought, was to go forth, also this. Choices:  A: reverse B: backwards C: back and D: back and E: tally back<n><n>### Response:		Choice: B<n><n>### Rationale:<n>A common saying goes something like "Go for it." <n>Since "for it" could mean many things, going "forward" or "toward" is logical to say. <n>However, since the word "and" is used, this means that "back" is being suggested.<n>Therefore, the choice that involves "back" is the correct one.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Input from the original program is as follows:<n>Common saying "go forth, also this." <n><n>There is a problem with this statement. "Go forth" should be reversed and not backward. Therefore, the choice that says go back instead of backward is correct. "Back and forth, also this" would be correct though, but the choice does not say that in it.<n><n>### Input From Original: Go for it. <n><n>### Inventory: Go for it. This can have many meanings. Go forward or go towards means going forward, not reversing. Therefore, back is the correct answer.<n><n>---<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:A shower is an expected amenity when you reserve a what? Choices:  A: gy mnasiu m B: motel room C: seashore D: bath room E: locker room<n><n>### Response:		A:gy mnasiu m<n><n><n><n>### Explanation<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the following tasks. Some task solutions are incomplete. Do not attempt to complete those tasks. Instead, use your skills of inference to complete the task.<n><n>#### Task Solutions:<n><n><n>### Question:If a bakery charged $10 for 4 loaves of bread, how much would they charge for 66 loaves of bread?<n><n>### Task:<n>Input: If a bakery charged \$10 for 4 (loaves) of bread, how much 66 (loaves) of money would they the bakery money?<n><n>Demonstration:<n>This question involves determining the amount of money a bakery would charge for 66 (loves of bread).<n><n>First, we need to determine how to represent 4 and 66 as fractions. <n><n>We know that there are 60 minutes in an hour, so dividing an hour by 60 gives us the unit fraction for an hour, which is 1 / 60. Divide 66 (loaches of bread by 60; how many loaches of bread are in an hour. Divide 60 by 4: how many hours are in a loache of bread. 4 x 60 = 240. Multiply 4 (four) by each of these factors: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 to determine the answer of the question. <n><n>Input: 66 can be represented as 60 x 4- (60 divided by 4) so answer 4 x 6 is 240.<n><n>### Questions:How many times can the sum of the 1st 19 odd numbers be divided by the 1st 5 even numbers?<n><n>### Answer:11<n><n>### Tasks:<n><n>### Question #1:How many times can you subtract 3 from 15 and 7 from 7 to get the same answer?<n><n>### Question#1:The question states to subtract 3 from 7 and 7 from 15. <n>You can subtract 3 7's to get to 3 - 3 = 0

(B) There is a total 152 boxes, 15 bottles, and cups. <n> <n>### Task: Add the correct sign and then multiply the total by the product. (A)(10/10) (B)(-46 +34) (A x B)<n><n>### Demostration:<n>A: -46 <n><n>When multiplying 10 x (the product to be calculated), the positive sign would be taken because when we multiply together two unlike quantities, that means that the product of the number is positive. Because in this case the first quantity of both answers in the column of A is 10, then that means the product will be positive because the product of a positive number and another positive number is a positive number too.<n><n>B: 34 <n><n>When multipiling 10 with (the product to be calulated), the negative sign would be taken because the second quantity in the column of A, which is the first quantity in the second column, is negative. That means that when we multiply a negative number to another negative number, that mean that the product of number is negative as well. The same thing goes for this problem in which (B)(-45) is being multiplied with (10) and it will then become (-45)(10).<n><n>A x B: 10 * (-45) = -460 <n><n>### Answer: 232 pears and bottles<n><n>### Instructions: Read the list carefully. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:They wanted to eat at home but the cupboards were barren, so they had to go what? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: eat C: go back to work D: make food E: get food<n><n>### Response:		Go what?<n>### Answer:Back to work<n><n>### Why?:Because they were starving and they hadn't cook dinner yet.<n><n>### Why not?:A, C, D didn't make any sense.<n><n>### How would you know if the answer is wrong?:The answer to the question must be incorrect because either you don't have cupboards or don't have food and they can't go back to work to get food and if you know how to cook then there is no need to eat out and the other answer didn't make any grammatical sense.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What would you do if you have curiosity about something but cannot leave your house? Choices:  A: hear testimony B: go somewhere C: see exhibits D: outdoor concert E: surf net<n><n>### Response:		A: hear testimony.<n><n>Rationales: A is the right choice because you can hear testimony from somewhere. You cannot ask to go to somewhere because you are physically isolated.<n>You cannot ask to go outside because you probably don't have a place to go to and you might get hurt.<n>A, B, C, D, and E are excluded because you cannot do them if you have a limited mobility.<n><n>### Input <n>Answer:<n>C<n>Input: A 7-layer dip usually contains (choices): <n>A. chives, black olives, and sour cream <n>B. green olive halves, jalapeno slices, and cheese <n>C. sour cream, tomato, and cilantro <n>D. avocado, jack, cheddar, cream cheese, and sour creme <n><n>### response: A<n><n>Rationales <n>A is correct because it contains avocado slices, black olives, corn taters, green onions, salsa, sour cream, tortilla chips, and tomato slices.<n><n>B is incorrect because it contains sour cream, sour creme, tomato, jack cheese, and avocadoes.<n><n>C is incorrect because it contains the following ingredients: tomato, salsa, corn, sour cream and avocados. <n><n>D is incorrect because it contains jack cheese, chedder cheese, cream cheese and sour cream.<n><n>### <n>A) You can get your 40,000 steps, your daily dose of fruit, and stay cool at the same time by walking down to your favorite park.<n>B) You can get your steps in walking down to your favorite museum, and still get your fruit in because museums usually have cafes and restaurants that sell fruit.<n>C) You can get the steps you need because you are on the subway.<n>D) You can get your daily dose of fruits by simply adding pineapple to your breakfast.<n>E) You can get your exercise if you decide to take an aerobics class at your local community center.<n>Fruit/Health/Diet<n><n>### 		Input:<n>###

Choices:  A: europe B: big house C: tuxedo D: palace E: men's room<n><n>### Response:		<n>A, B or C<n><n>### Rationale:<n>All wealthy people live in a big house. Men dressed up for weddings might live in a palace. A rich man who wants to be noticed flaunts his wealth. This means that if he is trying to show he has lot of money, he will dress as well as he can so people will know he has money.<n><n>### A<n><n>* Europe? No, not all wealthy people live in Europe.<n>* Big house? Yes, so A is the correct answer.<n><n>### B<n><n>* Big house? No, this does not make sense.<n>* Men's room? No, men dressed up for weddinsg would not likely live in a men's room, and so B is eliminated.<n><n>### C<n><n>* Big house, tuxedo, palace? No, a tuxedo is for weddings and only men dressed up for wedding would live in a palace. So C is eliminated.<n>* Wealthy? Yes, a wealthy man will dress as well as they can to show that they have lot of money.<n><n>## Tip1<n><n>The first answer is correct, the rest are incorrect, B&C do not make any sence at all<n><n>## Response 2<n><n>1. Big house is correct<n><n>### Response 3<n><n>Choices: A: Europe B: big house C men's room D: palace E: tuxedo<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>Let me start by saying that I feel this question is flawed... the answer to this question is C, the tuxedo. The best argument to C (Tux) is that the correct answer is a BIG HOUSE.<n><n>The question reads: "where does he likely live?", not “where is he from?”.<n>While the gentleman may be from Europe, we do not know whether or not he has lived there. The question leaves too many ambiguities. We do know that BIG HOUSE is correct.<n><n>1. TUXEDOS are for weddings.<n>2. Dressing up for weddings may require a palace (since big houses are sometimes rented for weddings).<n>3. Men

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What chore might a child have to do after breakfast, before getting on the bus? There are two ways to find the greatest difference between them. <n>The difference between 95 and 153 is 58, which is the biggest difference possible. <n>If we add 3 to 95, we have 98 and also if we add 4 to 153, we have 157. The difference between those two will still be 58 because you subtracted 3 from 98 and subtracted 4 from 153.<n><n>### Solution:98 - 02 = +58<n><n>## Instructions:<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>### Multiple<n>Input: A child has 13 marbles. 5 of the marbles are red. What is the probability that another marble the child draws is also red?<n>Rationales The problem involves finding the probability that another marbel drawn will be red.  There are three possible answers.  There are two red marbles, so it is 2/13 which would be.154545462399 (rounded to 15.45%).<n><n>### Multiple 2<n>You've been tasked with helping design a new dive suit that can hold more air than an ordinary one. If a diver is wearing the new suit and takes it off, when is the air in the suit less than it was when he took off his old suit?<n>Rationales<n>A suit with more girth can hold more air but when the diver takes the suit off there will be more space that is no longer filled with air, which means that the space will not have as
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where can someone view a county highway as a line? Choices:  A: from the sky B: map C: cross counties by car D: country E: michigan<n><n>### Response:		The correct response is **D**. County is spelled **COUNTRY.**<n><n>### Instructions: The two pictured drawings represent the letter **S.**<n><n>## Inverted U<n><n>### Instuctions:Look at the pictured inverted U. Is the shaded area between the two legs shaded or not shaded?<n><n>### Output:The shaded area is shaded.

Choices:  A: grocery store B: grocery bag C: restaurants D: farmer's market E: bushel basket<n><n>### Response:		<n>A- You use a grocery store.<n><n>B- You store it in a grocery bag.<n><n>C- You use a restaurant.<n><n>D- You use a farmer's market.<n><n>E- You store it in an old bushel basket.<n><n>### Output: <n>A- Grocery stores, unlike restaurants or farmer's markets, typically sell potatoes in big bags. So you carry your potato home from a grocery store in a bag. <n><n>B- You use a grocer's bag to carry home your potatoes.<n><n>C- Restaurants typically give away their potatoes to people who say that they plan on cooking the potatoes themselves. For example, customers who order a large helping of chips get a large bag with extra potato. The customers cannot use a big potato. A smaller potato will not suffice. So you use a restaurant when you intend on making potatoes for your family and use a bushel basket when you intend on making the potatoes into chips. <n><n>D- A grocery bag has enough room in it for groceries. The grocer's bags used to carry people's groceries. They used to carry them on a long journey but grocery store potatoes are small and do not take a long time to carry to their homes. They carry a potato in a grocery store bag. Since it does not take too much of people's time, they do not need to take a long trip with their groceries. <n><n>E- People use a bushel basket to carry home their potatoes. Some potatoes are expensive but these potatoes cost money, not time. However, some potatoes are too expensive to buy and these potatoes cost both time and money. <n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where do almost all people live? Choices:  A: football stadium B: apartment C: surface of earth D: car show E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>I'm pretty sure almost all people live in a house!<n><n>### Input<n>I found a recipe that makes a cake.  Here is the recipe:<n>To make a cake, you will need 2 cups of flour, 2 cups of sugar, 4 eggs, and 1 cup of vegetable oil. In the recipe, the author writes x+y cups of flour (which you can read as x(x+y) or x + x) but x=y.<n>This means that you need 3 cups of flour. You will also need 2 cups plus 4 cups of sugar (or 4(2) cups sugar). This means you need total of 5 cups of sugar. You will also need a total of 5 eggs which you know are four cups (4(2)) eggs. Finally, you need a total of three cups (3(4) cups) vegetable oil. Your recipe for making a cake is:<n>Total cups for flour: 3 cups (3(2))    cups for sugar: 5 cups for eggs: 5 cups (4(4)) cups for oil: 3 cups for recipe: 1(5+5+3+5) = 56<n><n>The author made a common decimal error. Correct the equation to solve for x.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The problem involves a recipe.<n><n>First, find out how many cups of sugar (total and separately) are needed. <n><n>56 ÷ 5 = __, which converts to: 56 ÷ 4<n><n>The total cup of sugar (56) is converted to cups of sugar (4) by finding the 56 ÷ ___, replacing the ___ with 5, and then dividing the original (56) whole number by the ____ (4) whole number. <n><n>So, cups of sugar = 56 ÷ __.<n><n>Now that you know how many cups of flour to use, you can plug each measurement into a separate column of the __. You have already determined the amount of sugar to use (2 cups). <n><n>Sugar: 56 ⁄ 0 = 56 cups of sugar

Choices: A: Absolutely B: Yes C: No D: I don't know E: I prefer a horse in my backyard.<n><n>### Response 1: I think it would be awesome to see a carousel circle around a tree. I prefer a carousel to a horse in my back yard.<n><n>### Input 2: I do prefer a horse in my yard over a carousel. The only time I would like a carousel is when I'm at the park.<n><n>### Solution:If I prefer a carousel in my yard to a horse than the correct answer is B. Choice A and C are incorrect since I prefer a carousel over a horse in a backyard, while choice D says that I like cars from my yard and choice E says I prefer a horse over a carousel.<n><n>### Comment: <n><n>### Detailed Answer:<n><n>Answer A is correct. Answer B is the answer you prefer while choice A is the answer you like more, hence the best answer. Answer C is incorrect because it is not an answer. Choice D is incorrect. It is not a logical statement. You would like a carousel when it is at the park so you should have chosen A. Choice E is incorrect. The only time you would like a carousel in your backyard is if you like a horse better. You would only then like a carousel in place of a horse.<n><n>### Another Comment:<n><n>### Another Solution:<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Bob needs a level to hang a shelf but cant find one in his home. Where would he go to get one? Choices:  A: glass of water B: build evenly C: garage D: carpenter's shop E: video game<n><n>### Response:		He would go to the hardware store aka the build evenly. A would be a good one but not correct, B is not correct either. C and D are incorrect. E is not correct also.<n><n>### Input : <n><n>Insects in a forest must move up as temperature gets warmer during the day and down to cooler areas at night. If temperature is 63 degrees all day, where would you expect the most insect activity to be?<n>(A): Daytime<n>(B): Evening<n>(C): Morning<n>(D): During the day and evening<n><n>### Rationale: D. Morning and evening are both correct, but during the day is even more correct. Morning is still not correct because the question states, during the day gets warmer, so insects move up. During the day is correct, morning is when the sun comes up and it is getting warmer.<n><n>### Choice 1<n><n>### Answer:<n>C<n><n>## Difficulty Level<n><n>## Input :<n>Hard<n><n>### Difficulty:<n>There are a total of five answers available.<n><n>### Explaination :<n><n>Choose the answer that describes the following input:  One can make 10 mugs for a total of $56. For each additional mug one can make, you can earn another $0.30. How much money will you earn and for which mugs?<n><n>Hard<n><n>#### Answer:<n><n><n>## Input:Jimmy has five bags of cereal. Bread costs $2 for two loaves, while cereal costs $5 for 5 bags. If his total money is $12, how many bags of cereals must he buy? <n><n>### Rationales:<n><n><n>How much money will you earm for buying cereal and bread? <n><n>For cereal and bread, I chose the correct answer.<n><n>I decided that bread costs $2 for two bags, so if I make a total of $12, I will have to invest in 5 bags of cereel.<n><n>I know that cereal costs $10 per bag.<n><n>I have to pay $12 for making 5 bags of bread, giving me a total of $36

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where in a town would you put your shed? Choices:  A: next to the house B: keeping things in C: backyard D: farm yard E: ranch<n><n>### Response:		<n>The instructions are ambiguous. We can't tell if the location is near the house, on the property, or far from the house and away from civilization (in the barn and out in the sticks). For each of these types of location, the shed needs to be large enough to cover the things we use in that location.<n><n>**If the location is near the (city) house, we need a big, tall shed like a barn so we can use our stuff away from the mess and noise of the city. Then we can buy a small shed for each location.**<n><n> **If the location is not in the city but on the house's property, then a smaller shed is fine. Then we can buy sheds for each location.** <n><n> **If the shed can go anywhere and anytime and no one minds - we don't need anyone to help us move it, we can take it where we go - then we can just get one big shed for wherever/whenever.**<n><n>Answer: Big shed<n><n>### Input :A group of students were asked :What's your favorite color?<n><n>### Response :<n>There is some ambiguity here. Is "color" a person? Are they asking us about our favorite color or if we are a color?<n><n>If they are asking us if we are a color, then they don't mean "What's your favorite (noun)" but "What color (adjective) are you? or "What color are you?".<n><n>If they are really asking us to pick a favorite color, then ask what they meant if they were asking: "A: What is your favorite color?"<n><n>If they meant "Color is a person," then "What's your (colored person's) favorite color?" would make the most sense.<n><n>Answer: They meant "What is your favorite color?" <n><n>### Input:-The car needed one gallon of fuel to run 70 miles. Choices:  A: united states B: atlas C: developed land D: park E: countryside<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Rationale:An atlas does not specify streets of a city or streets of a highway, but rather the general land mass and terrain of the whole country. This feature is useful to travelers because it provides a bird's eye view of the general geography of the country.<n><n>#### Example:<n>In 1609, the English explorer of the New World and navigator Sir Francis Drake published "The World Encompassed," the first English text printed on two continents. The text, which was written while Drake was in San Francisco Bay, was eventually published in London in 1628. In the book, Drake described his 1577 circumnavigation of the globe, describing the terrain of various land masses, as well as noting their navigable and treacherous nature. Some of the descriptions in the book would have been taken from maps, which had been created and used for centuries by explorers like Christopher Columbus, Vasco da Gama, and Ferdinand Magellan.: 84–89  Even earlier, the Ptolemy-Al-Maari map dating from 1300 was the first portrayal of the New World, with a depiction of the Aztec people.<n><n>### Another example:<n><n>In the early 1870's the United States Coast Pilot System developed the first maps of American coastal waters, and in 1891 the United States Geological Survey produced an atlas, the 1:24,000 scale U.S. Geological Survey's Standard Map of the United States.: 63, 117  The Department of the Interior's Geological Survey provided maps of the country until it was transferred in 1907 to the newly formed Bureau of the United States Geological and Geographical Survey, which was changed in 1969 to the USGS under the Department of the Interior. The bureau is responsible for mapping earthquake zones, mineral resources, and the water and wildlife, and is administered by an appointed director, and governed by national policy. The bureau's Director of the National Cartography and Petroleum Geology Division is also the Chief of the Mapping Services and is responsible for the production of the USGS Topographic and Atlas maps. The bureau uses a

This clue will help you determine the "might not" - think about "why" and what is missing or different. <n><n>1. Is it a real word?<n>  * If it is correct, continue to the next step. If it is incorrect, select the correct letter option and continue to the next step<n>  * You have correctly answered the question. Move to the next step.<n><n>Is it the real world?<n><n>2. A real word?<n>  If so, it is the real world.<n>  Move to the next step<n><n>3. Is it a word from the passage?<n>  If so the information cannot be from the passage<n>  Move to the correct letter option<n><n>4. Is it a real world?<n>  If so it is the real world<n>  Move to the letter option "real world"<n><n>5. Remember, your job is answering what "might not be?" <n><n>Move to the letter option, "Humans"<n><n>10. Incorrect<n>The answer is not a word. Move to letter option "wrong".<n><n>11. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where do most people keep their curling iron stored? Choices:  A: bathroom B: walkway C: use D: hair salon E: drawer<n><n>### Response:		D <n><n>### Demostration:<n>The hair salon is the place where curling irons are most likely to be stored as it is the place where people tend to wash, dry, and style their hair.<n><n><n>### Input  : A book and a can of pop have different heights on the shelf.  If the taller objects (in feet) are $5, then what is the less-taller object (in feet) ?<n><n>### Response  : 4 <n><n>### Rationales : The height of a book is represented by $5. The height of a can is represented by the difference between the height of the book and the height of the can, hence the taller object is $5 and the less-taller is the difference between the taller object and the less-tall. <n><n>### Input :  If the area of a room measures 4 yards by 3 yards, then what is its perimeter?<n><n>### Response : 18 <n><n>### Response Demonstated:<n>Input : The area of a room measures $4\times 3$ <n><n>Output : $\sqrt{3}(\sqrt{12}\times 4)$ = $12\sqrt{3}$ <n><n>Output perimeter area = $12\times \sqrt{3} \approx 18$<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>You will answer YES or NO at the end of each question. There are a maximum of 25 points available.<n><n>Answers:<n><n>0 <= p <= 10<n><n>0 <= q <=10<n><n>p+q <= 20<n><n><n><n>### Question 1:  Can you use your own voice to create a humming sound?<n><n>### Question #2  :  Do you speak English?<n><n>### Answer #3:  <n>(1) The length of the line segments must be 20 or 21 cm and not be different. Their heights can be changed. <n>(2) If one length of the line segments is short (smaller than 20 cm) or if one is tall (larger than 20 cm), then the product will be 12. This is because we can use the line segments to represent a product.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What does a master carpenter use to put holes in objects? Choices:  A: drill B: learn C: require obedience D: understand E: spoon<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale:<n>I need to choose the correct choice in order to earn more points.<n><n>I checked the options and A and D both have 5 letters. This tells me they are nouns.<n><n>Next, if A is the correct choice then I take the first letter of A and the first letter of B. AB.<n><n>These are both consonants.<n><n>Therefore, I can eliminate choices B, C and D because they have vowels in the first letter.<n><n>Finally, I check the first letter of A (the vowel) and the last letter of E (the consonant).<n><n>These are the same letter and therefore, I can eliminate choice E because it is not correct.<n><n>So, the answer is A. <n><n>Answer: A<n><n>## Instructions<n>1.Write a response that appropriately selects the letter or letters that can be used to complete each task.<n><n>## Sample Output<n>Example 1:<n>```output<n>> Write a response that appropriates correctly choose the letter or letters that are used for each task.<n><n>Example 1: Choose a letter of the alphabet that starts with a vowel is a consonant in the middle and ends with a consonant.<n>Response:<n>The letter in the middle is Y. <n><n>Example 2: Choose a letter in the middle of the alphabet. <n><n>Response:<n>Letter: S.<n>```<n><n>Example 2<n>```output<n>> Choose a letter in which the first consonant is always used as a vowel. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Changing society using a violent conflict is know as a what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Everybody raised a drink and cheered, they were doing what? Choices:  A: were thirsty B: toasting C: getting drunk D: refreshment E: celebrating<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n><n><n>### Input:-2 x 3 =?  Choices:- 7 - 3 - 4 - 1 - 2 - 1<n><n>### Response:-<n><n>### Input1:120 - 20 = 90 Choices1: 90 110 130 150 170 190<n><n>### Response1:110<n><n>### InstructionsA person will get 900 for 9 years' work, but 1600 for 5/3 years' work. How much will he get for 21/3 years' work?<n><n>### Instructors Rationales:- 1600 9 years' work<n>- 900 21/3 year's work<n>- 64*3*21/3 = 677+33*3*21=2174<n>- 677 + 1969 = 2646<n>### Response<n><n>### Instuctions:- What number did Sam get when he multiplied 4×10? Choose the correct answer. Choices:___15___, 16, 14, 17, _20 _<n>### Response:20<n><n>### Question:- Find the answer for the sum of the digits in 9213. ___ _ __\ 38<n>### Response:3__8 <n><n>### Question:Multiply 4×16. ___ __ _ 256<n>### Response: 256<n><n>### Question:"Who will win a race if she runs at a speed of 4 miles per hour and the other gal runs 2.5 miles per hour?" Choices:__1__, __2__, __3__, __1801 ___ 1200<n>### response:1801<n><n>### Questions:525÷3. What is the remainder? Choices: _5_ 182 238 235 _ 0<n>### Response284<n><n>### Question538÷6. What is the remainder. Choices:_5__6_ __

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:John is getting something important.  What does this make him feel? Choices:  A: then have B: headaches C: stoic D: being happy E: wanting more<n><n>### Response:		John will be happy. If you think that John is in a situation with bad consequences, you probably have headaches. Stoic means a person who is calm and cool. John is calm, so he is stoic. We can say that John is stoic because he is calm and cool all of the time as a character.<n><n>### Input <n>A: $x^2 + y^2 = 25 <br> B: $x^2 - y^2 = 15 <br> C: $25x^2 - $25y^2 = 65 <br> D: $15x^2 - ($15)y^2 <br> E: $25x + $25y <br> F: $25x - $25y <hr><n><n>### Demostration:<n>Rationales: Here, we have 4 equations describing the relationship between $x$ and $y$. The given equation is one of these, so all we need to do is make sure the two equations are consistent, and the one true equation must be  $25x^p - 25y^p = 65$. We must find the exponent of $x$ and $x$. The denominator must be a number less than zero or equal to zero as well.<n>These will give us p.<n>Exponent= p=2<n>11 = 2<n>5 = 0<n>2 = - 5<n><n>So, the final equation will be: $25x^{2} - 25y^{2 = 65}$.<n><n>Answer: <n>$25x^{2}-25y^{2}=65$<n><n>Answer: 25x2 – 25y2 = 65<n><n>### Input<n>$2y$ divided by $9$<n><n>### Demos:<n>$y$ (the dividend) needs to divide into $2$, the dividend. Then, divide $2$ by $9$ (the divisor). So, $2$ divided by $1$ and 9 (the divisor) is the answer.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>$2y$ / 9 = __ <n>because we know $2$ can be divided into $9$ is $2/9$<n><n>##Input

If each can recycles 22 pounds each, and each can recycles $0.15 per pound, how much money will each recycle?<n><n>Input:Matt finished the work before Sally.Sally finished 3 hours before Matt.If each worked for 8 hours, how many more hours worked did Sally finish  than Matt finished?<n><n>Input:The can recycling center pay $0.20 per pound for aluminum, $0.05 per pound for plastic, and $0.15/pound if it’s metal. Each student can reuse their own cans, and donate cans from their families. Each day, students bring in cans in sets of ten. How much money will each recycled $60 if they do this once a day for a week?<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Explanation: For the first one (Mindy received..................................), I answered option C.The amount of cents Mindy received is 33 (she received 13 cents) + 9 (cents more than Mindy) +12 (cents less than Mindy).<n><n>Therefore, we get 33 + 9 + 12 = 54 which is not present on options (A): inside the book.<n>We get 33 + (9 + 4) + (12 – 1) = 54 which means it matches the option (C): oral report.<n>Option (A): inside the Book is false.   <n>Option (B): library is false.   <n><n>### Export:Sara received 12 less than Mindy.<n>$$<n><n>12 – 12 = 0<n>$$<n><n>That means Mindy receives 12 more than Sara - Mindy receives 33 and Sara receives 21:<n><n>$$<n>33 + 21 = 5

How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:John is a human who is in a wheelchair due to an accident.  Where would he go to get to the third floor of his apartment building? Choices:  A: space shuttle B: detroit C: stairs D: downtown E: elevator<n><n>### Response:		Option A: <n><n>### Demostration:<n><img src="images/JohnInSpaceShuttleToTheThirdFloor2.jpg"<n> alt="JohnOnTheSpaceShuttle"></img><n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Inputs:1. What is the name of the first <n><n>### Rationales A)<n>### Demostración<n><n>### Demotraction<n><n>### Input 2:<n>What do you call an organization that sends a team of 70<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Rationales: The problem involves determining how much money you would receive for recycling cans and newspapers. <n><n>First find out how many sets of 12 cans are in 144 cans. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total number of cans (144) by the number of cans per set (12). <n><n>144 ÷ 12 = 12 sets of cans. <n><n>Each set of can is worth $0.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the cans, multiply the number of sets (12) by the worth of each set ($0.50). <n><n>12 x $0.50 = $6 <n><n>Next, find out how many set of 5 kilograms of newspapers are in 20 kilograms. <n><n>This is done by dividing the total kilograms of newspapers (20) by the number of kilograms per set (5). <n><n>20 ÷ 5 = 4 sets of newspapers. <n><n>Each set of newspaper is worth $1.50. <n><n>To calculate the total worth of the newspapers, multiply the number of sets (4) by the worth of each set ($1.50). <n><n>4 x $1.50 = $6 <n><n>Finally, to find the total money earned, add the worth of the cans and the newspapers together. <n><n>$6 (for cans) + $6 (for newspapers) = $12.<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:One might find theirs open, with the letters that had been delivered stolen. Choices:  A: front door B: newspaper C: post office D: package E: mail box<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Rationales:B<n><n>Input:One might find their dog's bones scattered about the kitchen. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Rationales: Betty picked 16 strawberries. <n>Then, Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty which makes 16 + 20 = 36 strawberries.<n>Therefore, Matthew picked 36 strawberries.<n>We know that Matthew picked twice as many strawberries as Natalie. <n>So, Natalie picked 36/2 = 18 strawberries.<n>The total number of strawberries they all picked is 16 (Betty's) + 36 (Matthew's) + 18 (Natalie's) = 70 strawberries.<n>Each jar of jam requires 7 strawberries, so they can make 70 strawberries / 7 strawberries per jar = 10 jars of jam.<n>Each jar of jam is sold for $4, so they made 10 jars * $4 per jar = $40 from the strawberries they picked.<n>Therefore, they made $40 from selling the strawberries they picked.<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:He would finally see idea become reality, never in a million years did he what that this would happen? Choices:  A: lot of grief B: depression C: no spouse D: lose money E: children suffer<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Rationales:Divorces can have a huge negative impact on both spouses, but they also have an impact on children. This is because, often times, custody of the children is given to the parent who didn't want the divorce. These children must often change from one parent to another parent. This change usually results in lots of grief and depression and children usually suffer as a result.<n><n>### Input-In the case of this year, 50% of all children were born with deformities of some kinds, some of which were incapacitating.  How many children have incapacitating deformities?<n><n>### RESPONSE: A<n><n>### RATIONALE: First, if 50% of the children have incapaciting deformities, then 50% of every 100 children are not going to have incapacititing deformities and 50% of those 100 children will. The fraction of the 100 children that will not have incapacitinbing deformities is 100/2 = 50. Therefore, 50% (1) of every 10 children do not have incapicitating deformities, and 50% (2) of the remaining 90 children do not have it. Therefore, it can be concluded that for every 1000 children, 500 children do not have an incapacitating disorder. <n><n>### Input - What is 6 over ½, simplified? <n><n>### Rationailes - The numerator in the top fraction is six, and, as 6/2 = 3/1, there are three ones in ½. Therefore, each of the six ones counts in half of a whole, or three and one third. The answer is three and one third.<n><n>### Output - What is the sum of eight and seven?<n><n>### Response -The sum of eight and seven is 15.<n><n>### Rationale - Eight is 8+0 = 8 and seven is 7+0 = 7, so 8+7 = 15.<n>### Input- What is a sum of twenty-six and twenty-two?<n><n>
